# Augustine: Gospel According to St. John

**[1:1]** Lectures or Tractates  on the  gospel according to st.

**[1:2]** John.

**[1:3]** Tractate I.

**[1:4]** Chapter I.

**[1:5]** 1–5  1.

**[1:6]** When I give heed to what we have just read from the apostolic lesson, that "the natural man perceiveth not the things which are of the Spirit of God," and consider that in the present assembly, my beloved, there must of necessity be among you many natural men, who know only according to the flesh, and cannot yet raise themselves to spiritual understanding, I am in great difficulty how, as the Lord shall grant, I may be able to express, or in my small measure to explain, what has been read from the Gospel, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God;" for this the natural man does not perceive.

**[1:7]** What then, brethren? Shall we be silent for this cause? Why then is it read, if we are to be silent regarding it? Or why is it heard, if it be not explained? And why is it explained, if it be not understood? And so, on the other hand, since I do not doubt that there are among your number some who can not only receive it when explained, but even understand it before it is explained, I shall not defraud those who are able to receive it, from fear of my words being wasted on the ears of those who are not able to receive it.

**[1:8]** Finally, there will be present with us the compassion of God, so that perchance there may be enough for all, and each receive what he is able, while he who speaks says what he is able.

**[1:9]** For to speak of the matter as it is, who is able? I venture to say, my brethren, perhaps not John himself spoke of the matter as it is, but even he only as he was able; for it was man that spoke of God, inspired indeed by God, but still man.

**[1:10]** Because he was inspired he said something; if he had not been inspired, he would have said nothing; but because a man inspired, he spoke not the whole, but what a man could he spoke.

**[1:11]** 2.

**[1:12]** For this John, dearly beloved brethren, was one of those mountains concerning which it is written: "Let the mountains receive peace for thy people, and the hills righteousness".

**[1:13]** The mountains are lofty souls, the hills little souls.

**[1:14]** But for this reason do the mountains receive peace, that the hills may be able to receive righteousness.

**[1:15]** What is the righteousness which the hills receive? Faith, for "the just doth live by faith".

**[1:16]** The smaller souls, however, would not receive faith unless the greater souls, which are called mountains, were illuminated by Wisdom herself, that they may be able to transmit to the little ones what the little ones can receive; and the hills live by faith, because the mountains receive peace.

**[1:17]** By the mountains themselves it was said to the Church, "Peace be with you;" and the mountains themselves in proclaiming peace to the Church did not divide themselves against Him from whom  they received peace, that truly, not feignedly, they might proclaim peace.

**[1:18]** 3.

**[1:19]** For there are other mountains which cause shipwreck, on which, if any one drive his ship, she is dashed to pieces.

**[1:20]** For it is easy, when land is seen by men in peril, to make a venture as it were to reach it; but sometimes land is seen on a mountain, and rocks lie hid under the mountain; and when any one makes for the mountain, he falls on the rocks, and finds there not rest, but wrecking.

**[1:21]** So there have been certain mountains, and great have they appeared among men, and they have created heresies and schisms, and have divided the Church of God; but those who divided the Church of God were not those mountains concerning which it is said, "Let the mountains receive peace for thy people".

**[1:22]** For in what manner have they received peace who have severed unity?  4.

**[1:23]** But those who received peace to proclaim it to the people have made Wisdom herself an object of contemplation, so far as human hearts could lay hold on that which "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither has ascended into the heart of man".

**[1:24]** If it has not ascended into the heart of man, how has it ascended into the heart of John? Was not John a man? Or perhaps neither into John's heart did it ascend, but John's heart ascended into it? For that which ascends into the heart of man is from beneath, to man; but that to which the heart of man ascends is above, from man.

**[1:25]** Even so brethren, can it be said that, if it ascended into the heart of John (if in any way it can be said), it ascended into his heart in so far as he was not man.

**[1:26]** What means "was not man"? In so far as he had begun to be an angel.

**[1:27]** For all saints are angels, since they are messengers of God.

**[1:28]** Therefore to carnal and natural men, who are not able to perceive the things that are of God, what says the apostle? "For whereas ye say, I am of Paul, I of Apollos, are ye not men?" What did he wish to make them whom he upbraided because they were men? Do you wish to know what he wished to make them? Hear in the Psalms: "I have said, ye are gods; and all of you are children of the Most High".

**[1:29]** To this, then, God calls us, that we be not men.

**[1:30]** But then will it be for the better that we be not men, if first we recognize the fact that we are men, that is, to the end that we may rise to that height from humility; lest, when we think that we are something when we are nothing, we not only do not receive what we are not, but even lose what we are.

**[1:31]** 5.

**[1:32]** Accordingly, brethren, of these mountains was John also, who said, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

**[1:33]** This mountain had received peace; he was contemplating the divinity of the Word.

**[1:34]** Of what sort was this mountain? How lofty? He had risen above all peaks of the earth, he had risen above all plains of the sky, he had risen above all heights of the stars, he had risen above all choirs and legions of the angels.

**[1:35]** For unless he rose above all those things which were created, he would not arrive at Him by whom all things were made.

**[1:36]** You cannot imagine what he rose above, unless you see at what he arrived.

**[1:37]** Dost thou inquire concerning heaven and earth? They were made.

**[1:38]** Dost thou inquire concerning the things that are in heaven and earth? Surely much more were they made.

**[1:39]** Dost thou inquire concerning spiritual beings, concerning angels, archangels, thrones, dominions, powers, principalities? These also were made.

**[1:40]** For when the Psalm enumerated all these things, it finished thus: "He spoke, and they were made; He commanded, and they were created".

**[1:41]** If "He spoke and they were made," it was by the Word that they were made; but if it was by the Word they were made, the heart of John could not reach to that which he says, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God," unless he had risen above all things that were made by the Word.

**[1:42]** What a mountain this! How holy! How high among those mountains that received peace for the people of God, that the hills might receive righteousness!  6.

**[1:43]** Consider, then, brethren, if perchance John is not one of those mountains concerning whom we sang a little while ago, "I have lifted up mine eyes to the mountains, from whence shall come my help".

**[1:44]** Therefore, my brethren, if you would understand, lift up your eyes to this mountain, that is, raise yourselves up to the evangelist, rise to his meaning.

**[1:45]** But, because though these mountains receive peace he cannot be in peace who places his hope in man, do not so raise your eyes to the mountain as to think that your hope should be placed in man; and so say, "I have lifted up mine eyes to the mountains, from whence shall come my help," that you immediately add, "My help is from the Lord, who made heaven and earth".

**[1:46]** Therefore let us lift our eyes to the mountains,  from whence shall come our help; and yet it is not in the mountains themselves that our hope should be placed, for the mountains receive what they may minister to us; therefore, from whence the mountains also receive there should our hope be placed.

**[1:47]** When we lift our eyes to the Scriptures, since it was through men the Scriptures were ministered, we are lifting our eyes to the mountains, from whence shall come our help; but still, since they were men who wrote the Scriptures, they did not shine of themselves, but "He was the true light, who lighteth every man that cometh into the world".

**[1:48]** A mountain also was that John the Baptist, who said, "I am not the Christ," lest any one, placing his hope in the mountain, should fall from Him who illuminates the mountain.

**[1:49]** He also confessed, saying, "Since of His fullness have all we received".

**[1:50]** So thou oughtest to say, "I have lifted up mine eyes to the mountains, from whence shall come my help," so as not to ascribe to the mountains the help that comes to thee; but continue and say, "My help is from the Lord, who made heaven and earth".

**[1:51]** 7.

**[1:52]** Therefore, brethren, may this be the result of my admonition, that you understand that in raising your hearts to the Scriptures (when the gospel was sounding forth, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God," and the rest that was read), you were lifting your eyes to the mountains.

**[1:53]** For unless the mountains said these things, you would not find out how to think of them at all.

**[1:54]** Therefore from the mountains came your help, that you even heard of these things; but you cannot yet understand what you have heard.

**[1:55]** Call for help from the Lord, who made heaven and earth; for the mountains were enabled only so to speak as not of themselves to illuminate, because they themselves are also illuminated by hearing.

**[1:56]** Thence John, who said these things, received them—he who lay on the Lord's breast, and from the Lord's breast drank in what he might give us to drink.

**[1:57]** But he gave us words to drink.

**[1:58]** Thou oughtest then to receive understanding from the source from which he drank who gave thee to drink; so that thou mayest lift up thine eyes to the mountains from whence shall come thine aid, so that from thence thou mayest receive, as it were, the cup, that is, the word, given thee to drink; and yet, since thy help is from the Lord, who made heaven and earth, thou mayest fill thy breast from the source from which he filled his; whence thou saidst, "My help is from the Lord, who made heaven and earth:" let him, then, fill who can.

**[1:59]** Brethren, this is what I have said: Let each one lift up his heart in the manner that seems fitting, and receive what is spoken.

**[1:60]** But perhaps you will say that I am more present to you than God.

**[1:61]** Far be such a thought from you! He is much more present to you; for I appear to your eyes, He presides over your consciences.

**[1:62]** Give me then your ears, Him your hearts, that you may fill both.

**[1:63]** Behold, your eyes, and those your bodily senses, you lift up to us; and yet not to us, for we are not of those mountains, but to the gospel itself, to the evangelist himself: your hearts, however, to the Lord to be filled.

**[1:64]** Moreover, let each one so lift up as to see what he lifts up, and whither.

**[1:65]** What do I mean by saying, "what he lifts up, and whither?" Let him see to it what sort of a heart he lifts up, because it is to the Lord he lifts it up, lest, encumbered by a load of fleshly pleasure, it fall ere ever it is raised.

**[1:66]** But does each one see that he bears a burden of flesh? Let him strive by continence to purify that which he may lift up to God.

**[1:67]** For "Blessed are the pure in heart, because they shall see God".

**[1:68]** 8.

**[1:69]** But let us see what advantage it is that these words have sounded, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

**[1:70]** We also uttered words when we spoke.

**[1:71]** Was it such a word that was with God? Did not those words which we uttered sound and pass away? Did God's Word, then, sound and come to an end? If so, how were all things made by it, and without it was nothing made? how is that which it created ruled by it, if it sounded and passed away? What sort of a word, then, is that which is both uttered and passes not away? Give ear, my beloved, it is a great matter.

**[1:72]** By everyday talk, words here become despicable to us, because through their sounding and passing away they are despised, and seem nothing but words.

**[1:73]** But there is a word in the man himself which remains within; for the sound proceeds from the mouth.

**[1:74]** There is a word which is spoken in a truly spiritual manner, that which you understand from the sound, not the sound itself.

**[1:75]** Mark, I speak a word when I say "God".

**[1:76]** How short the word which I have spoken—four letters and two syllables! Is this all that God is, four letters and two syllables? Or is that which is signified as costly as the word is paltry? What took place in thy heart when thou heardest "God"? What took place in my heart when I said "God"?  A certain great and perfect substance was in our thoughts, transcending every changeable creature of flesh or of soul.

**[1:77]** And if I say to thee, "Is God changeable or unchangeable?" thou wilt answer immediately, "Far be it from me either to believe or imagine that God is changeable: God is unchangeable".

**[1:78]** Thy soul, though small, though perhaps still carnal, could not answer me otherwise than that God is unchangeable: but every creature is changeable; how then wert thou able to enter, by a glance of thy spirit, into that which is above the creature, so as confidently to answer me, "God is unchangeable"? What, then, is that in thy heart, when thou thinkest of a certain substance, living, eternal, all-powerful, infinite, everywhere present, everywhere whole, nowhere shut in? When thou thinkest of these qualities, this is the word concerning God in thy heart.

**[1:79]** But is this that sound which consists of four letters and two syllables? Therefore, whatever things are spoken and pass away are sounds, are letters, are syllables.

**[1:80]** His word which sounds passes away; but that which the sound signified, and was in the speaker as he thought of it, and in the hearer as he understood it, that remains while the sounds pass away.

**[1:81]** 9.

**[1:82]** Turn thy attention to that word.

**[1:83]** Thou canst have a word in thy heart, as it were a design born in thy mind, so that thy mind brings forth the design; and the design is, so to speak, the offspring of thy mind, the child of thy heart.

**[1:84]** For first thy heart brings forth a design to construct some fabric, to set up something great on the earth; already the design is conceived, and the work is not yet finished: thou seest what thou wilt make; but another does not admire, until thou hast made and constructed the pile, and brought that fabric into shape and to completion; then men regard the admirable fabric, and admire the design of the architect; they are astonished at what they see, and are pleased with what they do not see: who is there who can see a design? If, then, on account of some great building a human design receives praise, do you wish to see what a design of God is the Lord Jesus Christ, that is, the Word of God? Mark this fabric of the world.

**[1:85]** View what was made by the Word, and then thou wilt understand what is the nature of the world.

**[1:86]** Mark these two bodies of the world, the heavens and the earth.

**[1:87]** Who will unfold in words the beauty of the heavens? Who will unfold in words the fruitfulness of the earth? Who will worthily extol the changes of the seasons? Who will worthily extol the power of seeds? You see what things I do not mention, lest in giving a long list I should perhaps tell of less than you can call up to your own minds.

**[1:88]** From this fabric, then, judge the nature of the Word by which it was made: and not it alone; for all these things are seen, because they have to do with the bodily sense.

**[1:89]** By that Word angels also were made; by that Word archangels were made, powers, thrones, dominions, principalities; by that Word were made all things.

**[1:90]** Hence, judge what a Word this is.

**[1:91]** 10.

**[1:92]** Perhaps some one now answers me, "Who so conceives this Word?" Do not then imagine, as it were, some paltry thing when thou hearest "the Word," nor suppose it to be words such as thou hearest them every day—"he spoke such words," "such words he uttered," "such words you tell me;" for by constant repetition the term word has become, so to speak, worthless.

**[1:93]** And when thou hearest, "In the beginning was the Word," lest thou shouldest imagine something worthless, such as thou hast been accustomed to think of when thou wert wont to listen to human words, hearken to what thou must think of: "The Word was God".

**[1:94]** 11.

**[1:95]** Now some unbelieving Arian may come forth and say that "the Word of God was made".

**[1:96]** How can it be that the Word of God was made, when God by the Word made all things? If the Word of God was itself also made, by what other Word was it made? But if thou sayest that there is a Word of the Word, I say, that by which it was made is itself the only Son of God.

**[1:97]** But if thou dost not say there is a Word of the Word, allow that that was not made by which all things were made.

**[1:98]** For that by which all things were made could not be made by itself.

**[1:99]** Believe the evangelist then.

**[1:100]** For he might have said, "In the beginning God made the Word:" even as Moses said, "In the beginning God made the heavens and the earth;" and enumerates all things thus: "God said, Let it be made, and it was made".

**[1:101]** If "said," who said? God.

**[1:102]** And what was made? Some creature.

**[1:103]** Between the speaking of God and the making of the creature, what was there by which it was made but the Word? For God said, "Let it be made, and it was made".

**[1:104]** This Word is unchangeable; although changeable things are made by it, the Word itself is unchangeable.

**[1:105]** 12.

**[1:106]** Do not then believe that that was made by which were made all things, lest thou be not new-made by the Word, which makes all things new.

**[1:107]** For already hast thou been made by the Word, but it behoves thee to be new-made by the Word.

**[1:108]** If, however, thy  belief about the Word be wrong, thou wilt not be able to be new-made by the Word.

**[1:109]** And although creation by the Word has happened to thee, so that thou hast been made by Him, thou art unmade by thyself: if by thyself thou art unmade, let Him who made thee make thee new: if by thyself thou hast been made worse, let Him who created thee re-create thee.

**[1:110]** But how can He re-create thee by the Word, if thou holdest a wrong opinion about the Word? The evangelist says, "In the beginning was the Word;" and thou sayest, "In the beginning the Word was made".

**[1:111]** He says, "All things were made by Him;" and thou sayest that the Word Himself was made.

**[1:112]** The evangelist might have said, "In the beginning the Word was made:" but what does he say? "In the beginning was the Word".

**[1:113]** If He was, He was not made; that all things might be made by it, and without Him nothing be made.

**[1:114]** If, then, "in the beginning the Word was, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God;" if thou canst not imagine what it is, wait till thou art grown.

**[1:115]** That is strong meat: receive thou milk that thou mayest be nourished, and be able to receive strong meat.

**[1:116]** 13.

**[1:117]** Give good heed to what follows, brethren, "All things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made," so as not to imagine that "nothing" is something.

**[1:118]** For many, wrongly understanding "without Him was nothing made," are wont to fancy that "nothing" is something.

**[1:119]** Sin, indeed, was not made by Him; and it is plain that sin is nothing, and men become nothing when they sin.

**[1:120]** An idol also was not made by the Word;—it has indeed a sort of human form, but man himself was made by the Word;—for the form of man in an idol was not made by the Word, and it is written, "We know that an idol is nothing".

**[1:121]** Therefore these things were not made by the Word; but whatever was made in the natural manner, whatever belongs to the creature, everything that is fixed in the sky, that shines from above, that flies under the heavens, and that moves in universal nature, every creature whatsoever: I will speak more plainly, brethren, that you may understand me; I will say, from an angel even to a worm.

**[1:122]** What more excellent than an angel among created things? what lower than a worm? He who made the angel made the worm also; but the angel is fit for heaven, the worm for earth.

**[1:123]** He who created also arranged.

**[1:124]** If He had placed the worm in heaven, thou mightest have found fault; if He had willed that angels should spring from decaying flesh, thou mightest have found fault: and yet God almost does this, and He is not to be found fault with.

**[1:125]** For all men born of flesh, what are they but worms? and of these worms God makes angels.

**[1:126]** For if the Lord Himself says, "But I am a worm and no man," who will hesitate to say what is written also in Job, "How much more is man rottenness, and the son of man a worm?" First he said, "Man is rottenness;" and afterwards, "The son of man a worm:" because a worm springs from rottenness, therefore "man is rottenness," and "the son of man a worm".

**[1:127]** Behold what for thy sake He was willing to become, who "in the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God!" Why did He for thy sake become this? That thou mightest suck, who wert not able to chew.

**[1:128]** Wholly in this sense, then, brethren, understand "All things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made".

**[1:129]** For every creature, great and small, was made by Him: by Him were made things above and things beneath; spiritual and corporeal, by Him were they made.

**[1:130]** For no form, no structure, no agreement of parts, no substance whatever that can have weight, number, measure, exists but by that Word, and by that Creator Word, to whom it is said, "Thou hast ordered all things in measure, and in number, and in weight".

**[1:131]** 14.

**[1:132]** Therefore, let no one deceive you, when perchance you suffer annoyance from flies.

**[1:133]** For some have been mocked by the devil, and taken with flies.

**[1:134]** As fowlers are accustomed to put flies in their traps to deceive hungry birds, so these have been deceived with flies by the devil.

**[1:135]** Some one or other was suffering annoyance from flies; a Manichaean found him in his trouble, and when he said that he could not bear flies, and hated them exceedingly, immediately the Manichaean said, "Who made them?" And since he was suffering from annoyance, and hated them, he dared not say, "God made them," though he was a Catholic.

**[1:136]** The other immediately added, "If God did not make them, who made them?" "Truly," replied the Catholic, "I believe the devil made them".

**[1:137]** And the other immediately said, "If the devil made the fly, as I see you allow, because you understand the matter well, who made the bee, which is a little larger than the fly?" The Catholic dared not say that God made the bee and not the fly, for the case was much the same.

**[1:138]** From the bee he led him to the locust; from the locust to the  lizard; from the lizard to the bird; from the bird to the sheep; from the sheep to the cow; from that to the elephant, and at last to man; and persuaded a man that man was not made by God.

**[1:139]** Thus the miserable man, being troubled with the flies, became himself a fly, and the property of the devil.

**[1:140]** In fact, Beelzebub, they say, means "Prince of flies;" and of these it is written, "Dying flies deprive the ointment of its sweetness".

**[1:141]** 15.

**[1:142]** What then, brethren? why have I said these things? Shut the ears of your hearts against the wiles of the enemy.

**[1:143]** Understand that God made all things, and arranged them in their orders.

**[1:144]** Why, then, do we suffer many evils from a creature that God made? Because we have offended God? Do angels suffer these things? Perhaps we, too, in that life of theirs, would have no such thing to fear.

**[1:145]** For thy punishment, accuse thy sin, not the Judge.

**[1:146]** For, on account of our pride, God appointed that tiny and contemptible creature to torment us; so that, since man has become proud and has boasted himself against God, and, though mortal, has oppressed mortals, and, though man, has not acknowledged his fellowman,—since he has lifted himself up, he may be brought low by gnats.

**[1:147]** Why art thou inflated with human pride? Some one has censured thee, and thou art swollen with rage.

**[1:148]** Drive off the gnats, that thou mayest sleep: understand who thou art.

**[1:149]** For, that you may know, brethren, it was for the taming of our pride these things were created to be troublesome to us, God could have humbled Pharaoh's proud people by bears, by lions, by serpents; He sent flies and frogs upon them, that their pride might be subdued by the meanest creatures.

**[1:150]** 16.

**[1:151]** "All things," then, brethren, "all things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made".

**[1:152]** But how were all things made by Him? "That, which was made, in Him is life".

**[1:153]** It can also be read thus: "That, which was made in Him, is life;" and if we so read it, everything is life.

**[1:154]** For what is there that was not made in Him? For He is the Wisdom of God, and it is said in the Psalm, "In Wisdom hast Thou made all things".

**[1:155]** If, then, Christ is the Wisdom of God, and the Psalm says, "In Wisdom hast Thou made all things:" as all things were made by Him, so all things were made in Him.

**[1:156]** If, then, all things were made in Him, dearly beloved brethren, and that, which was made in Him, is life, both the earth is life and wood is life.

**[1:157]** We do indeed say wood is life, but in the sense of the wood of the cross, whence we have received life.

**[1:158]** A stone, then, is life.

**[1:159]** It is not seemly so to understand the passage, as the same most vile sect of the Manichaeans creep stealthily on us again, and say that a stone has life, that a wall has a soul, and a cord has a soul, and wool, and clothing.

**[1:160]** For so they are accustomed to talk in their raving; and when they have been driven back and refuted, they in some sort bring forward Scripture, saying, "Why is it said, 'That, which was made in Him, is life'?" For if all things were made in Him, all things are life.

**[1:161]** Be not carried away by them; read thus "That which was made;" here make a short pause, and then go on, "in Him is life".

**[1:162]** What is the meaning of this? The earth was made, but the very earth that was made is not life; but there exists spiritually in the Wisdom itself a certain reason by which the earth was made: this is life.

**[1:163]** 17.

**[1:164]** As far as I can, I shall explain my meaning to you, beloved.

**[1:165]** A carpenter makes a box.

**[1:166]** First he has the box in design; for if he had it not in design, how could he produce it by workmanship? But the box in theory is not the very box as it appears to the eyes.

**[1:167]** It exists invisibly in design, it will be visible in the work.

**[1:168]** Behold, it is made in the work; has it ceased to exist in design? The one is made in the work, and the other remains which exists in design; for that box may rot, and another be fashioned according to that which exists in design.

**[1:169]** Give heed, then, to the box as it is in design, and the box as it is in fact.

**[1:170]** The actual box is not life, the box in design is life; because the soul of the artificer, where all these things are before they are brought forth, is living.

**[1:171]** So, dearly beloved brethren, because the Wisdom of God, by which all things have been made, contains everything according to design before it is made, therefore those things which are made through this design itself are not forthwith life, but whatever has been made is life in Him.

**[1:172]** You see the earth, there is an earth in design; you see the sky, there is a sky in design; you see the sun and the moon, these also exist in design: but externally they are bodies, in design they are life.

**[1:173]** Understand, if in any way you are able, for a great matter has been spoken.

**[1:174]** If I am not great by whom it is spoken, or through whom it is spoken, still it is from a great authority.

**[1:175]** For these things are not spoken by me who am small; He is not small to whom I refer in saying these things.

**[1:176]** Let each one take in what he can, and to what extent he can; and he who is not able to take in any of it, let him nourish his heart, that he may become able.

**[1:177]** How is he to nourish it? Let him nourish it with milk, that he may come to strong meat.

**[1:178]** Let him not leave Christ born through the flesh till he arrive at Christ born of the Father alone, the God-Word with God, through whom all things were made; for that is life, which in Him is the light of men.

**[1:179]** 18.

**[1:180]** For this follows: "and the life was the light of men;" and from this very life are men illuminated.

**[1:181]** Cattle are not illuminated, because cattle have not rational minds capable of seeing wisdom.

**[1:182]** But man was made in the image of God, and has a rational mind, by which he can perceive wisdom.

**[1:183]** That life, then, by which all things were made, is itself the light; yet not the light of every animal, but of men.

**[1:184]** Wherefore a little after he says, "That was the true light, which lighteth every man that cometh into the world".

**[1:185]** By that light John the Baptist was illuminated; by the same light also was John the Evangelist himself illuminated.

**[1:186]** He was filled with that light who said, "I am not the Christ; but He cometh after me, whose shoe's latchet I am not worthy to unloose".

**[1:187]** By that light he had been illuminated who said, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

**[1:188]** Therefore that life is the light of men.

**[1:189]** 19.

**[1:190]** But perhaps the slow hearts of some of you cannot yet receive that light, because they are burdened by their sins, so that they cannot see.

**[1:191]** Let them not on that account think that the light is in any way absent, because they are not able to see it; for they themselves are darkness on account of their sins.

**[1:192]** "And the light shineth in darkness, and the darkness comprehended it not".

**[1:193]** Accordingly, brethren, as in the case of a blind man placed in the sun, the sun is present to him, but he is absent from the sun.

**[1:194]** So every foolish man, every unjust man, every irreligious man, is blind in heart.

**[1:195]** Wisdom is present; but it is present to a blind man, and is absent from his eyes; not because it is absent from him, but because he is absent from it.

**[1:196]** What then is he to do? Let him become pure, that he may be able to see God.

**[1:197]** Just as if a man could not see because his eyes were dirty and sore with dust, rheum, or smoke, the physician would say to him: "Cleanse from your eye whatever bad thing is in it, so that you may be able to see the light of your eyes".

**[1:198]** Dust, rheum, and smoke are sins and iniquities: remove then all these things, and you will see the wisdom that is present; for God is that wisdom, and it has been said, "Blessed are the pure in heart; for they shall see God".

**[2:1]** Tractate II.

**[2:2]** Chapter I.

**[2:3]** 6–14  It is fitting, brethren, that as far as possible we should treat of the text of Holy Scripture, and especially of the Holy Gospel, without omitting any portion, that both we ourselves may derive nourishment according to our capacity, and may minister to you from that source from which we have been nourished.

**[2:4]** Last Lord's day, we remember, we treated of the first section; that is, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

**[2:5]** The same was in the beginning with God.

**[2:6]** All things were made by Him; and without Him was nothing made.

**[2:7]** That which was made, in Him is life; and the life was the light of men.

**[2:8]** And the light shineth in darkness; and the darkness comprehended it not".

**[2:9]** So far, I believe, had I advanced in the treatment of the passage: let all who were present recall what was then said; and those of you who were not present, believe me and those who chose to be present.

**[2:10]** Now therefore,—because we cannot always be repeating everything, out of justice to those who desire to hear what follows, and because repetition of the former thought is a burden to them and deprives them of what succeeds,—let those who were absent on the former occasion refrain from demanding repetition, but, together with those who were here, listen to the present exposition.

**[2:11]** 2.

**[2:12]** It goes on, "There was a man sent from God whose name was John".

**[2:13]** Truly, brethren beloved, those things which were said before, were said regarding the ineffable divinity of Christ, and almost ineffably.

**[2:14]** For who shall comprehend "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God"?  And do not allow the name word to appear mean to you, through the habit of daily words, for it is added, "and the Word was God".

**[2:15]** This Word is He of whom yesterday we spoke much; and I trust that God was present, and that even from only thus much speaking something reached your hearts.

**[2:16]** "In the beginning was the Word".

**[2:17]** He is the same, and is in the same manner; as He is, so He is always; He cannot be changed; that is, He is.

**[2:18]** This His name He spoke to His servant Moses: "I am that I am; and He that is hath sent me".

**[2:19]** Who then shall comprehend this when you see that all mortal things are variable; when you see that not only do bodies vary as to their qualities, by being born, by increasing, by becoming less, by dying, but that even souls themselves through the effect of divers volitions are distended and divided; when you see that men can obtain wisdom if they apply themselves to its light and heat, and also lose wisdom if they remove themselves from it through some evil influence? When, therefore, you see that all those things are variable, what is that which is, unless that which transcends all things which are so that they are not? Who then can receive this? Or who, in what manner soever he may have applied the strength of his mind to touch that which is, can reach to that which he may in any way have touched with his mind? It is as if one were to see his native land at a distance, and the sea intervening; he sees whither he would go, but he has not the means of going.

**[2:20]** So we desire to arrive at that our stability where that which is, is, because this alone always is as it is: the sea of this world interrupts our course, even although already we see whither we go; for many do not even see whither they go.

**[2:21]** That there might be a way by which we could go, He has come from Him to whom we wished to go.

**[2:22]** And what has He done? He has appointed a tree by which we may cross the sea.

**[2:23]** For no one is able to cross the sea of this world, unless borne by the cross of Christ.

**[2:24]** Even he who is of weak eyesight sometimes embraces this cross; and he who does not see from afar whither he goes, let him not depart from it, and it will carry him over.

**[2:25]** 3.

**[2:26]** Therefore, my brethren, I would desire to have impressed this upon your hearts: if you wish to live in a pious and Christian manner, cling to Christ according to that which He became for us, that you may arrive at Him according to that which is, and according to that which was.

**[2:27]** He approached, that for us He might become this; because He became that for us, on which the weak may be borne, and cross the sea of this world and reach their native country; where there will be no need of a ship, for no sea is crossed.

**[2:28]** It is better then not to see with the mind that which is, and yet not to depart from the cross of Christ, than to see it with the mind, and despise the cross of Christ.

**[2:29]** It is good beyond this, and best of all, if it be possible, that we both see whither we ought to go, and hold fast that which carries us as we go.

**[2:30]** This they were able to do, the great minds of the mountains, who have been called mountains, whom the light of divine justice pre-eminently illuminates; they were able to do this, and saw that which is.

**[2:31]** For John seeing said, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

**[2:32]** They saw this, and in order that they might arrive at that which they saw from afar, they did not depart from the cross of Christ, and did not despise Christ's lowliness.

**[2:33]** But little ones who cannot understand this, who do not depart from the cross and passion and resurrection of Christ, are conducted in that same ship to that which they do not see, in which they also arrive who do see.

**[2:34]** 4.

**[2:35]** But truly there have been some philosophers of this world who have sought for the Creator by means of the creature; for He can be found by means of the creature, as the apostle plainly says, "For the invisible things of Him from the creation of the world are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even His eternal power and glory; so they are without excuse".

**[2:36]** And it follows, "Because that, when they knew God;" he did not say, Because they did not know, but "Because that, when they knew God, they glorified Him not as God, neither were thankful; but became vain in their imaginations, and their foolish heart was darkened".

**[2:37]** How darkened? It follows, when he says more plainly: "Professing themselves to be wise, they became fools".

**[2:38]** They saw whither they must come; but ungrateful to Him who afforded them what they saw, they wished to ascribe to themselves what they saw; and having become proud, they lost what they saw, and were turned from it to idols and images, and to the worship of demons, to adore the creature and to despise the Creator.

**[2:39]** But these having been blinded did those things, and became proud, that they might be blinded: when they were proud they said that they were wise.

**[2:40]** Those, therefore, concerning whom he said, "Who,  when they had known God," saw this which John says, that by the Word of God all things were made.

**[2:41]** For these things are also found in the books of the philosophers: and that God has an only-begotten Son, by whom are all things.

**[2:42]** They were able to see that which is, but they saw it from afar: they were unwilling to hold the lowliness of Christ, in which ship they might have arrived in safety at that which they were able to see from afar and the cross of Christ appeared vile to them.

**[2:43]** The sea has to be crossed, and dost thou despise the wood? Oh, proud wisdom! thou laughest to scorn the crucified Christ; it is He whom thou dost see from afar: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God".

**[2:44]** But wherefore was He crucified? Because the wood of His humiliation was needful to thee.

**[2:45]** For thou hadst become swollen with pride, and hadst been cast out far from that fatherland; and by the waves of this world has the way been intercepted, and there is no means of passing to the fatherland unless borne by the wood.

**[2:46]** Ungrateful one! thou laughest Him to scorn who has come to thee that thou mayest return: He has become the way, and that through the sea: thence He walked in the sea to show that there is a way in the sea.

**[2:47]** But thou who art not able in any way thyself to walk in the sea, be carried in a ship, be carried by the wood: believe in the crucified One, and thou shalt arrive thither.

**[2:48]** On account of thee He was crucified, to teach thee humility; and because if He should come as God, He would not be recognized.

**[2:49]** For if He should come as God, He would not come to those who were not able to see God.

**[2:50]** For not according to His Godhead does He either come or depart; since He is everywhere present, and is contained in no place.

**[2:51]** But, according to what did He come? He appeared as a man.

**[2:52]** 5.

**[2:53]** Therefore, because He was so man, that the God lay hid in Him, there was sent before Him a great man, by whose testimony He might be found to be more than man.

**[2:54]** And who is this? "He was a man".

**[2:55]** And how could that man speak the truth concerning God? "He was sent by God".

**[2:56]** What was he called? "Whose name was John".

**[2:57]** Wherefore did he come? "He came for a witness, that he might bear witness concerning the light, that all might believe through him".

**[2:58]** What sort of man was he who was to bear witness concerning the light? Something great was that John, vast merit, great grace, great loftiness! Admire, by all means, admire; but as it were a mountain.

**[2:59]** But a mountain is in darkness unless it be clothed with light.

**[2:60]** Therefore only admire John that you may hear what follows, "He was not that light;" lest if, when thou thinkest the mountain to be the light, thou make shipwreck on the mountain, and find not consolation.

**[2:61]** But what oughtest thou to admire? The mountain as a mountain.

**[2:62]** But lift thyself up to Him who illuminates the mountain, which for this end was elevated that it might be the first to receive the rays, and make them known to your eyes.

**[2:63]** Therefore, "he was not that light".

**[2:64]** 6.

**[2:65]** Wherefore then did he come? "But that he might bear witness concerning the light".

**[2:66]** Why so? "That all might believe through him".

**[2:67]** And concerning what light was he to bear witness? "That was the true light".

**[2:68]** Wherefore is it added true? Because an enlightened man is also called a light; but the true light is that which enlightens.

**[2:69]** For even our eyes are called lights; and nevertheless, unless either during the night a lamp is lighted, or during the day the sun goes forth, these lights are open in vain.

**[2:70]** Thus, therefore, John was a light, but not the true light; because, if not enlightened, he would have been darkness; but, by enlightenment, he became a light.

**[2:71]** For unless he had been enlightened he would have been darkness, as all those once impious men, to whom, as believers, the apostle said, "Ye were sometimes darkness".

**[2:72]** But now, because they had believed, what?—"but now are ye light," he says, "in the Lord".

**[2:73]** Unless he had added "in the Lord," we should not have understood.

**[2:74]** "Light," he says, "in the Lord:" darkness you were not in the Lord.

**[2:75]** "For ye were sometimes darkness," where he did not add in the Lord.

**[2:76]** Therefore, darkness in you, light in the Lord.

**[2:77]** And thus "he was not that light, but was sent to bear witness of the light".

**[2:78]** 7.

**[2:79]** But where is that light? "He was the true light, which lighteth every man that cometh into the world".

**[2:80]** If every man that cometh, then also John.

**[2:81]** The true light, therefore, enlightened him by whom He desired Himself to be pointed out.

**[2:82]** Understand, beloved, for He came to infirm minds, to wounded hearts, to the gaze of dim-eyed souls.

**[2:83]** For this purpose had He come.

**[2:84]** And whence was the soul able to see that which perfectly is? Even as it commonly happens, that by means of some illuminated body, the sun, which we cannot see with the eyes, is known to have arisen.

**[2:85]** Because even those  who have wounded eyes are able to see a wall illuminated and enlightened by the sun, or a mountain, or a tree, or anything of that sort; and, by means of another body illuminated, that arising is shown to those who are not as yet able to gaze on it.

**[2:86]** Thus, therefore all those to whom Christ came were not fit to see Him: upon John He shed the beams of His light; and by means of him confessing himself to have been irradiated and enlightened, not claiming to be one who irradiates and enlightens, He is known who enlightens, He is known who illuminates, He is known who fills.

**[2:87]** And who is it? "He who lighteth every man," he says, "who cometh into the world".

**[2:88]** For if man had not receded from that light, he would not have required to be illuminated; but for this reason has he to be illuminated here, because he departed from that light by which man might always have been illuminated.

**[2:89]** 8.

**[2:90]** What then? If He came hither, where was He? "He was in this world".

**[2:91]** He was both here and came hither; He was here according to His divinity, and He came hither according to the flesh; because when He was here according to His divinity, He could not be seen by the foolish, by the blind, and the wicked.

**[2:92]** These wicked men are the darkness concerning which it was said, "The light shineth in darkness, and the darkness comprehended it not".

**[2:93]** Behold, both here He is now, and here He was, and here He is always; and He never departs, departs no-whither.

**[2:94]** There is need that thou have some means whereby thou mayest see that which never departs from thee; there is need that thou depart not from Him who departs no-whither; there is need that thou desert not, and thou shalt not be deserted.

**[2:95]** Do not fall, and His sun will not set to thee.

**[2:96]** If thou fallest, His sun setteth upon thee; but if thou standest, He is present with thee.

**[2:97]** But thou hast not stood: remember how thou hast fallen, how he who fell before thee cast thee down.

**[2:98]** For he cast thee down, not by violence, not by assault, but by thine own will.

**[2:99]** For hadst thou not consented unto evil, thou wouldest have stood, thou wouldest have remained enlightened.

**[2:100]** But now, because thou hast already fallen, and hast become wounded in heart,—the organ by which that light can be seen,—He came to thee such as thou mightest see; and He in such fashion manifested Himself as man, that He sought testimony from man.

**[2:101]** From man God seeks testimony, and God has man as a witness;—God has man as a witness, but on account of man: so infirm are we.

**[2:102]** By a lamp we seek the day; because John himself was called a lamp, the Lord saying, "He was a burning and a shining light; and ye were willing for a season to rejoice in his light: but I have greater witness than John".

**[2:103]** 9.

**[2:104]** Therefore He showed that for the sake of men He desired to have Himself revealed by a lamp to the faith of those who believed, that by means of the same lamp His enemies might be confounded.

**[2:105]** There were enemies who tempted Him, and said, "Tell us by what authority doest thou these things?" "I also," saith He, "will ask you one question; answer me.

**[2:106]** The baptism of John, whence was it? from heaven, or of men? And they were troubled, and said among themselves, If we shall say, From heaven, he will say unto us, Why did ye not believe him?" (Because he had borne testimony to Christ, and had said, I am not the Christ, but He.

**[2:107]** "But if we shall say, Of men, we fear the people, lest they should stone us: for they held John as a prophet".

**[2:108]** Afraid of stoning, but fearing more to confess the truth, they answered a lie to the Truth; and "wickedness imposed a lie upon itself".

**[2:109]** For they said, "We know not".

**[2:110]** And the Lord, because they shut the door against themselves, by professing ignorance of what they knew, did not open to them, because they did not knock.

**[2:111]** For it is said, "Knock, and it shall be opened unto you".

**[2:112]** Not only did these not knock that it might be opened to them; but, by denying that they knew, they barred that door against themselves.

**[2:113]** And the Lord says to them, Neither tell I you by what authority I do these things".

**[2:114]** And they were confounded by means of John; and in them were the words fulfilled, "I have ordained a lamp for mine anointed.

**[2:115]** His enemies will I clothe with shame".

**[2:116]** 10.

**[2:117]** "He was in the world, and the world was made by Him".

**[2:118]** Think not that He was in the world as the earth is in the world, as the sky is in the world, as the sun is in the world, the moon and the stars, trees, cattle, and men.

**[2:119]** He was not thus in the world.

**[2:120]** But in what manner then? As the Artificer governing what He had made.

**[2:121]** For He did not make it as a carpenter makes a chest.

**[2:122]** The chest which he makes is outside the carpenter, and so it is put in another place, while being made; and although the workman is nigh, he sits in another place, and is external to that which he fashions.

**[2:123]** But God, infused into  the world, fashions it; being everywhere present He fashions, and withdraweth not Himself elsewhere, nor doth He, as it were, handle from without, the matter which He fashions.

**[2:124]** By the presence of His majesty He maketh what He maketh; His presence governs what He made.

**[2:125]** Therefore was He in the world as the Maker of the world; for, "The world was made by Him, and the world knew Him not".

**[2:126]** 11.

**[2:127]** What meaneth "the world was made by Him"? The heaven, the earth, the sea, and all things which are therein, are called the world.

**[2:128]** Again, in another signification, those who love the world are called the world.

**[2:129]** "The world was made by Him, and the world knew Him not".

**[2:130]** Did not the heavens know their Creator, or did the angels not know their Creator, or did the stars not know their Creator, whom the demons confess? All things from all sides gave testimony.

**[2:131]** But who did not know? Those who, for their love of the world, are called the world.

**[2:132]** By loving we dwell with the heart; but because of their loving the world they deserved to be called after the name of that in which they dwelt.

**[2:133]** In the same manner as we say, This house is bad, or this house is good, we do not in calling the one bad or the other good accuse or praise the walls; but by a bad house we mean a house with bad inhabitants, and by a good house, a house with good inhabitants.

**[2:134]** In like manner we call those the world who by loving it, inhabit the world.

**[2:135]** Who are they? Those who love the world; for they dwell with their hearts in the world.

**[2:136]** For those who do not love the world in the flesh, indeed, sojourn in the world, but in their hearts they dwell in heaven, as the apostle says, "Our conversation is in heaven".

**[2:137]** Therefore "the world was made by Him, and the world knew Him not".

**[2:138]** 12.

**[2:139]** "He came unto His own,"—because all these things were made by Him,—"and His own received Him not".

**[2:140]** Who are they? The men whom He made.

**[2:141]** The Jews whom He at the first made to be above all nations.

**[2:142]** Because other nations worshipped idols and served demons; but that people was born of the seed of Abraham, and in an eminent sense His own, because kindred through that flesh which He deigned to assume.

**[2:143]** "He came unto His own, and His own received Him not".

**[2:144]** Did they not receive Him at all? did no one receive Him? Was there no one saved? For no one shall be saved unless he who shall have received the coming Christ.

**[2:145]** 13.

**[2:146]** But John adds: "As many as received Him".

**[2:147]** What did He afford to them? Great benevolence! Great mercy! He was born the only Son of God, and was unwilling to remain alone.

**[2:148]** Many men, when they have not sons, in advanced age adopt a son, and thus obtain by an exercise of will what nature has denied to them: this men do.

**[2:149]** But if any one have an only son, he rejoices the more in him; because he alone will possess everything, and he will not have any one to divide with him the inheritance, so that he should be poorer.

**[2:150]** Not so God: that same only Son whom He had begotten, and by whom He created all things, He sent into this world that He might not be alone, but might have adopted brethren.

**[2:151]** For we were not born of God in the manner in which the Only-begotten was born of Him, but were adopted by His grace.

**[2:152]** For He, the Only-begotten, came to loose the sins in which we were entangled, and whose burden hindered our adoption: those whom He wished to make brethren to Himself, He Himself loosed, and made joint-heirs.

**[2:153]** For so saith the apostle, "But if a son, then an heir through God".

**[2:154]** And again, "Heirs of God, and joint-heirs with Christ".

**[2:155]** He did not fear to have joint-heirs, because His heritage does not become narrow if many are possessors.

**[2:156]** Those very persons, He being possessor, become His inheritance, and He in turn becomes their inheritance.

**[2:157]** Hear in what manner they become His inheritance: "The Lord hath said unto me, Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten Thee.

**[2:158]** Ask of me, and I will give Thee the nations for Thine inheritance".

**[2:159]** Hear in what manner He becomes their inheritance.

**[2:160]** He says in the Psalms: "The Lord is the portion of mine inheritance, and of my cup".

**[2:161]** Let us possess Him, and let Him possess us: let Him possess us as Lord; let us possess Him as salvation, let us possess Him as light.

**[2:162]** What then did He give to them who received Him? "To them He gave power to become sons of God, even to them that believe on His name;" that they may cling to the wood and cross the sea.

**[2:163]** 14.

**[2:164]** And how are they born? Because they become sons of God and brethren of Christ, they are certainly born.

**[2:165]** For if they are not born, how can they be sons? But the sons of men are born of flesh and blood, and of the will of man, and of the embrace of wedlock.

**[2:166]** But in what manner are they born? "Who not of bloods," as if of male and female.

**[2:167]** Bloods is not Latin; but because it is plural in Greek, the interpreter preferred so to express it, and to speak bad Latin according to  the grammarian that he might make the matter plain to the understanding of the weak among his hearers.

**[2:168]** For if he had said blood in the singular number, he would not have explained what he desired; for men are born of the bloods of male and female.

**[2:169]** Let us say so, then, and not fear the ferule of grammarians, so long as we reach the solid and certain truth.

**[2:170]** He who understands it and blames it, is thankless for his having understood.

**[2:171]** "Not of bloods, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man".

**[2:172]** The apostle puts flesh for woman; because, when she was made of his rib, Adam said, "This is now bone of my bone, and flesh of my flesh".

**[2:173]** And the apostle saith, "He that loveth his wife loveth himself; for no one ever hated his own flesh".

**[2:174]** Flesh, then, is put for woman, in the same manner that spirit is sometimes put for husband.

**[2:175]** Wherefore? Because the one rules, the other is ruled; the one ought to command, the other to serve.

**[2:176]** For where the flesh commands and the spirit serves, the house is turned the wrong way.

**[2:177]** What can be worse than a house where the woman has the mastery over the man? But that house is rightly ordered where the man commands and the woman obeys.

**[2:178]** In like manner that man is rightly ordered where the spirit commands and the flesh serves.

**[2:179]** 15.

**[2:180]** These, then, "were born not of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God".

**[2:181]** But that men might be born of God, God was first born of them.

**[2:182]** For Christ is God, and Christ was born of men.

**[2:183]** It was only a mother, indeed, that He sought upon earth; because He had already a Father in heaven: He by whom we were to be created was born of God, and He by whom we were to be re-created was born of a woman.

**[2:184]** Marvel not, then, O man, that thou art made a son by grace, that thou art born of God according to His Word.

**[2:185]** The Word Himself first chose to be born of man, that thou mightest be born of God unto salvation, and say to thyself, Not without reason did God wish to be born of man, but because He counted me of some importance, that He might make me immortal, and for me be born as a mortal man.

**[2:186]** When, therefore, he had said, "born of God," lest we should, as it were, be filled with amazement and trembling at such grace, at grace so great as to exceed belief that men are born of God, as if assuring thee, he says, "And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us".

**[2:187]** Why, then, dost thou marvel that men are born of God? Consider God Himself born of men: "And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us".

**[2:188]** 16.

**[2:189]** But because "the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us," by His very nativity he made an eye-salve to cleanse the eyes of our heart, and to enable us to see His majesty by means of His humility.

**[2:190]** Therefore "the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us:" He healed our eyes; and what follows? "And we beheld His glory".

**[2:191]** His glory can no one see unless healed by the humility of His flesh.

**[2:192]** Wherefore were we not able to see? Consider, then, dearly beloved, and see what I say.

**[2:193]** There had dashed into man's eye, as it were, dust, earth; it had wounded the eye, and it could not see the light: that wounded eye is anointed; by earth it was wounded, and earth is applied to it for healing.

**[2:194]** For all eye-salves and medicines are derived from the earth alone.

**[2:195]** By dust thou wert blinded, and by dust thou art healed: flesh, then, had wounded thee, flesh heals thee.

**[2:196]** The soul had become carnal by consenting to the affections of the flesh; thus had the eye of the heart been blinded.

**[2:197]** "The Word was made flesh:" that Physician made for thee an eye-salve.

**[2:198]** And as He thus came by flesh to extinguish the vices of the flesh, and by death to slay death; therefore did this take place in thee, that, as "the Word became flesh," thou mayest be able to say, "And we beheld His glory".

**[2:199]** What sort of glory? Such as He became as Son of man? That was His humility, not His glory.

**[2:200]** But to what is the sight of man brought when cured by means of flesh? "We beheld His glory, the glory as of the Only-begotten from the Father, full of grace and truth".

**[2:201]** Of grace and truth we shall speak more fully in another place in this same Gospel, if the Lord vouchsafe us opportunity.

**[2:202]** Let these things suffice for the present, and be ye edified in Christ: be ye comforted in faith, and watch in good works, and see that ye do not depart from the wood by which ye may cross the sea.

**[3:1]** Tractate III.

**[3:2]** Chapter I.

**[3:3]** 15–18  We undertook, in the name of the Lord, and promised to you, beloved, to treat of that grace and truth of God, full of which the only-begotten Son, our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, appeared to the saints, and to show how, as a matter belonging to the New Testament, it is to be distinguished from the Old Testament.

**[3:4]** Give, then, your attention that what I receive in my measure from God you in your measure may receive and hear the same.

**[3:5]** For it will only remain if, when the seed is scattered in your hearts, the birds take it not away, nor thorns choke it, nor heat scorch it, and there descend upon it the rain of daily exhortations and your own good thoughts, by which that is done in the heart which in the field is done by means of harrows, so that the clod is broken, and the seed covered and enabled to germinate: that you bear fruit at which the husbandman may be glad and rejoice.

**[3:6]** But if, in return for good seed and good rain, you bring forth not fruit but thorns, the seed will not be blamed, nor will the rain be in fault; but for thorns due fire is prepared.

**[3:7]** 2.

**[3:8]** I do not think that I need spend much time in endeavoring to persuade you that we are Christian men; and if Christians, by virtue of the name, belonging to Christ.

**[3:9]** Upon the forehead we bear His sign; and we do not blush because of it, if we also bear it in the heart.

**[3:10]** His sign is His humility.

**[3:11]** By a star the Magi knew Him; and this sign was given by the Lord, and it was heavenly and beautiful.

**[3:12]** He did not desire that a star should be His sign on the forehead of the faithful, but His cross.

**[3:13]** By it humbled, by it also glorified; by it He raised the humble, even by that to which He, when humbled, descended.

**[3:14]** We belong, then, to the gospel, we belong to the New Testament.

**[3:15]** "The law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ".

**[3:16]** We ask the apostle, and he says to us, since we are not under the law but under grace.

**[3:17]** "He sent therefore His Son, made of a woman, made under the law, that He might redeem those who were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons".

**[3:18]** Behold, for this end Christ came, that He might redeem those who were under the law; that now we may not be under the law, but under grace.

**[3:19]** Who, then, gave the law? He gave the law who gave likewise grace; but the law He sent by a servant, with grace He Himself came down.

**[3:20]** And in what manner were men made under the law? By not fulfilling the law.

**[3:21]** For he who fulfills the law is not under the law, but with the law; but he who is under the law is not raised up, but pressed down by the law.

**[3:22]** All men, therefore, being placed under the law, are by the law made guilty; and for this purpose it is over their head, that it may show sins, not take them away.

**[3:23]** The law then commands, the Giver of the law showeth pity in that which the law commands.

**[3:24]** Men, endeavoring by their own strength to fulfill that which the law commands, fell by their own rash and headstrong presumption; and not with the law, but under the law, became guilty: and since by their own strength they were unable to fulfill the law, and were become guilty under the law, they implored the aid of the Deliverer; and the guilt which the law brought caused sickness to the proud.

**[3:25]** The sickness of the proud became the confession of the humble.

**[3:26]** Now the sick confess that they are sick; let the physician come to heal the sick.

**[3:27]** 3.

**[3:28]** Who is the Physician? Our Lord Jesus Christ.

**[3:29]** Who is our Lord Jesus Christ? He who was seen even by those by whom He was crucified.

**[3:30]** He who was seized, buffeted, scourged, spit upon, crowned with thorns, suspended upon the cross, died, pierced by the spear, taken down from the cross, laid in the sepulchre.

**[3:31]** That same Jesus Christ our Lord, that same Jesus exactly, He is the complete Physician of our wounds.

**[3:32]** That crucified One at whom insults were cast, and while He hung on the cross His persecutors wagging the head, and saying, "If he be the Son of God, let him come down from the cross,"—He, and no other, is our complete Physician.

**[3:33]** Wherefore, then, did He not show to his deriders that He was the Son of God; so that if He allowed Himself to be lifted up upon the cross, at least when they said, "If he be the Son of God, let him come down from the cross," He should then come down, and show to them that He was the very Son of God whom they had dared to deride? He would not.

**[3:34]** Wherefore would He not? Was it because He could not? Manifestly  He could.

**[3:35]** For which is greater, to descend from the cross or to rise from the sepulchre? But He bore with His insulters; for the cross was taken not as a proof of power, but as an example of patience.

**[3:36]** There He cured thy wounds, where He long bore His own; there He healed thee of death eternal, where He vouchsafed to die the temporal death.

**[3:37]** And did He die, or in Him did death die? What a death was that, which slew death!  4.

**[3:38]** Is it, however, our Lord Jesus Christ Himself—His whole self—who was seen, and held, and crucified? Is the whole very self that? It is the same, but not the whole, that which the Jews saw; this is not the whole Christ.

**[3:39]** And what is? "In the beginning was the Word".

**[3:40]** In what beginning? "And the Word was with God".

**[3:41]** And what word? "And the Word was God".

**[3:42]** Was then perhaps this Word made by God? No.

**[3:43]** For "the same was in the beginning with God".

**[3:44]** What then? Are the other things which God made not like unto the Word? No: because "all things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made".

**[3:45]** In what manner were all things made by Him? Because "that which was made in Him was life;" and before it was made there was life.

**[3:46]** That which was made is not life; but in the art, that is, in the wisdom of God, before it was made, it was life.

**[3:47]** That which was made passes away; that which is in wisdom cannot pass away.

**[3:48]** There was life, therefore, in that which was made.

**[3:49]** And what sort of life, since the soul also is the life of the body? Our body has its own life; and when it has lost it, the death of the body ensues.

**[3:50]** Was then the life such as this? No; but "the life was the light of men".

**[3:51]** Was it the light of cattle? For this light is the light of men and of cattle.

**[3:52]** There is a certain light of men: let us see how far men differ from the cattle, and then we shall understand what is the light of men.

**[3:53]** Thou dost not differ from the cattle except in intellect; do not glory in anything besides.

**[3:54]** Dost thou presume upon thy strength? By the wild beasts thou art surpassed.

**[3:55]** Upon thy swiftness dost thou presume? By the flies thou art surpassed.

**[3:56]** Upon thy beauty dost thou presume? How great beauty is there in the feathers of a peacock! Wherein then art thou better? In the image of God.

**[3:57]** Where is the image of God? In the mind, in the intellect.

**[3:58]** If then thou art in this respect better than the cattle, that thou hast a mind by which thou mayest understand what the cattle cannot understand; and therein a man, because better than the cattle; the light of men is the light of minds.

**[3:59]** The light of minds is above minds and surpasses all minds.

**[3:60]** This was that life by which all things were made.

**[3:61]** 5.

**[3:62]** Where was it? Was it here? was it with the Father, and was it not here? or, what is more true, was it both with the Father and here also? If then it was here, wherefore was it not seen? Because "the light shineth in darkness, and the darkness comprehended it not".

**[3:63]** Oh men, be not darkness, be not unbelieving, unjust, unrighteous, rapacious, avaricious lovers of this world: for these are the darkness.

**[3:64]** The light is not absent, but you are absent from the light.

**[3:65]** A blind man in the sunshine has the sun present to him, but is himself absent from the sun.

**[3:66]** Be ye not then darkness.

**[3:67]** For this is perhaps the grace regarding which we are about to speak, that now we be no more darkness, and that the apostle may say to us, "We were sometime darkness, but now light in the Lord".

**[3:68]** Because then the light of men was not seen, that is, the light of minds, there was a necessity that a man should give testimony regarding the light, who was not in darkness, but who was already enlightened; and nevertheless, because enlightened, not the light itself, "but that He might bear witness of the light".

**[3:69]** For "he was not that light".

**[3:70]** And what was the light? "That was the true light which enlightened every man that cometh into the world".

**[3:71]** And where was that light? "In this world it was".

**[3:72]** And how was it "in this world?" As the light of the sun, of the moon, and of lamps, was that light thus in the world? No.

**[3:73]** Because "the world was made by Him, and the world knew Him not;" that is to say, "the light shineth in darkness, and the darkness comprehended it not".

**[3:74]** For the world is darkness; because the lovers of the world are the world.

**[3:75]** For did not the creature acknowledge its Creator? The heavens gave testimony by a star; the sea gave testimony, and bore its Lord when He walked upon it; the winds gave testimony, and were quiet at His bidding; the earth gave testimony, and trembled when He was crucified.

**[3:76]** If all these gave testimony, in what sense did the world not know Him, unless that the world signifies the lovers of the world, those who with their hearts dwell in the world? And the world is evil, because the inhabitants of the world are evil; just as a house is evil, not because of its walls, but because of its inhabitants.

**[3:77]** 6.

**[3:78]** "He came unto His own;" that is to say, He came to that which belonged to Himself; "and His own received Him not".

**[3:79]** What, then, is the hope, unless that "as many  as received Him, to them gave He power to become the sons of God"? If they become sons, they are born; if born, how are they born? Not of flesh, "nor of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man; but of God are they born".

**[3:80]** Let them rejoice, therefore, that they are born of God; let them believe that they are born of God; let them receive the proof that they are born of God: "And the Word became flesh, and dwelt among us".

**[3:81]** If the Word was not ashamed to be born of man, are men ashamed to be born of God? And because He did this, He cured us; and because He cured us, we see.

**[3:82]** For this, "that the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us," became a medicine unto us, so that as by earth we were made blind, by earth we might be healed; and having been healed, might behold what? "And we beheld," he says, "His glory, the glory as of the Only-begotten of the Father, full of grace and truth".

**[3:83]** 7.

**[3:84]** "John beareth witness of Him, and crieth, saying, This was He of whom I spake, He that cometh after me is made before me".

**[3:85]** He came after me, and He preceded me.

**[3:86]** What is it, "He is made before me"? He preceded me.

**[3:87]** Not was made before I was made, but was preferred before me, this is "He was made before me".

**[3:88]** Wherefore was He made before thee, when He came after thee? "Because He was before me".

**[3:89]** Before thee, O John! what great thing to be before thee! It is well that thou dost bear witness to Him; let us, however, hear Himself saying, "Even before Abraham, I am".

**[3:90]** But Abraham also was born in the midst of the human race: there were many before him, many after him.

**[3:91]** Listen to the voice of the Father to the Son: "Before Lucifer I have begotten Thee".

**[3:92]** He who was begotten before Lucifer Himself illuminates all.

**[3:93]** A certain one was named Lucifer, who fell; for he was an angel and became a devil; and concerning him the Scripture said, "Lucifer, who did arise in the morning, fell".

**[3:94]** And why was he Lucifer? Because, being enlightened, he gave forth light.

**[3:95]** But for what reason did he become dark! Because he abode not in the truth.

**[3:96]** Therefore He was before Lucifer, before every one that is enlightened; since before every one that is enlightened, of necessity He must be by whom all are enlightened who can be enlightened.

**[3:97]** 8.

**[3:98]** Therefore this follows: "And of His fullness have all we received".

**[3:99]** What have ye received? "And grace for grace".

**[3:100]** For so run the words of the Gospel, as we find by a comparison of the Greek copies.

**[3:101]** He does not say, And of His fullness have all we received grace for grace; but thus He says: "And of His fullness have all we received, and grace for grace,"—that is, have we received; so that He would wish us to understand that we have received from His fullness something unexpressed, and something besides, grace for grace.

**[3:102]** For we received of His fullness grace in the first instance; and again we received grace, grace for grace.

**[3:103]** What grace did we, in the first instance, receive? Faith: walking in faith, we walk in grace.

**[3:104]** How have we merited this? by what previous merits of ours? Let not each one flatter himself, but let him return into his own conscience, seek out the secret places of his own thoughts, recall the series of his deeds; let him not consider what he is if now he is something, but what he was that he might be something: he will find that he was not worthy of anything save punishment.

**[3:105]** If, then, thou wast worthy of punishment, and He came not to punish sins, but to forgive sins, grace was given to thee, and not reward rendered.

**[3:106]** Wherefore is it called grace? Because it is bestowed gratuitously.

**[3:107]** For thou didst not, by previous merits, purchase that which thou didst receive.

**[3:108]** This first grace, then, the sinner received, that his sins were forgiven.

**[3:109]** What did he deserve? Let him interrogate justice, he finds punishment; let him interrogate mercy, he finds grace.

**[3:110]** But God promised this also through the prophets; therefore, when He came to give what He had promised, He not only gave grace, but also truth.

**[3:111]** How was truth exhibited? Because that was done which had been promised.

**[3:112]** 9.

**[3:113]** What, then, is "grace for grace"? By faith we render God favorable to us; and inasmuch as we were not worthy to have our sins forgiven, and because we, who were unworthy, received so great a benefit, it is called grace.

**[3:114]** What is grace? That which is freely given.

**[3:115]** What is "freely given"? Given, not paid.

**[3:116]** If it was due, wages were given, not grace bestowed; but if it was reply due, thou wast good; but if, as is true, thou wast evil, but didst believe on Him who justifieth the ungodly (What is, Who justifieth the ungodly? Of the ungodly maketh pious), consider what did by right hang over thee by the law, and what thou hast obtained by grace.

**[3:117]** But having obtained that grace of faith, thou shalt be just by faith (for the just lives by faith); and thou shalt obtain favor of God by living by faith.

**[3:118]** And having obtained favor from God by living by faith,  thou shalt receive immortality as a reward, and life eternal.

**[3:119]** And that is grace.

**[3:120]** For because of what merit dost thou receive life eternal? Because of grace.

**[3:121]** For if faith is grace, life eternal is, as it were, the wages of faith: God, indeed, appears to bestow eternal life as if it were due (To whom due? To the faithful, because he had merited it by faith); but because faith itself is grace, life eternal also is grace for grace.

**[3:122]** 10.

**[3:123]** Listen to the Apostle Paul acknowledging grace, and afterwards desiring the payment of a debt.

**[3:124]** What acknowledgment of grace is there in Paul? "Who was before a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious; but I obtained," saith he, "mercy".

**[3:125]** He said that he who obtained it was unworthy; that he had, however, obtained it, not through his own merits, but through the mercy of God.

**[3:126]** Listen to him now demanding the payment of a debt, who had first received unmerited grace: "For," saith he, "I am now ready to be offered up, and the time of my departure is at hand.

**[3:127]** I have fought a good fight, I have finished my course, I have kept the faith: henceforth there is laid up for me a crown of righteousness".

**[3:128]** Now he demands a debt, he exacts what is due.

**[3:129]** For consider the following words: "Which the Lord, the righteous Judge, shall render unto me in that day".

**[3:130]** That he might in the former instance receive grace, he stood in need of a merciful Father; for the reward of grace, of a just judge.

**[3:131]** Will He who did not condemn the ungodly man condemn the faithful man? And yet, if thou dost rightly consider, it was He who first gave thee faith, whereby thou didst obtain favor; for not of thine own didst thou so obtain favor that anything should be due to thee.

**[3:132]** Wherefore, then, in afterwards bestowing the reward of immortality, He crowns His own gifts, not thy merits.

**[3:133]** Therefore, brethren, "we all of His fullness have received;" of the fullness of His mercy, of the abundance of His goodness have we received.

**[3:134]** What? The remission of sins that we might be justified by faith.

**[3:135]** And what besides? "And grace for grace;" that is, for this grace by which we live by faith we shall receive another grace.

**[3:136]** What, then, is it except grace? For if I shall say that this also is due, I attribute something to myself as if to me it were due.

**[3:137]** But God crowns in us the gifts of His own mercy; but on condition that we walk with perseverance in that grace which in the first instance we received  11.

**[3:138]** "For the law was given by Moses;" which law held the guilty.

**[3:139]** For what saith the apostle? "The law entered that the offense might abound".

**[3:140]** It was a benefit to the proud that the offense abounded, for they gave much to themselves, and, as it were, attributed much to their own strength; and they were unable to fulfill righteousness without the aid of Him who had commanded it.

**[3:141]** God, desirous to subdue their pride, gave the law, as if saying: Behold, fulfill, and do not think that there is One wanting to command.

**[3:142]** One to command is not wanting, but one to fulfill.

**[3:143]** 12.

**[3:144]** If, then, there is one wanting to fulfill, whence does he not fulfill? Because born with the heritage of sin and death.

**[3:145]** Born of Adam, he drew with him that which was there conceived.

**[3:146]** The first man fell, and all who were born of him from him derived the concupiscence of the flesh.

**[3:147]** It was needful that another man should be born who derived no concupiscence.

**[3:148]** A man and a man: a man to death and a man to life.
