**[19:161]** But since its own life is God, just as it supplies vigor, comeliness, activity, the functions of the limbs to the body, while it exists in the body; so, in like manner, while God, its life, is in the soul, He supplies to it wisdom, godliness, righteousness, charity.

**[19:162]** Accordingly, what the soul supplies to the body, and what God supplies to the soul, are of a different kind: the soul quickens and is quickened.

**[19:163]** It quickens while dead, even if itself is not quickened.

**[19:164]** But when the word comes, and is poured into the hearers, and they not only hear, but are made obedient, the soul rises from its death to its life—that is, from unrighteousness, from folly, from ungodliness, to its God, who is to it wisdom, righteousness, light.

**[19:165]** Let it rise to Him, and be enlightened by Him.

**[19:166]** "Come near," saith he, "to Him".

**[19:167]** And what shall we have? "And be enlightened".

**[19:168]** If, therefore, by "coming to" ye are enlightened, and by "departing from" ye become darkened, your light was not in yourselves, but in your God.

**[19:169]** Come to Him that ye may rise again: if ye depart from Him, ye shall die.

**[19:170]** If by coming to Him ye live, and by departing from Him ye die, your life was not in yourselves.

**[19:171]** For the same is your life which is your light.

**[19:172]** "Because with Thee is the fountain of life, and in Thy light we shall see light".

**[19:173]** 13.

**[19:174]** Not, then, in like manner as the soul is one thing before it is enlightened, and becomes a better thing when it is enlightened, by participation of a better; not so, I say, was the Word of God, the Son of God, something else before He received life, that He should have life by participation; but He has life in Himself, and is consequently Himself the very life.

**[19:175]** What is it, then, that He saith, "hath given to the Son to have life in Himself"? I would say it briefly, He begot the Son.

**[19:176]** For it is not that He existed without life, and received life, but He is life by being begotten.

**[19:177]** The Father is life not by being begotten; the Son is life by being begotten.

**[19:178]** The Father is of no father; the Son is of God the Father.

**[19:179]** The Father in His being is of none, but in that He is Father, 'tis because of the Son.

**[19:180]** But the Son also, in that He is Son, 'tis because of the Father: in His being, He is of the Father.

**[19:181]** This He said, therefore: "hath given life to the Son, that He might have it in Himself".

**[19:182]** Just as if He were to say, "The Father, who is life in Himself, begot the Son, who should be life in Himself".

**[19:183]** Indeed, He would have this dedit (hath given) to be understood for the same thing as genuit (hath begotten).

**[19:184]** It is like as if we said to a person, "God hath given thee being".

**[19:185]** To whom? If to some one already existing, then He gave him not being, because he who could receive existed before it was given him.

**[19:186]** When, therefore, thou hearest it said, "He gave thee being," thou wast not in being to receive, but thou didst receive, that thou shouldst be by coming into existence.

**[19:187]** The builder gave to this house that it should be.

**[19:188]** But what did he give to it? He gave it to be a house.

**[19:189]** To what did he give? To this house.

**[19:190]** Gave it what? To be a house.

**[19:191]** How could he give to a house that it should be a house? For if the house was, to what did he give to be a house, when the house existed already? What, then, does that mean, "gave it to be a house"? It means, he brought to pass that it should be a house.

**[19:192]** Well, then, what gave He to the Son? Gave Him to be the Son, begot Him to be life—that is, "gave Him to have life in Himself" that He should be the life not needing life, that He may not be understood as having life by participation.

**[19:193]** For if He had life by par  ticipation, He might, by losing, be without life.

**[19:194]** Do not take, nor think, nor believe this to be possible respecting the Son.

**[19:195]** Wherefore the Father continues the life, the Son continues the life: the Father, life in Himself, not from the Son; the Son, life in Himself, but from the Father.

**[19:196]** Begotten of the Father, that He might live in Himself; but the Father, not begotten, life in Himself.

**[19:197]** Nor did He beget the Son less than Himself to become equal by growth.

**[19:198]** For surely He by whom, being perfect, the times were created, was not assisted by time towards His own perfection.

**[19:199]** Before all time, He is co-eternal with the Father.

**[19:200]** For the Father has never been without the Son; but the Father is eternal, therefore also the Son co-eternal.

**[19:201]** Soul, what of thee? Thou wast dead, didst lose life; hear then the Father through the Son.

**[19:202]** Arise, take to thee life, that in Him who has life in Himself thou mayest receive the life which is not in thee.

**[19:203]** He that giveth thee life, then, is the Father and the Son; and the first resurrection is accomplished when thou risest to partake of the life which thou art not thyself, and by partaking art made living.

**[19:204]** Rise from thy death to thy life, which is thy God, and pass from death to eternal life.

**[19:205]** For the Father hath eternal life in Himself; and unless He had begotten such a Son as had life in Himself, it could not be that as the Father raiseth up the dead, and quickeneth them, so also the Son should quicken whom He will.

**[19:206]** 14.

**[19:207]** But what of that resurrection of the body? For these who hear and live, whence live, except by hearing? For "the friend of the Bridegroom standeth and heareth Him, and rejoiceth greatly because of the Bridegroom's voice:" not because of his own voice; that is to say, they hear and live by partaking, not by coming into being; and all that hear live, because all that obey live.

**[19:208]** Tell us something, O Lord, also of the resurrection of the flesh; for there have been those who denied it, asserting that this is the only resurrection which is wrought by faith.

**[19:209]** Of which resurrection the Lord has just now made mention, and inflamed our desire, because "the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and shall live".

**[19:210]** It is not some of those who hear shall live, and others shall die; but "all that hear shall live," because all that obey shall live.

**[19:211]** Behold, we see a resurrection of the mind; let us not therefore let go our faith of the resurrection of the flesh.

**[19:212]** And unless Thou, O Lord Jesus, declare to us this, whom shall we oppose to those who assert the contrary? For truly all sects that have undertaken to engraft any religion upon men have allowed this resurrection of minds; otherwise, it might be said to them, If the soul rise not, why speakest thou to me? What meanest thou to do in me? If thou dost not make of the worse a better, why speakest thou? If thou dost not make a righteous of the unrighteous, why speakest thou? But if thou dost make righteous of the unrighteous, godly of the ungodly, wise of the foolish, thou confessest that my soul doth rise again, if I comply with thee and believe.

**[19:213]** So, then, all those that have founded any sect, even of false religion, while they wished to be believed, could not but admit this resurrection of minds: all have agreed concerning this; but many have denied the resurrection of the flesh, and affirmed that the resurrection had taken place already in faith.

**[19:214]** Such the apostle resisteth, saying, "Of whom is Hymeneus and Philetus, who concerning the truth have erred, saying that the resurrection hath taken place already, and overthrow the faith of some".

**[19:215]** They said that the resurrection had taken place already, but in such manner that another was not to be expected; and they blamed people who were looking for a resurrection of the flesh, just as if the resurrection which was promised were already accomplished in the act of believing, namely, in the mind.

**[19:216]** The apostle censures these.

**[19:217]** Why does he censure them? Did they not affirm what the Lord spoke just now: "The hour cometh, and now is, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and they that hear shall live"? But, saith Jesus to thee, it is of the life of minds that I am hitherto speaking: I am not yet speaking of the life of bodies; but I speak of the life of that which is the life of bodies, that is, of the life of souls, in which the life of bodies exists.

**[19:218]** For I know that there are bodies lying in the tombs; I know also that your bodies will lie in the tombs.

**[19:219]** I am not speaking of that resurrection, but I speak of this; in this, rise ye again, lest ye rise to punishment in that.

**[19:220]** But that ye may know that I speak also of that, what do I add? "For as the Father hath life in Himself, even so hath He given to the Son to have life in Himself".

**[19:221]** This life which the Father is, which the Son is, to what does it pertain? To the soul or to the body? It is not surely the body that is sensible of that life of wisdom, but the rational mind.

**[19:222]** For not every soul hath capacity to apprehend wisdom.

**[19:223]** A brute beast, in fact, has a soul, but the soul of the brute beast  cannot apprehend wisdom.

**[19:224]** It is the human soul, then, that can perceive this life which the Father hath in Himself, and hath given to the Son to have in Himself; because that is "the true light which enlighteneth," not every soul, but "every man coming into this world".

**[19:225]** When, therefore, I speak to the mind itself, let it hear, that is, let it obey and live.

**[19:226]** 15.

**[19:227]** Wherefore, keep not silent, O Lord, concerning the resurrection of the flesh; lest men believe it not, and we continue reasoners, not preachers.

**[19:228]** But "as the Father hath life in Himself, even so hath He given to the Son to have life in Himself".

**[19:229]** Let them that hear, understand; let them believe that they may understand; let them obey that they may live.

**[19:230]** And that they may not suppose that the resurrection is finished here, let them hear this further: "and hath given Him authority to execute judgment also".

**[19:231]** Who hath given? The Father.

**[19:232]** To whom hath He given? To the Son; namely, to whom He gave to have life in Himself, to the same hath He given authority to execute judgment.

**[19:233]** "Because He is the Son of man".

**[19:234]** For this is the Christ, both Son of God and Son of man.

**[19:235]** "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

**[19:236]** This was in the beginning with God".

**[19:237]** Behold, how He hath given Him to have life in Himself! But because "the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us," was made man of the Virgin Mary, He is the Son of man.

**[19:238]** What, therefore, hath He received as Son of man? Authority to execute judgment.

**[19:239]** What judgment? That in the end of the world.

**[19:240]** Then also there will be a resurrection, but a resurrection of bodies.

**[19:241]** So, then, God raiseth up souls by Christ, the Son of God; bodies He raiseth up by the same Christ, the Son of man.

**[19:242]** "Hath given Him authority".

**[19:243]** He should not have this authority did He not receive it; and He should be a man without authority.

**[19:244]** But the same who is Son of God is also Son of man.

**[19:245]** For by adhering to the unity of person, the Son of man with the Son of God is made one person, and the Son of God is the same person which the Son of man is.

**[19:246]** But what characteristic it has, and wherefore, must be distinguished.

**[19:247]** The Son of man has soul and body.

**[19:248]** The Son of God, which is the Word of God, has man, as the soul has body.

**[19:249]** And just as soul having body does not make two persons, but one man; so the Word, having man, maketh not two persons, but one Christ.

**[19:250]** What is man? A rational soul, having a body.

**[19:251]** What is Christ? The Word of God, having man.

**[19:252]** I see of what things I speak, who I the speaker am, and to whom I am speaking.

**[19:253]** 16.

**[19:254]** Now hear concerning the resurrection of bodies, not me, but the Lord about to speak, on account of those who have risen again by a resurrection from death, by cleaving to life.

**[19:255]** To what life? To a life which knows not death.

**[19:256]** Why knows not death? Because it knows not mutability.

**[19:257]** Why knows not mutability? Because it is life in itself.

**[19:258]** "And hath given Him authority to execute judgment, because He is the Son of man".

**[19:259]** What judgment, what kind of judgment? "Marvel not at this" which I have said,—gave Him authority to execute judgment,—"for the hour is coming".

**[19:260]** He does not adds "and now is:" therefore He means to make known to us a certain hour in the end of the world.

**[19:261]** The hour is now that the dead rise, the hour will be in the end of the world that the dead rise: but that they rise now in the mind, then in the flesh; that they rise now in the mind by the Word of God, the Son of God; then in the flesh by the Word of God made flesh, the Son of man.

**[19:262]** For it will not be the Father Himself that will come to judgment, notwithstanding the Father doth not withdraw Himself from the Son.

**[19:263]** How, then, is it that the Father Himself will not come? In that He will not be seen in the judgment.

**[19:264]** "They shall look on Him whom they pierced".

**[19:265]** That form which stood before the judge, will be Judge: that form will judge which was judged; for it was judged unjustly, it will judge justly.

**[19:266]** There will come the form of a servant, and that same will be apparent.

**[19:267]** For how could the form of God be made apparent to the just and to the unjust? If the judgment were to be only among the just, then the form of God might appear as to the just.

**[19:268]** But because the judgment is to be of the just and of the unjust, and that it is not permitted to the wicked to see God,—for "blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God,"—such a Judge will appear as may be seen by those whom He is about to crown, and by those whom He is about to condemn.

**[19:269]** Hence the form of a servant will be seen, the form of God will be hid.

**[19:270]** The Son of God will be hid in the servant, and the Son of man will be manifest, because to Him "hath He given authority to execute judgment, because He is the Son of man".

**[19:271]** And because He alone will appear in the form of a servant, but the Father not, since He has not taken upon Him the form of a servant; for that reason He saith above: "The Father judgeth not any man, but hath given all judgment to  the Son".

**[19:272]** Rightly then had it been deferred, that the propounder might Himself be the interpreter.

**[19:273]** For before it was hidden; now, as I think, it is already manifest, that "He gave Him authority to execute judgment," that "the Father judgeth not any man, but hath given all judgment to the Son:" because the judgment is to be by that form which the Father hath not.

**[19:274]** And what kind of judgment? "Marvel not at this, for the hour is coming:" not that which now is, for the souls to rise; but that which is to be, for the bodies to rise.

**[19:275]** 17.

**[19:276]** Let Him declare this more distinctly, that the heretical denier of the resurrection of the body may not find a pretext for sophistical cavil, although the meaning already shines out clearly.

**[19:277]** When it was said above, "The hour is coming," He added, "and now is;" but just now, "The hour is coming," He has not added, "and now is".

**[19:278]** Let Him, however, by the open truth, burst asunder all handles, all loops and pegs of sophistical attack, all the nooses of ensnaring objections.

**[19:279]** "Marvel not at this: for the hour is coming, in which all that are in the graves".

**[19:280]** What more evident? what more distinct? Bodies are in the graves; souls are not in the graves, either of just or of unjust.

**[19:281]** The soul of the just man was in the bosom of Abraham; the unjust man's soul was in hell, tormented: neither the one nor the other was in the grave.

**[19:282]** Above, when He saith, "The hour is coming, and now is," I beseech you give earnest heed.

**[19:283]** Ye know, brethren, that we get the bread of the belly with toil; with how much greater toil the bread of the mind! With labor you stand and hear, but with greater we stand and speak.

**[19:284]** If we labor for your sake, you ought to labor with us for your own sake.

**[19:285]** Above, then, when He said, "The hour is coming," and added, "and now is," what did He subjoin? "When the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and they that hear shall live".

**[19:286]** He did not say, "All the dead shall hear, and they that hear shall live;" for He meant the unrighteous to be understood.

**[19:287]** And is it so, that all the unrighteous obey the gospel? The apostle says openly, "But not all obey the gospel".

**[19:288]** But they that hear shall live, because all that obey the gospel shall pass to eternal life by faith: yet all do not obey; and this is now.

**[19:289]** But certainly, in the end, "All that are in the graves," both the just and the unjust, "shall hear His voice, and come forth".

**[19:290]** How is it He would not say, "and shall live"? All, indeed, will come forth, but all will not live.

**[19:291]** For in that which He said above, "And they that hear shall live," He meant it to be understood that there is in that very hearing and obeying an eternal and blessed life, which not all that shall come forth from the graves will have.

**[19:292]** Here, then, both in the mention of graves, and by the expression of a "coming forth" from the graves, we openly understand a resurrection of bodies.

**[19:293]** 18.

**[19:294]** "All shall hear His voice, and shall come forth".

**[19:295]** And where is judgment, if all shall hear and all shall come forth? It is as if all were confusion; I see no distinguishing.

**[19:296]** Certainly Thou hast received authority to judge, because Thou art the Son of man: behold, Thou wilt be present in the judgment; the bodies will rise again; but tell us something of the judgment itself, that is, of the separation of the evil and the good.

**[19:297]** Hear this further, then: "They that have done good into the resurrection of life; they that have done evil into the resurrection of judgment".

**[19:298]** When above He spoke of a resurrection of minds and souls, did He make any distinction? No, for all "that hear shall live;" because by hearing, viz.

**[19:299]** by obeying, shall they live.

**[19:300]** But certainly not all will go to eternal life by rising and coming forth from the graves,—only they that have done well; and they that have done ill, to judgment.

**[19:301]** For here He has put judgment for punishment.

**[19:302]** There will also be a separation, not such as there is now.

**[19:303]** For now we are separated, not by place, but by character, affections, desires, faith, hope, charity.

**[19:304]** Now we live together with the unjust, though the life of all is not the same: in secret we are distinguished, in secret we are separated; as grain on the floor, not as grain in the granary.

**[19:305]** On the floor, grain is both separated and mixed: separated, because severed from the chaff; mixed, because not yet winnowed.

**[19:306]** Then there will be an open separation; a distinguishing of life just as of the character, a separation as there is in wisdom, so also will there be in bodies.

**[19:307]** They that have done well will go to live with the angels of God; they that have done evil, to be tormented with the devil and his angels.

**[19:308]** And the form of a servant will pass away.

**[19:309]** For to this end He had manifested Himself, that He might execute judgment.

**[19:310]** After the judgment, He shall go hence, will lead with Him the body of which He is the head, and deliver up the kingdom of God.

**[19:311]** Then will openly be seen that form of God which could not be seen by the wicked, to whose vision the form of a servant must be shown.

**[19:312]** He says also in another place on this wise:  "These shall go away into everlasting burning" (speaking of certain on the left), "but the just into life eternal;" of which life He says in another place: "And this is eternal life, that they may know Thee the one true God, and Jesus Christ whom Thou hast sent".

**[19:313]** Then will He be there manifested, "who, being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal with God".

**[19:314]** Then He will manifest Himself, as He has promised to manifest Himself to them that love Him.

**[19:315]** For "he that loveth me," saith He, "keepeth my commandments; and he that loveth me shall be loved of my Father; and I will love him, and will manifest myself to him".

**[19:316]** He was present in person with those to whom He was speaking: but they saw the form of a servant, they did not see the form of God.

**[19:317]** They were being led on His own beast to His dwelling to be healed; but now being healed, they will see, because, saith He, "I will manifest myself to him".

**[19:318]** How is He shown equal to the Father? When He says to Philip, "He that seeth me seeth my Father also".

**[19:319]** 19.

**[19:320]** "I cannot of myself do anything: as I hear, I judge: and my judgment is just".

**[19:321]** Else we might have said to Him, "Thou wilt judge, and the Father will not judge, for 'all judgment hath He given to the Son;' it is not, therefore, according to the Father that Thou wilt judge".

**[19:322]** Hence He added, "I cannot of myself do anything: as I hear, I judge: and my judgment is just; because I seek not my own will, but the will of Him that sent me".

**[19:323]** Undoubtedly the Son quickeneth whom He will.

**[19:324]** He seeketh not His own will, but the will of Him that sent Him.

**[19:325]** Not my own, my proper will; not mine, not the Son of man's; not mine to resist God.

**[19:326]** For men do their own will, not God's, when they do what they list, not what God commands; but when they do what they list, so as yet to follow God's will, they do not their own will, notwithstanding they do what they list to do.

**[19:327]** Do what thou art bidden willingly, and thus shall thou both do what thou willest, and also not do thine own will, but His that biddeth.

**[19:328]** 20.

**[19:329]** What then? "As I hear, I judge".

**[19:330]** The Son "heareth," and the Father "showeth" to Him, and the Son seeth the Father doing.

**[19:331]** But we had deferred these matters, in order to handle them, so far as might lie in our abilities, with somewhat greater plainness and fullness, should time and strength remain to us after finishing the perusal of the passage.

**[19:332]** If I say that I am able to speak yet further, you perhaps are not able to go on hearing.

**[19:333]** Again, perhaps, in your eagerness to hear, you say, "We are able".

**[19:334]** Better, then, that I should confess my weakness, that, being already fatigued, I am not able to speak longer, than that, when you are already satiated, I should continue to pour into you what you cannot well digest.

**[19:335]** Then, as to this promise, which I deferred until today, should there be an opportunity, hold me, with the Lord's help, your debtor until to-morrow.

**[20:1]** Tractate XX.

**[20:2]** Chapter V.

**[20:3]** 19  1.

**[20:4]** The words of our Lord Jesus Christ, especially those recorded by the Evangelist John,—who not without cause leaned on the Lord's bosom, that he might drink in the secrets of that higher wisdom, and by evangelizing give forth again what by loving he had drunk in,—are so secret and profound of understanding, that they trouble all who are perverse of heart, and exercise all who are in heart upright.

**[20:5]** Wherefore, beloved, give heed to these few words that have been read.

**[20:6]** Let us see if in any wise we can, by His own gift and help who has willed His words to be recited to us, which at that time were heard and committed to writing that they might now be read, what He means in what ye have now heard Him say: "Verily, verily, I say unto you, The Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing: for what things soever the Father doeth, these same the Son also doeth in like manner".

**[20:7]** 2.

**[20:8]** Now you need to be reminded whence this discourse arose, by reason of what precedes this passage, where the Lord had cured a certain man among those who were lying in the five porches of that pool of Solomon, and to whom He had said, "Take up thy bed, and go unto thy house".

**[20:9]** But this He had done  on the Sabbath; and hence the Jews, being troubled, were falsely accusing Him as a destroyer and transgressor of the law.

**[20:10]** He then said to them, "My Father worketh even until now, and I work".

**[20:11]** For they, taking the observance of the Sabbath in a carnal sense, fancied that God had, as it were, slept after the labor of framing the world even to this day; and that therefore He had sanctified that day, from which He began to rest as from labor.

**[20:12]** Now, to our fathers of old there was ordained a sacrament of the Sabbath, which we Christians observe spiritually, in abstaining from every servile work, that is, from every sin (for the Lord saith, "Every one that committeth sin is the servant of sin"), and in having rest in our heart, that is, spiritual tranquillity.

**[20:13]** And although in this life we strive after this rest, yet not until we have departed this life shall we attain to that perfect rest.

**[20:14]** But the reason why God is said to have rested is, that He made no creature after all was finished.

**[20:15]** Moreover, the Scripture called it rest, to admonish us that after good works we shall rest.

**[20:16]** For thus we have it written in Genesis, "And God made all things very good, and God rested on the seventh day," in order that thou, O man, considering that God Himself is said to have rested after good works, shouldest not expect rest for thyself, until after thou hast wrought good works; and even as God after He made man in His own image and likeness, and in him finished all His works very good, rested on the seventh day, so mayest thou also not expect rest to thyself, except thou return to that likeness in which thou wast made, which likeness thou hast lost by sinning.

**[20:17]** For, in reality, God cannot be said to have toiled, who "said, and they were done".

**[20:18]** Who is there that, after such facility of work, desires to rest as if after labor? If He commanded and some one resisted Him, if He commanded and it was not done, and labored that it might be done, then justly He should be said to have rested after labor.

**[20:19]** But when in that same book of Genesis we read, "God said, Let there be light, and there was light; God said, Let there be a firmament, and the firmament was made, and all the rest were made immediately at His word: to which also the psalm testifies, saying, "He spake, and they were made; He commanded, and they were created,"—how could He require rest after the world was made, as if to enjoy leisure after toil, He who in commanding never toiled? Consequently these sayings are mystical, and are laid down in this wise that we may be looking for rest after this life, provided we have done good works.

**[20:20]** Accordingly, the Lord, restraining the impudence and refuting the error of the Jews, and showing them that they did not think rightly of God, says to them, when they were offended at His working men's healing on the Sabbath, "My Father worketh until now, and I work:" do not therefore suppose that my Father so rested on the Sabbath, that thenceforth He doth not work; but even as He now worketh, so I also work.

**[20:21]** But as the Father without toil, so too the Son without toil.

**[20:22]** God "said, and they were done;" Christ said to the impotent man, "Take up thy bed, and go unto thy house," and it was done.

**[20:23]** 3.

**[20:24]** But the catholic faith has it, that the works of the Father and of the Son are not separable.

**[20:25]** This is what I wish, if possible, to speak to you, beloved; but, according to those words of the Lord, "he that is able to receive it, let him receive it".

**[20:26]** But he that is not able to receive it, let him not charge it on me, but on his own dullness; and let him turn to Him that opens the heart, that He may pour in what He freely giveth.

**[20:27]** And, lastly, if any one may not have understood, because I have not declared it as I ought to have declared it, let him excuse the weakness of man, and supplicate the divine goodness.

**[20:28]** For we have within a Master, Christ.

**[20:29]** Whatever ye are not able to receive through your ear and my mouth, turn ye in your heart to Him who both teacheth me what to speak, and distributeth to you in what measure He deigns.

**[20:30]** He who knows what to give, and to whom to give, will help him that seeketh, and open to him that knocketh.

**[20:31]** And if so be that He give not, let no one call himself forsaken.

**[20:32]** For it may be that He delays to give something, but He leaves none hungry.

**[20:33]** If, indeed, He give not at the hour, He is exercising the seeker, He is not scorning the suitor.

**[20:34]** Look ye, then, and give heed to what I wish to say, even if I should not be able to say it.

**[20:35]** The catholic faith, confirmed by the Spirit of God in His saints, has this against all heretical perverseness, that the works of the Father and of the Son are inseparable.

**[20:36]** What is this that I have said? As the Father and the Son are inseparable, so also the works of the Father and of the Son are inseparable.

**[20:37]** How are the Father and the Son inseparable, since Himself said, "I and the Father are one?"  Because the Father and the Son are not two Gods, but one God, the Word and He whose the Word is, One and the Only One, Father and Son  bound together by charity, One God, and the Spirit of Charity also one, so that Father, Son, and Holy Spirit is made the Trinity.

**[20:38]** Therefore, not only of the Father and Son, but also of the Holy Spirit; as there is equality and inseparability of persons, so also the works are inseparable.

**[20:39]** I will tell you yet more plainly what is meant by "the works are inseparable".

**[20:40]** The catholic faith does not say that God the Father made something, and the Son made some other thing; but what the Father made, that also the Son made, that also the Holy Spirit made.

**[20:41]** For all things were made by the Word; when "He spoke and they were done," it is by the Word they were done, by Christ they were done.

**[20:42]** For "in the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God: all things were made by Him".

**[20:43]** If all things were made by Him, "God said, Let there be light, and there was light; in the Word He made, by the Word He made.

**[20:44]** 4.

**[20:45]** Behold, then, we have now heard the Gospel, where He answered the Jews who were indignant "that He not only broke the Sabbath, but said also that God was His Father, making Himself equal with God".

**[20:46]** For so it is written in the foregoing paragraph.

**[20:47]** When, therefore, the Son of God, the Truth, made answer to their erring indignation, saith He, "Verily, verily, I say unto you, The Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing;" as if He said, "Why are ye offended because I have said that God is my Father, and that I make myself equal with God? I am equal in that wise that He begat me; I am equal in that wise that He is not from me, but I from Him".

**[20:48]** For this is implied in these words: "The Son cannot do anything of Himself, but  what He seeth the Father doing".

**[20:49]** That is, whatever the Son hath to do, the doing it He hath of the Father.

**[20:50]** Why of the Father hath He the doing it? Because of the Father He hath it that He is Son.

**[20:51]** Why hath He it of the Father to be Son? Because of the Father He hath it that He is able, of the Father that He is.

**[20:52]** For, to the Son, both to be able and to be is the self-same thing.

**[20:53]** It is not so with man.

**[20:54]** Raise your hearts by all means from a comparison of human weakness, that lies far beneath; and should any of us perhaps reach to the secret, and, while awe-struck by the brilliance as it were of a great light, should discern somewhat, and not remain wholly ignorant; yet let him not imagine that he understands the whole, lest he should become proud, and lose what knowledge he has gotten.

**[20:55]** With man, to be and to be able are different things.

**[20:56]** For sometimes the man is, and yet cannot what he wills; sometimes, again, the man is in such wise, that he can what he wills; therefore his being and his being able are different things.

**[20:57]** For if man's esse and posse were the same thing, then he could when he would.

**[20:58]** But with God it is not so, that His substance to be is one thing, and His power to be able another thing; but whatever is His, and whatever He is, is consubstantial with Him, because He is God: it is not so that in one way He is, in another way is able; He has the esse and the posse together, because He has to will and to do together.

**[20:59]** Since, then, the power of the Son is of the Father, therefore also the substance of the Son is of the Father; and since the substance of the Son is of the Father, therefore the power of the Son is of the Father.

**[20:60]** In the Son, power and substance are not different: the power is the self-same that the substance is; the substance to be, the power to be able.

**[20:61]** Accordingly, because the Son is of the Father, He said, "The Son cannot of Himself do anything".

**[20:62]** Because He is not Son from Himself, therefore He is not able from Himself.

**[20:63]** 5.

**[20:64]** He appears to have made Himself as it were less, when He said, "The Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing".

**[20:65]** Hereupon heretical vanity lifts the neck; theirs, indeed, who say that the Son is less than the Father, of less authority, of less majesty, of less possibility, not understanding the mystery of Christ's words.

**[20:66]** But attend, beloved, and see how they are confounded in their carnal intellect by the words of Christ.

**[20:67]** And this is what I said a little before, that the word of God troubles all perverse hearts, just as it exercises pious hearts, especially that spoken by the Evangelist John.

**[20:68]** For they are deep words that are spoken by him, not random words, nor such as may be easily understood.

**[20:69]** So, a heretic, if he happen to hear these words, immediately rises and says to us, "Lo, the Son is less than the Father; hear the words of the Son, who says, 'The Son cannot do anything of Himself, but what He seeth the Father doing.

**[20:70]** '" Wait; as it is written, "Be meek to hear the word, that thou mayest understand".

**[20:71]** Well, suppose that because I assert the power and majesty of the Father and of the Son to be equal, I was disconcerted at hearing these words, "The Son cannot do anything of Himself, but what He seeth the Father doing".

**[20:72]** Well, I, being disconcerted at these words, will ask thee, who seemest to thyself to have instantly understood them, a question.

**[20:73]** We know in the Gospel that the Son walked upon the sea; when saw He the Father walk upon the sea? Here now he is disconcerted.

**[20:74]** Lay aside, then, thy understanding of the words, and let us examine them together.

**[20:75]** What do we then? We have heard the words of the Lord: "The Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing".

**[20:76]** The Son walked upon the sea, the Father never walked upon the sea.

**[20:77]** Yet certainly "the Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing".

**[20:78]** 6.

**[20:79]** Return then with me to what I was saying, in case it is so to be understood that we may both escape from the question.

**[20:80]** For I see how I, according to the catholic faith, may escape without tripping or stumbling; whilst thou, on the other hand, shut in on every side, art seeking a way of escape.

**[20:81]** See by what way thou hast entered.

**[20:82]** Perhaps thou hast not understood this that I said, See by what way thou hast entered: hear Himself saying, "I am the door".

**[20:83]** Not without cause, then, art thou seeking how thou mayest get out; and this only thou findest, that thou hast not entered by the door, but fell in over the wall.

**[20:84]** Therefore raise thyself up from thy fall how thou canst, and enter by the door, that thou mayest go in without stumbling, and go out without straying.

**[20:85]** Come by Christ, not bringing forward of thy own heart what thou mayest say; but what He shows, that speak.

**[20:86]** Behold how the catholic faith gets clear of this question.

**[20:87]** The Son walked upon the sea, planted the feet of flesh on the waves: the flesh walked, and the divinity directed.

**[20:88]** But when the flesh was walking and the divinity directing, was the Father absent? If absent, how doth the Son Himself say, "but the Father abiding in me, Himself doeth the works?" If the Father, abiding in the Son, Himself doeth His works, then that walking upon the sea was made by the Father, and through the Son.

**[20:89]** Accordingly, that walking is an inseparable work of Father and Son.

**[20:90]** I see both acting in it.

**[20:91]** Neither the Father forsook the Son, nor the Son left the Father.

**[20:92]** Thus, whatever the Son doeth, He doeth not without the Father; because whatever the Father doeth, He doeth not without the Son.

**[20:93]** 7.

**[20:94]** We have got clear of this question.

**[20:95]** Mark ye that rightly we say the works of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit are inseparable.

**[20:96]** But as thou understandest it, lo, God made the light, and the Son saw the Father making light, according to thy carnal understanding, who wilt have it that He is less, because He said, "The Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing".

**[20:97]** God the Father made light; what other light did the Son make? God the Father made the firmament, the heaven between waters and waters; and the Son saw Him, according to thy dull and sluggish understanding.

**[20:98]** Well, since the Son saw the Father making the firmament, and also said, "The Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing," then show me the other firmament made by the Son.

**[20:99]** Hast thou lost the foundation? But they that are "built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ Himself being the chief corner-stone," are brought into a state of peace in Christ; nor do they strive and wander in heresy.

**[20:100]** Therefore we understand that the light was made by God the Father, but through the Son; that the firmament was made by God the Father, but through the Son.

**[20:101]** For "all things were made through Him, and without Him was nothing made".

**[20:102]** Cast out thine understanding, which ought not to be called understanding, but evidently foolishness.

**[20:103]** God the Father made the world; what other world did the Son make? Show me the Son's world.

**[20:104]** Whose is this world in which we are? Tell us, by whom made? If thou sayest, "By the Son, not by the Father," then thou hast erred from the Father; if thou sayest, "By the Father, not by the Son," the Gospel answers thee thus, "And the world was made by (through) Him, and the world knew Him not".

**[20:105]** Acknowledge Him, then, by whom the world was made, and be not among those who knew not Him that made the world.

**[20:106]** 8.

**[20:107]** Wherefore the works of the Father and of the Son are inseparable.

**[20:108]** Moreover, this, "The Son cannot do anything of Himself," would mean the same thing as if He were to say, "The Son is not from Himself".

**[20:109]** For if He is a Son, He was begotten; if begotten, He is from Him of whom He is begotten.

**[20:110]** Nevertheless, the Father begat Him equal to Himself.

**[20:111]** Nor was aught wanting to Him that begat; He who begat a co-eternal required not time to beget: who produced the Word of Himself, required not a mother to beget by; the Father begetting did not precede the Son in age, so that He should beget a Son younger than Himself.

**[20:112]** But perhaps some one may say, that after many ages God  begat a Son in His old age.

**[20:113]** Even as the Father is without age, so the Son is without growth; neither has the one grown old nor the other increased, but equal begat equal, eternal begat eternal.

**[20:114]** How, says some one, has eternal begat eternal? As a temporary flame generates a temporary light.

**[20:115]** The generating flame is coeval with the light which it generates: the generating flame does not precede in time the generated light; but from the moment the flame begins, from that moment the light begins.

**[20:116]** Show me flame without light, and I show thee God the Father without Son.

**[20:117]** Accordingly, "the Son cannot do anything of Himself, but what He seeth the Father doing," implies, that for the Son to see and to be begotten of the Father, is the same thing.

**[20:118]** His seeing and His substance are not different; nor are His power and substance different.

**[20:119]** All that He is, He is of the Father; all that He can is of the Father; because what He can and what He is is one thing, and all of the Father.

**[20:120]** 9.

**[20:121]** Moreover, He goes on in His own words, and troubles those that understand the matter amiss, in order to recall the erring to a right apprehension of it.

**[20:122]** After He had said, "The Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing;" lest a carnal understanding of the matter should by chance creep in and turn the mind aside, and a man should imagine as it were two mechanics, one a master, the other a learner, attentively observing the master while making, say a chest, so that, as the master made the chest, the learner should make another chest according to the appearance which he looked upon while the master wrought; lest, I say, the carnal mind should frame to itself any such twofold notion in the case of the divine unity, going on, He saith, "For what things soever the Father doeth, these same also the Son doeth in like manner".

**[20:123]** It is not, the Father doeth some, the Son others like them, but the same in like manner.

**[20:124]** For He saith not, What things soever the Father doeth, the Son also doeth others the like; but saith He, "What things soever the Father doeth, these same also the Son doeth in like manner".

**[20:125]** What things the Father doeth, these also the Son doeth: the Father made the world, the Son made the world, the Holy Ghost made the world.

**[20:126]** If three Gods, then three worlds; if one God, the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, then one world was made by the Father, through the Son, in the Holy Ghost.

**[20:127]** Consequently the Son doeth those things which also the Father doeth, and doeth not in a different manner; He both doeth these, and doeth them in like manner.

**[20:128]** 10.

**[20:129]** After He had said, "these doeth," why did He add, "in like manner doeth"? Lest another distorted understanding or error should spring up in the mind.

**[20:130]** Thou seest, for instance, a man's work: in man there is mind and body; the mind rules the body, but there is a great difference between body and mind: the body is visible, the mind is invisible: there is a great difference between the power and virtue of the mind and that of any kind of body whatever, be it even a heavenly body.

**[20:131]** Still the mind rules its own body, and the body doeth; and what the mind appears to do, this the body doeth also.

**[20:132]** Thus the body appears to do this same thing that the mind doeth, but not "in like manner".

**[20:133]** How doeth this same, but not in like manner? The mind frames a word in itself; it commands the tongue, and the tongue produces the word which the mind framed: the mind made, and the tongue made; the lord of the body made, and the servant made; but that the servant might make, it received of its lord what to make, and made while the lord commanded.

**[20:134]** The same thing was made by both, but was it in like manner? How not in like manner? says some one.

**[20:135]** See, the word that my mind formed, remains in me; that which my tongue made, passed through the smitten air, and is not.

**[20:136]** When thou hast said a word in thy mind, and uttered it by thy tongue, return to thy mind, and see that the word which thou hast made is there still.

**[20:137]** Has it remained on thy tongue, just as it has in thy mind? What was uttered by the tongue, the tongue made by sounding, the mind made by thinking; but what the tongue uttered has passed away, what the mind thought remains.

**[20:138]** Therefore the body made that which the mind made, but not in like manner.

**[20:139]** For the mind, indeed, made that which the mind may hold, but the tongue made what sounds and strikes the ear through the air.

**[20:140]** Dost thou chase the syllables, and cause them to remain? Well, not in such manner the Father and the Son; but "these same doeth," and "in like manner doeth".

**[20:141]** If God made heaven that remains, this heaven that remains the Son made.

**[20:142]** If God the Father made man that is mortal, the same man that is mortal the Son made.

**[20:143]** What things soever the Father made that endure, these things that endure made also the Son, because in like manner He made; and what things soever the Father made that are temporal, these same things that are temporal made also the Son, because He made not only the same, but also in like manner made.

**[20:144]** For the Father made by the Son, since by the Word the Father made all things.

**[20:145]** 11.

**[20:146]** Seek in the Father and Son a separation, thou findest none; no, not if thou hast mounted high; no, not even if thou hast reached something above thy mind.

**[20:147]** For if thou turnest about among the things which thy wandering mind makes for itself, thou talkest with thine own imaginations, not with the Word of God; thine own imaginations deceive thee.

**[20:148]** Mount also beyond the body, and understand the mind; mount also beyond the mind, and understand God.

**[20:149]** Thou reachest not unto God, unless thou hast passed beyond the mind; how much less thou reachest unto God, if thou hast tarried in the flesh! They who think of the flesh, how far are they from understanding what God is!—since they would not be there even if they knew the mind.

**[20:150]** Man recedes far from God when his thoughts are of the flesh; and there is a great difference between flesh and mind, yet a greater between mind and God.

**[20:151]** If thou art occupied with the mind, thou art in the midway: if thou directest thy attention beneath, there is the body; if above, there is God.

**[20:152]** Lift thyself up from the body, pass beyond even thyself.

**[20:153]** For observe what said the psalm, and thou art admonished how God must be thought of: "My tears," it saith, "were made to me my bread day and night, when it was said to me daily, Where is thy God?" As the pagans may say, "Behold our gods, where is your God?" They indeed show us what is seen; we worship what is not seen.

**[20:154]** And to whom can we show? To a man who has not sight with which to see? For anyhow, if they see their gods with their eyes, we too have other eyes with which to see our God: for "blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God".

**[20:155]** Therefore, when he had said that he was troubled, when it was daily said to him, "Where is thy God?" "these things I remembered," saith he, "because it is daily said to me, Where is thy God?" And as if wishing to lay hold of his God, "These things," saith he, "I remembered, and poured out my soul above me".

**[20:156]** Therefore, that I might reach unto my God, of whom it was said to me, "Where is thy God? I poured out my soul," not over my flesh, but "above me;" I transcended myself, that I might reach unto Him: for He is above me who made me; none reaches to Him but he that passes beyond himself.

**[20:157]** 12.

**[20:158]** Consider the body: it is mortal, earthy, weak, corruptible; away with it.

**[20:159]** Yes, perhaps thou sayest, but the body is temporal.

**[20:160]** Think then of other bodies, the heavenly; they are greater, better, more magnificent.

**[20:161]** Look at them, moreover, attentively.

**[20:162]** They roll from east to west, they stand not; they are seen with the eyes, not only by man, but even by the beast of the field.

**[20:163]** Pass beyond them too.

**[20:164]** And how, sayest thou, pass beyond the heavenly bodies, seeing that I walk on the earth? Not in the flesh dost thou pass beyond them, but in the mind.

**[20:165]** Away with them too: though they shine ever so much, they are bodies; though they glitter from heaven, they are bodies.

**[20:166]** Come, now that perhaps thou thinkest thou hast not whither to go, after considering all these.

**[20:167]** And whither am I to go, sayest thou, beyond the heavenly bodies; and what am I to pass beyond with the mind? Hast thou considered all these? I have, sayest thou.

**[20:168]** By what means hast thou considered them? Let the being that considers appear in person.

**[20:169]** The being that considers all these, that discriminates, distinguishes, and in a manner weighs them in the balance of wisdom, is really the mind.

**[20:170]** Doubtless, then, better is the mind with which thou hast contemplated all these things, than these things which thou hast contemplated.

**[20:171]** This mind, then, is a spirit, not a body.

**[20:172]** Pass beyond it too.

**[20:173]** And that thou mayest see whither thou art to pass beyond, compare that mind itself, in the first place, with the flesh.

**[20:174]** Heaven forbid that thou shouldest deign so to compare it! Compare it with the brightness of the sun, of the moon, and of the stars; the brightness of the mind is greater.

**[20:175]** Observe, first, the swiftness of the mind; see whether the scintillation of the thinking mind be not more impetuous than the brilliance of the shining sun.

**[20:176]** With the mind thou seest the sun rising.

**[20:177]** How slow is its motion compared with thy mind! What the sun is about to do, thou canst think in a trice.

**[20:178]** It is about to come from the east to the west; to-morrow rises from another quarter.

**[20:179]** Where thy thought has done this, the sun still lags behind, and thou hast traversed the whole journey.

**[20:180]** A great thing, therefore, is the mind.

**[20:181]** But how do I say is? Pass beyond it also.

**[20:182]** For the mind, notwithstanding it be better than every kind of body, is itself changeable.

**[20:183]** Now it knows, now knows not; now forgets, now remembers; now wills, now wills not; now errs, now is right.

**[20:184]** Pass therefore beyond all changeableness; not only beyond all that is seen, but also beyond all that changes.

**[20:185]** For thou hast passed beyond the flesh which is seen; beyond heaven, the sun, moon, and stars, which are seen.

**[20:186]** Pass, too, beyond all that changes.

**[20:187]** For when thou hadst done with those things that are seen, and hadst come to thy mind, there thou didst find the changeableness of  thy mind.

**[20:188]** Is God at all changeable? Pass then, beyond even thy mind.

**[20:189]** Pour out thy soul "above thee," that thou mayest reach unto God, of whom it is said to thee, "Where is thy God?"  13.

**[20:190]** Do not imagine that thou art to do something beyond a man's ability.

**[20:191]** The Evangelist John himself did this.

**[20:192]** He soared beyond the flesh, beyond the earth which he trod, beyond the seas which he looked upon, beyond the air in which the fowls fly, beyond the sun, the moon, the stars, beyond all the spirits unseen, beyond his own mind, by the very reason of his rational soul.

**[20:193]** Soaring beyond all these, pouring out his soul above him, whither did he arrive? What did he see? "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God".

**[20:194]** If, therefore, thou seest no separation in the light, why seekest thou a separation in the work? See God, see His Word inhering to the Word speaking, that the speaker speaks not by syllables, but this his speaking is a shining out in the brightness of wisdom.

**[20:195]** What is said of the Wisdom itself? "It is the radiance of eternal light".

**[20:196]** Observe the radiance of the sun.

**[20:197]** The sun is in the heaven, and spreads out its brightness over all lands and over all seas, and it is simply a corporal light.

**[20:198]** If, indeed, thou canst separate the brightness from the sun, then separate the Word from the Father.

**[20:199]** I am speaking of the sun.

**[20:200]** One small, slender flame of a lamp, which can be extinguished by one breath, spreads its light over all that lies near it: thou seest the light generated by the flame spread out; thou seest its emission, but not a separation.

**[20:201]** Understand, then, beloved brethren, that the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Ghost are inseparably united in themselves; that this Trinity is one God; that all the works of the one God are the works of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.

**[20:202]** All the rest which follows, and which refers to the discourse of our Lord Jesus Christ, now that a discourse is due to you to-morrow also, be present that ye may hear.

**[21:1]** Tractate XXI.

**[21:2]** Chapter V.

**[21:3]** 20–23  1.

**[21:4]** Yesterday, so far as the Lord vouchsafed to bestow, we discussed with what ability we could, and discerned according to our capacity, how the works of the Father and of the Son are inseparable; and how the Father doeth not some, the Son others, but that the Father doeth all things through the Son, as through His Word, of which it is written, "All things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made".

**[21:5]** Let us to-day look at the words that follow.

**[21:6]** And of the same Lord let us pray for mercy, and hope that, if He deem it meet, we may understand what is true; but if we should not be able to do this, that we may not go into what is false.

**[21:7]** For it is better not to know than to go astray; but to know is better than not to know.

**[21:8]** Therefore, before all things, we ought to strive to know.

**[21:9]** Should we be able, to God be thanks; but should we not be able meanwhile to arrive at the truth, let us not go to falsehood.

**[21:10]** For we are bound to consider well what we are, and what we are treating of.

**[21:11]** We are men bearing flesh, walking in this life; and though now begotten again of the seed of the Word of God, yet in Christ renewed in such manner that we are not yet wholly rid of Adam.

**[21:12]** For truly our mortal and corruptible part that weighs down the soul shows itself to be, and manifestly is, of Adam; but what in us is spiritual, and raises up the soul, is of God's gift and of His mercy, who has sent His only Son to partake our death with us, and to lead us to His own immortality.

**[21:13]** The Son we have for our Master, that we may not sin; and for our defender, if we have sinned and have confessed, and been converted; an intercessor for us, if we have desired any good of God; and the bestower of it with the Father, because Father and Son is one God.

**[21:14]** But He was speaking these things as man to men: God concealed, the man manifest, that He might make them gods that are manifest men; and the Son of God made Son of man, that He might make the sons of men sons of God.

**[21:15]** By what skill of His wisdom He doeth this, we perceive in His own words.

**[21:16]** For as a little one He speaks to little ones, but Himself little in such wise that He is also great, and we little, but in Him great.

**[21:17]** He speaks, in  deed as one cherishing and nourishing children at the breast that grow by loving.

**[21:18]** 2.

**[21:19]** He had said, "The Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing".

**[21:20]** We, however, understood it not that the Father doeth something separately, which when the Son seeth, Himself also doeth something of the same kind, after seeing His Father's work; but when He said, "The Son cannot of Himself do anything, but what He seeth the Father doing," we understood it that the Son is wholly of the Father—that His whole substance and His whole power are of the Father that begat Him.

**[21:21]** But just now, when He had said that He doeth in like manner these things which the Father doeth, that we may not understand it to mean that the Father doeth some, the Son others, but that the Son with like power doeth the very same which the Father doeth, whilst the Father doeth through the Son, He went on, and said what we have heard read to-day: "For the Father loveth the Son, and showeth Him all things that Himself doeth".

**[21:22]** Again mortal thought is disturbed.

**[21:23]** The Father showeth to the Son what things Himself doeth; therefore, saith some one, the Father doeth separately, that the Son may be able to see what He doeth.

**[21:24]** Again, there occur to human thought, as it were, two artificers—as, for instance, a carpenter teaching his son his own art, and showing him whatever he doeth, that the son also may be able to do it.

**[21:25]** "Showeth Him," saith He, "all things that Himself doeth".

**[21:26]** Is it therefore so, that whilst He doeth, the Son doeth not, that He may be able to see the Father do? Yet, certainly, "all things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made".

**[21:27]** Hence we see how the Father showeth the Son what He doeth, since the Father doeth nothing but what He doeth through the Son.

**[21:28]** What hath the Father made? He made the world.

**[21:29]** Hath He shown the world, when made, to the Son in such wise, that the Son also should make something like it? Then let us see the world which the Son made.

**[21:30]** Nevertheless, both "all things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made," and also "the world was made by Him".

**[21:31]** If the world was made by Him, and all things were made by Him, and the Father doeth nothing save by the Son, where doth the Father show to the Son what He doeth, if it be not in the Son Himself, through whom He doeth? In what place can the work of the Father be shown to the Son, as though He were doing and sitting outside, and the Son attentively watching the Father's hand how it maketh? Where is that inseparable Trinity? Where the Word, of which it is said that the same is "the power and the wisdom of God"? Where that which the Scripture saith of the same wisdom: "For it is the brightness of the eternal light?" Where what was said of it again: "It powerfully reaches from the end even to the end, and ordereth all things sweetly"? Whatever the Father doeth, He doeth through the Son: through His wisdom and his power He doeth; not from without doth He show to the Son what He may see, but in the Son Himself He showeth Him what He doeth.

**[21:32]** 3.

**[21:33]** What seeth the Father, or rather, what doth the Son see in the Father, that Himself also may do? Perhaps I may be able to speak it, but show me the man who can comprehend it; or perhaps I may be able to think and not speak it; or perhaps I may not be able even to think it.

**[21:34]** For that divinity excels us, as God excels men, as the immortal excels a mortal, as the eternal excels the temporal.

**[21:35]** May He inspire and endow us, and out of that fountain of life deign to bedew and to drop somewhat on our thirst, that we may not be parched in this wilderness! Let us say to Him, Lord, to whom we have learnt to say Father.

**[21:36]** We make bold to say this, because Himself willed it; if only we so live that He may not say to us, "If I am a Father, where is mine honor? if I am Lord, where is my fear?" Let us then say to Him, "Our Father".

**[21:37]** To whom do we say, "Our Father"? To the Father of Christ.

**[21:38]** He, then, who says "Our Father" to the Father of Christ, says to Christ, what else but "Our Brother"? Not, however, as He is the Father of Christ is He in like manner our Father; for Christ never so conjoined us as to make no distinction between Him and us.

**[21:39]** For He is the Son equal to the Father, the eternal Son with the Father, and co-eternal with the Father; but we became sons through the Son, adopted through the Only-begotten.

**[21:40]** Hence was it never heard from the mouth of our Lord Jesus Christ, when speaking to His disciples, that He said of the supreme God His Father, "Our Father;" but He said either "My Father" or "Your Father".

**[21:41]** But He said not "Our Father;" so much so, that in a certain place He used these two expressions: "I go to my God," saith He, "and to your God".

**[21:42]** Why did He not say, "Our God"? Further, He said, "My Father, and your Father;" He said not, "Our Father".

**[21:43]** He so joins as to distinguish, distinguishes so as not to disjoin.

**[21:44]** He wills us to be one in Him, but the Father and Himself one.

**[21:45]** 4.

**[21:46]** How much soever then we may understand, and how much soever we may see, we shall not see as the Son seeth, even when we shall be made equal with the angels.

**[21:47]** For we are something even when we do not see; but what are we when we do not see, other than persons not seeing? And that we may see, we turn to Him whom we may see, and there is formed in us a seeing which was not before, although we were in being.

**[21:48]** For a man is when not seeing; and the same, when he doth see, is called a man seeing.

**[21:49]** For him, then, to see is not the same thing as to be a man; for if it were, he would not be man when not seeing.

**[21:50]** But since he is man when not seeing, and seeks to see what he sees not, he is one who seeks, and who turns to see; and when he has well turned and has seen, he becomes a man seeing, who was before a man not seeing.

**[21:51]** Consequently, to see is to him a thing that comes and goes; it comes to him when he turns to, and leaves him when he turns away.

**[21:52]** Is it thus with the Son? Far be it from us to think so.

**[21:53]** It was never so that He was Son, not seeing, and afterwards was made to see; but to see the Father is to Him the same thing as to be Son.

**[21:54]** For we, by turning away to sin, lose enlightenment; and by turning to God we receive enlightenment.

**[21:55]** For the light by which we are enlightened is one thing; we who are enlightened, another thing.

**[21:56]** But the light itself, by which we are enlightened, neither turns away from itself, nor loses its lucidity, because as light it exists.

**[21:57]** The Father, then, showeth a thing which He doeth to the Son, in such wise that the Son seeth all things in the Father, and is all things in the Father.

**[21:58]** For by seeing He was begotten; and by being begotten He seeth.

**[21:59]** Not, however, that at any time He was not begotten, and afterwards was begotten; nor that at any time He saw not, and afterwards saw.

**[21:60]** But in what consists His seeing, in the same consists His being, in the same His being begotten, in the same His continuing, in the same His unchanging, in the same His abiding without beginning and without end.

**[21:61]** Let us not therefore take it in a carnal sense that the Father sitteth and doeth a work, and showeth it to the Son; and the Son seeth the work that the Father doeth, and doeth another work in another place, or out of other materials.

**[21:62]** For "all things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made".

**[21:63]** The Son is the Word of the Father.

**[21:64]** The Father said nothing which He did not say in the Son.

**[21:65]** For by speaking in the Son what He was about to do through the Son, He begat the Son through whom He made all things.

**[21:66]** 5.

**[21:67]** "And greater works than these will He show Him, that ye may marvel".

**[21:68]** Here again we are embarrassed.

**[21:69]** And who is there that may worthily investigate this so great a secret? But now, in that He has deigned to speak to us, Himself opens it.

**[21:70]** For He would not speak what He would not have us understand; and as He has deigned to speak, without doubt He has excited attention: for does He forsake any whom He has roused to give attentive hearing? We have said that it is not in a temporal sense that the Son knoweth,—that the knowledge of the Son is not one thing, and the Son Himself another; nor one thing His seeing, Himself another; but that the seeing itself is the Son, and the knowledge as well as the wisdom of the Father is the Son; and that that wisdom and seeing is eternal and co-eternal with Him from whom it is; that it is not something that varies by time, nor something produced that was not in being, nor something that vanishes away which did exist.

**[21:71]** What is it, then, that time does in this case, that He should say, "Greater works than these He will show Him"? "He will show," that is, "He is about to show".

**[21:72]** Hath shown is a different thing from will show: hath shown, we say of an act past; will show, of an act future.

**[21:73]** What shall we do here, then, brethren? Behold, He whom we had declared to be co-eternal with the Father, in whom nothing is varied by time, in whom is no moving through spaces either of moments or of places, of whom we had declared that He abides ever with the Father seeing, seeing the Father, and by seeing existing; He, I say, here again mentioning times to us, saith, "He will show Him greater works than these".

**[21:74]** Is He then about to show something to the Son, which the Son doth not as yet know? What, then, do we make of it? How do we understand this? Behold, our Lord Jesus Christ was above, is beneath.

**[21:75]** When was He above? When He said, "What things soever the Father doeth, these same also the Son doeth in like manner".

**[21:76]** Whence know we that He is now beneath? Hence: "Greater works than these He will show Him".

**[21:77]** O Lord Jesus Christ, our Saviour, Word of God, by which all things were made, what is the Father about to show Thee, that as yet Thou knowest not? What of the Father is hid from Thee? What in the Father is hid from Thee, from whom the Father is not hid? What greater works is He about to show Thee? Or greater than what works are they which He is to show Thee? For when He said, "Greater than these," we ought first to understand the works than which are they greater.

**[21:78]** 6.

**[21:79]** Let us again call to mind whence this discourse started.

**[21:80]** It was when that man  who was thirty-eight years in infirmity was healed, and Jesus commanded him, now made whole, to take up his bed and to go to his house.

**[21:81]** For this cause, indeed, the Jews with whom He was speaking were enraged.

**[21:82]** He spoke in words, as to the meaning He was silent; hinted in some measure at the meaning to those who understood, and hid the matter from them that were wroth.

**[21:83]** For this cause, I say, the Jews, being enraged because the Lord did this on the Sabbath, gave occasion to this discourse.

**[21:84]** Therefore let us not hear these things in such wise as if we had forgotten what was said above, but let us look back to that impotent man languishing for thirty-eight years suddenly made whole, while the Jews marvelled and were wroth.

**[21:85]** They sought darkness from the Sabbath more than light from the miracle.

**[21:86]** Speaking then to these, while they are indignant, He saith, "Greater works than these will He show Him".

**[21:87]** "Greater than these:" than which? What ye have seen, that a man, whose infirmity had lasted thirty-eight years, was made whole; greater than these the Father is about to show to the Son.

**[21:88]** What are greater works? He goes on, saying, "For as the Father raiseth the dead, and quickeneth them, so also the Son quickeneth whom He will".

**[21:89]** Clearly these are greater.

**[21:90]** Very much greater is it that a dead man should rise, than that a sick man should recover: these are greater.

**[21:91]** But when is the Father about to show these to the Son? Does the Son not know them? And He who was speaking, did He not know how to raise the dead? Had He yet to learn how to raise the dead to life—He, I say, by whom all things were made? He who caused that we should live, when we were not in being, had He yet to learn how we might be raised to life again? What, then, do His words mean?  7.

**[21:92]** But now He condescends to us, and He who a little before was speaking as God, now begins to speak as man.

**[21:93]** Notwithstanding, the same is man who is God, for God was made man; but was made what He was not, without losing what He was.

**[21:94]** The man therefore was added to the God, that He might be man who was God, but not that He should now henceforth be man and not be God.

**[21:95]** Let us then hear Him also as our brother whom we did hear as our Maker.

**[21:96]** Our Maker, because the Word in the beginning; our Brother, because born of the Virgin Mary: Maker, before Abraham, before Adam, before earth, before heaven, before all things corporeal and spiritual; but Brother, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Judah, of the Israelitish virgin.

**[21:97]** If therefore we know Him who speaks to us as both God and man, let us understand the words of God and of man; for sometimes He speaks to us such things as are applicable to the majesty, sometimes such as are applicable to the humility.

**[21:98]** For the selfsame is high who was made low, that He might make us high who are low.

**[21:99]** What, then, saith He? "The Father will show" to me "greater than these, that ye may marvel".

**[21:100]** To us, therefore, He is about to show, not to Him.

**[21:101]** And since it is to us that the Father is to show, for that reason He said, "that ye may marvel".

**[21:102]** He has, in fact, explained what He meant in saying, "The Father will show" to me.

**[21:103]** Why did He not say, The Father will show to you; but, He will show to the Son? Because also we are members of the Son; and like as what we the members learn, He Himself in a manner learns in His members.

**[21:104]** How doth He learn in us? As He suffers in us.

**[21:105]** Whence may we prove that He suffers in us? From that voice out of heaven, "Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?" Is it not Himself that will sit as Judge in the end of the world, and, setting the just on the right, and the wicked on the left, will say, "Come, ye blessed of my Father, receive the kingdom; for I was hungry, and ye gave me to eat"? And when they shall answer, "Lord, when saw we Thee hungry?" He will say to them, "Since ye gave to one of the least of mine, ye gave to me".

**[21:106]** Let us at this time question Him, and let us say to Him, Lord, when wilt Thou be a learner, seeing Thou teachest all things? Immediately, indeed, He makes answer to us in our faith, When one of the least of mine doth learn, I learn.

**[21:107]** 8.

**[21:108]** Let us rejoice, then, and give thanks that we are made not only Christians, but Christ.

**[21:109]** Do ye understand, brethren, and apprehend the grace of God upon us? Marvel, be glad, we are made Christ.

**[21:110]** For if He is the head, we are the members: the whole man is He and we.

**[21:111]** This is what the Apostle Paul saith: "That we be no longer babes, tossed to and fro, and carried about with every wind of doctrine".

**[21:112]** But above he had said, "Until we all come together into the unity of faith, and to the knowledge of the Son of God, to the perfect man, to the measure of the age of the fullness of Christ".

**[21:113]** The fullness of Christ, then, is head and members.

**[21:114]** Head and members, what is that? Christ and the Church.

**[21:115]** We should indeed be arrogating this to ourselves proudly, if He did not Himself deign to promise it, who saith by the same apostle, "But ye are the body of Christ, and members".

**[21:116]** 9.

**[21:117]** Whenever, then, the Father showeth to Christ's members, He showeth to Christ.

**[21:118]** A certain great but yet real miracle happens.

**[21:119]** There is a showing to Christ of what Christ knew, and it is shown to Christ through Christ.

**[21:120]** A marvelous and great thing it is, but the Scripture so saith.

**[21:121]** Shall we contradict the divine declarations? Shall we not rather understand them, and of His own gift render thanks to Him who freely bestowed it on us? What is this that I said, "is shown to Christ through Christ"? Is shown to the members through the head.

**[21:122]** Lo, look at this in thyself.

**[21:123]** Suppose that with thine eyes shut thou wouldest take up something, thy hand knows not whither to go; and yet thy hand is at any rate thy member, for it is not separated from thy body.

**[21:124]** Open thine eyes, now the hand sees whither it may go; while the head showed, the member followed.

**[21:125]** If, then, there could be found in thyself something such, that thy body showed to thy body, and that through thy body something was shown to thy body, then do not marvel that it is said there is shown to Christ through Christ.

**[21:126]** For the head shows that the members may see, and the head teaches that the members may learn; nevertheless one man, head and members.

**[21:127]** He willed not to separate Himself, but deigned to attach Himself to us.

**[21:128]** Far was He from us, yea, very far.

**[21:129]** What so far apart as the creature and the Creator? What so far apart as God and man? What so far as justice and iniquity? What so far as eternity and mortality? Behold, so far from us was the Word in the beginning, God with God, by whom all things were made.

**[21:130]** How, then, was He made near, that He might be what we are, and we in Him? "The Word was made flesh, and dwelt in (among) us".

**[21:131]** 10.

**[21:132]** This, then, He is about to show us; this He showed to His disciples, who saw Him in the flesh.

**[21:133]** What is this? "As the Father raiseth the dead, and quickeneth them, so also the Son quickeneth whom He will".

**[21:134]** Is it that the Father some, the Son others? Surely all things were made by Him.

**[21:135]** What do we say, my brethren? Christ raised Lazarus; what dead man did the Father raise, that Christ might see how to raise Lazarus? When Christ raised Lazarus, did not the Father raise him? or was it the doing of the Son alone, without the Father? Read ye the passage itself, and see that He invokes the Father that Lazarus may rise again.

**[21:136]** As a man, He calls on the Father; as God, He doeth with the Father.

**[21:137]** Therefore also Lazarus, who rose again, was raised both by the Father and by the Son, in the gift and grace of the Holy Spirit; and that wonderful work the Trinity performed.

**[21:138]** Let us not, therefore, understand this, "As the Father raiseth the dead, and quickeneth them, so also the Son quickeneth whom He will," in such wise as to suppose that some are raised and quickened by the Father, others by the Son; but that the Son raiseth and quickeneth the very same whom the Father raiseth and quickeneth; because "all things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made".

**[21:139]** And to show that He has, though given by the Father, equal power, therefore He saith, "So also the Son quickeneth whom He will," that He might therein show His will; and lest any should say, "The Father raiseth the dead by the Son, but the Father as being powerful, and as having power, the Son as by another's power, as a servant does something, as an angel," He indicated His power when He saith, "So also the Son quickeneth whom He will".

**[21:140]** It is not so that the Father willeth other than the Son; but as the Father and the Son have one substance, so also one will.

**[21:141]** 11.

**[21:142]** And who are these dead whom the Father and the Son quicken? Are they the same of whom we have spoken—Lazarus, or that widow's son, or the ruler of the synagogue's daughter? For we know that these were raised by Christ the Lord.

**[21:143]** It is some other thing that He means to signify to us,—namely, the resurrection of the dead, which we all look for; not that resurrection which certain have had, that the rest might believe.

**[21:144]** For Lazarus rose to die again; we shall rise again to live for ever.

**[21:145]** Is it the Father that effects such a resurrection, or the Son? Nay verily, the Father in the Son.

**[21:146]** Consequently the Son, and the Father in the Son.

**[21:147]** Whence do we prove that He speaks of this resurrection? When He had said, "As the Father raiseth up the dead, and quickeneth them, so also the Son quickeneth whom He will".

**[21:148]** Lest we should understand here that resurrection which He performs for a miracle, not for eternal life, He proceeded, saying, "For the Father judgeth not any man, but all judgment hath He given to the Son".

**[21:149]** What is this? He was speaking of the resurrection of the dead, that "as the Father raiseth the dead, and quickeneth them, so also the Son quickeneth whom He will;" and immediately thereupon added as a reason, concerning the judgment, saying, "for the Father judgeth not any man, but all judgment hath He given to the Son".

**[21:150]** Why said He this, but to indicate that He had spoken of that resurrection of  the dead which will take place in the judgment?  12.

**[21:151]** "For," saith He, "the Father judgeth no man, but all judgment hath He given to the Son".

**[21:152]** A little before we were thinking that the Father doeth something which the Son doeth not, when He said, "The Father loveth the Son, and showeth Him all things that Himself doeth;" as though the Father were doing, and the Son were seeing.

**[21:153]** In this way there was creeping in upon our mind a carnal conception, as if the Father did what the Son did not; but that the Son was looking on while the Father showed what He was doing.

**[21:154]** Then, as the Father was doing what the Son did not, just now we see the Son doing what the Father doeth not.

**[21:155]** How He turns us about, and keeps our mind busy!
