**[26:169]** Thence the bread, thence the drink.

**[26:170]** The rock was Christ in sign; the real Christ is in the Word and in flesh.

**[26:171]** And how did they drink? The rock was smitten twice with a rod; the double smiting signified the two wooden beams of the cross.

**[26:172]** "This, then, is the bread that cometh down from heaven, that if any man eat thereof, he shall not die".

**[26:173]** But this is what belongs to the virtue of the sacrament, not to the visible sacrament; he that eateth within, not without; who eateth in his heart, not who presses with his teeth.

**[26:174]** 13.

**[26:175]** "I am the living bread, which came down from heaven".

**[26:176]** For that reason "living," because I came down from heaven.

**[26:177]** The manna also came down from heaven; but the manna was only a shadow, this is the truth.

**[26:178]** "If any man eat of this bread, he shall live for ever: and the bread that I will give is my flesh, for the life of the world".

**[26:179]** When did flesh comprehend this flesh which He called bread? That is called flesh which flesh does not comprehend, and for that reason all the more flesh does not comprehend it, that it is called flesh.

**[26:180]** For they were terrified at this: they said it was too much for them; they thought it impossible.

**[26:181]** "Is my flesh," saith He, "for the life of the world".

**[26:182]** Believers know the body of Christ, if they neglect not to be the body of Christ.

**[26:183]** Let them become the body of Christ, if they wish to live by the Spirit of Christ.

**[26:184]** None lives by the Spirit of Christ but the body of Christ.

**[26:185]** Understand, my brethren, what I mean to say.

**[26:186]** Thou art a man; thou hast both a spirit and a body.

**[26:187]** I call that a spirit which is called the soul; that whereby it consists that thou art a man, for thou consistest of soul and body.

**[26:188]** And so thou hast an invisible spirit and a visible body.

**[26:189]** Tell me which lives of the other: does thy spirit live of thy body, or thy body of thy spirit? Every man that lives can answer; and he that cannot answer this, I know not whether he lives: what doth every man that lives answer? My body, of course, lives by my spirit.

**[26:190]** Wouldst thou then also live by the Spirit of Christ.

**[26:191]** Be in the body of Christ.

**[26:192]** For surely my body does not live by thy spirit.

**[26:193]** My body lives by my spirit, and thy body by thy spirit.

**[26:194]** The body of Christ cannot live but by the Spirit of Christ.

**[26:195]** It is for this that the Apostle Paul, expounding this bread, says: "One bread," saith he, "we being many are one body".

**[26:196]** O mystery of piety! O sign of unity! O bond of charity! He that would live has where to live, has whence to live.

**[26:197]** Let him draw near, let him believe; let him be embodied, that he may be made to live.

**[26:198]** Let him not shrink from the compact of members; let him not be a rotten member that deserves to be cut off; let him not be a deformed member whereof to be ashamed; let him be a fair, fit, and sound member; let him cleave to the body, live for God by God: now let him labor on earth, that hereafter he may reign in heaven.

**[26:199]** 14.

**[26:200]** The Jews, therefore, strove among themselves, saying, "How can this man give us his flesh to eat?" They strove, and that among themselves, since they understood not, neither wished to take the bread of concord: "for they who eat such bread do not strive with one another; for we being many are one bread, one body".

**[26:201]** And by this bread, "God makes people of one sort to dwell in a house".

**[26:202]** 15.

**[26:203]** But that which they ask, while striving among themselves, namely, how the Lord can give His flesh to be eaten, they do not immediately hear: but further it is said to them, "Verily, verily, I say unto you, except ye eat the flesh of the Son of man, and drink His blood, ye will have no life in you".

**[26:204]** How, indeed, it may be eaten, and what may be the mode of eating this bread, ye are ignorant of; nevertheless, "except ye eat the flesh of the Son of man, and drink His blood, ye will not have life in you".

**[26:205]** He spoke these words, not certainly to corpses, but to living men.

**[26:206]** Whereupon, lest they, understanding it to mean this life, should strive about this thing also, He going on added, "Whoso eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blood, hath eternal life".

**[26:207]** Wherefore, he that eateth not this bread, nor drinketh this blood, hath not this life; for men can have temporal life without that, but they can noways have eternal life.

**[26:208]** He then that eateth not His flesh, nor drinketh His blood, hath no life in him; and he that eateth His flesh, and drinketh His blood, hath life.

**[26:209]** This epithet, eternal, which He used, answers to both.

**[26:210]** It is not so in the case of that food which we take for the purpose of sustaining  this temporal life.

**[26:211]** For he who will not take it shall not live, nor yet shall he who will take it live.

**[26:212]** For very many, even who have taken it, die; it may be by old age, or by disease, or by some other casualty.

**[26:213]** But in this food and drink, that is, in the body and blood of the Lord, it is not so.

**[26:214]** For both he that doth not take it hath no life, and he that doth take it hath life, and that indeed eternal life.

**[26:215]** And thus He would have this meat and drink to be understood as meaning the fellowship of His own body and members, which is the holy Church in his predestinated, and called, and justified, and glorified saints and believers.

**[26:216]** Of these, the first is already effected, namely, predestination; the second and third, that is, the vocation and justification, have taken place, are taking place, and will take place; but the fourth, namely, the glorifying, is at present in hope; but a thing future in realization.

**[26:217]** The sacrament of this thing, namely, of the unity of the body and blood of Christ, is prepared on the Lord's table in some places daily, in some places at certain intervals of days, and from the Lord's table it is taken, by some to life, by some to destruction: but the thing itself, of which it is the sacrament, is for every man to life, for no man to destruction, whosoever shall have been a partaker thereof.

**[26:218]** 16.

**[26:219]** But lest they should suppose that eternal life was promised in this meat and drink in such manner that they who should take it should not even now die in the body, He condescended to meet this thought; for when He had said, "He that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blood, hath eternal life," He forthwith subjoined, "and I will raise him up on the last day".

**[26:220]** That meanwhile, according to the Spirit, he may have eternal life in that rest into which the spirits of the saints are received; but as to the body, he shall not be defrauded of its eternal life, but, on the contrary, he shall have it in the resurrection of the dead at the last day.

**[26:221]** 17.

**[26:222]** "For my flesh," saith He, "is meat indeed, and my blood is drink indeed".

**[26:223]** For whilst by meat and drink men seek to attain to this, neither to hunger nor thirst, there is nothing that truly affords this, except this meat and drink, which doth render them by whom it is taken immortal and incorruptible; that is, the very fellowship of the saints, where will be peace and unity, full and perfect.

**[26:224]** Therefore, indeed, it is, even as men of God understood this before us, that our Lord Jesus Christ has pointed our minds to His body and blood in those things, which from being many are reduced to some one thing.

**[26:225]** For a unity is formed by many grains forming together; and another unity is effected by the clustering together of many berries.

**[26:226]** 18.

**[26:227]** In a word, He now explains how that which He speaks of comes to pass, and what it is to eat His body and to drink His blood.

**[26:228]** "He that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blood, dwelleth in me, and I in him".

**[26:229]** This it is, therefore, for a man to eat that meat and to drink that drink, to dwell in Christ, and to have Christ dwelling in him.

**[26:230]** Consequently, he that dwelleth not in Christ, and in whom Christ dwelleth not, doubtless neither eateth His flesh [spiritually] nor drinketh His blood [although he may press the sacrament of the body and blood of Christ carnally and visibly with his teeth], but rather doth he eat and drink the sacrament of so great a thing to his own judgment, because he, being unclean, has presumed to come to the sacraments of Christ, which no man taketh worthily except he that is pure: of such it is said, "Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God".

**[26:231]** 19.

**[26:232]** "As the living Father hath sent me," saith He, "and I live by the Father; so he that eateth me, even he shall live by me".

**[26:233]** He says not: As I eat the Father, and live by the Father; so he that eateth me, the same shall live by me.

**[26:234]** For the Son, who was begotten equal, does not become better by participation of the Father; just as we are made better by participation of the Son, through the unity of His body and blood, which thing that eating and drinking signifies.

**[26:235]** We live then by Him, by eating Him; that is, by receiving Himself as the eternal life, which we did not have from ourselves.

**[26:236]** Himself, however, lives by the Father, being sent by Him, because "He emptied Himself, being made obedient even unto the death of the cross".

**[26:237]** For if we take this declaration, "I live by the Father," according to that which He says in another place, "The Father is greater than I;" just as we, too, live by Him who is greater than we; this results from His being sent.

**[26:238]** The sending is in fact the emptying of Himself, and His taking upon Him the form of a servant: and this is rightly understood, while also the Son's equality of nature with the Father is preserved.

**[26:239]** For the Father is greater than the Son as man, but He has the Son as God equal,—whilst the same is both God and man, Son of God and Son of man, one Christ Jesus.

**[26:240]** To this effect, if these words are rightly understood, He spoke thus: "As the living Father hath sent me, and I live by the Father; so he that eateth me, even he shall live by me:" just as if He were to say, My emptying of myself (in that He  sent me) effected that I should live by the Father; that is, should refer my life to Him as the greater; but that any should live by me is effected by that participation in which he eats me.

**[26:241]** Therefore, I being humbled, do live by the Father, man being raised up, liveth by me.

**[26:242]** But if it was said, "I live by the Father," so as to mean, that He is of the Father, not the Father of Him, it was said without detriment to His equality.

**[26:243]** And yet further, by saying, "And he that eateth me, even he shall live by me," He did not signify that His own equality was the same as our equality, but He thereby showed the grace of the Mediator.

**[26:244]** 20.

**[26:245]** "This is the bread that cometh down from heaven;" that by eating it we may live, since we cannot have eternal life from ourselves.

**[26:246]** "Not," saith He, "as your fathers did eat manna, and are dead: he that eateth this bread shall live forever".

**[26:247]** That those fathers are dead, He would have to be understood as meaning, that they do not live forever.

**[26:248]** For even they who eat Christ shall certainly die temporally; but they live forever, because Christ is eternal life.

**[27:1]** Tractate XXVII.

**[27:2]** Chapter VI.

**[27:3]** 60–72  1.

**[27:4]** We have just heard out of the Gospel the words of the Lord which follow the former discourse.

**[27:5]** From these a discourse is due to your ears and minds, and it is not unseasonable to-day; for it is concerning the body of the Lord which He said that He gave to be eaten for eternal life.

**[27:6]** And He explained the mode of this bestowal and gift of His, in what manner He gave His flesh to eat, saying, "He that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blood, dwelleth in me, and I in him".

**[27:7]** The proof that a man has eaten and drank is this, if he abides and is abode in, if he dwells and is dwelt in, if he adheres so as not to be deserted.

**[27:8]** This, then, He has taught us, and admonished us in mystical words that we may be in His body, in His members under Himself as head, eating His flesh, not abandoning our unity with Him.

**[27:9]** But most of those who were present, by not understanding Him, were offended; for in hearing these things, they thought only of flesh, that which themselves were.

**[27:10]** But the apostle says, and says what is true, "To be carnally-minded is death".

**[27:11]** The Lord gives us His flesh to eat, and yet to understand it according to the flesh is death; while yet He says of His flesh, that therein is eternal life.

**[27:12]** Therefore we ought not to understand the flesh carnally.

**[27:13]** As in these words that follow:  2.

**[27:14]** "Many therefore," not of His enemies, but "of His disciples, when they had heard this, said, This is a hard saying; who can hear it?" If His disciples accounted this saying hard, what must His enemies have thought? And yet so it behoved that to be said which should not be understood by all.

**[27:15]** The secret of God ought to make men eagerly attentive, not hostile.

**[27:16]** But these men quickly departed from Him, while the Lord said such things: they did not believe Him to be saying something great, and covering some grace by these words; they understood just according to their wishes, and in the manner of men, that Jesus was able, or was determined upon this, namely, to distribute the flesh with which the Word was clothed, piecemeal, as it were, to those that believe on Him.

**[27:17]** "This," say they, "is a hard saying; who can hear it?"  3.

**[27:18]** "But Jesus, knowing in Himself that His disciples murmured at it,"—for they so said these things with themselves that they might not be heard by Him: but He who knew them in themselves, hearing within Himself,—answered and said, "This offends you;" because I said, I give you my flesh to eat, and my blood to drink, this forsooth offends you.

**[27:19]** "Then what if ye shall see the Son of man ascending where He was before?" What is this? Did He hereby solve the question that perplexed them? Did He hereby uncover the source of their offense? He did clearly, if only they understood.

**[27:20]** For they supposed that He was going to deal out His body to them; but He said that He was to ascend into heaven, of course, whole: "When ye shall see the Son of man ascending where He was before;" certainly then, at least, you will see that not in the manner you suppose does He dispense His body; certainly then, at least, you will understand that His grace is not consumed by tooth-biting.

**[27:21]** 4.

**[27:22]** And He said, "It is the Spirit that quickeneth; the flesh profiteth nothing".

**[27:23]** Before we expound this, as the Lord grants us, that other must not be negligently passed over, where He says, "Then what if ye shall see the Son of man ascending where He was before?" For Christ is the Son of man, of the Virgin Mary.

**[27:24]** Therefore Son of man He began to be here on earth, where He took flesh from the earth.

**[27:25]** For which cause it was said prophetically, "Truth is sprung from the earth".

**[27:26]** Then what does He mean when He says, "When ye shall see the Son of man ascending where He was before"? For there had been no question if He had spoken thus: "If ye shall see the Son of God ascending where He was before".

**[27:27]** But since He said, "The Son of man ascending where He was before," surely the Son of man was not in heaven before the time when He began to have a being on earth? Here, indeed, He said, "where He was before," just as if He were not there at this time when He spoke these words.

**[27:28]** But in another place He says, "No man has ascended into heaven but He that came down from heaven, the Son of man who is in heaven".

**[27:29]** He said not "was," but, saith He, "the Son of man who is in heaven".

**[27:30]** He was speaking on earth, and He declared Himself to be in heaven.

**[27:31]** And yet He did not speak thus: "No man hath ascended into heaven but He that came down from heaven," the Son of God, "who is in heaven".

**[27:32]** Whither tends it, but to make us understand that which even in the former discourse I commended to your minds, my beloved, that Christ, both God and man, is one person, not two persons, lest our faith be not a trinity, but a quaternity? Christ, therefore, is one; the Word, soul and flesh, one Christ; the Son of God and Son of man, one Christ; Son of God always, Son of man in time, yet one Christ in regard to unity of person.

**[27:33]** In heaven He was when He spoke on earth.

**[27:34]** He was Son of man in heaven in that manner in which He was Son of God on earth; Son of God on earth in the flesh which He took, Son of man in heaven in the unity of person.

**[27:35]** 5.

**[27:36]** What is it, then, that He adds? "It is the Spirit that quickeneth; the flesh profiteth nothing".

**[27:37]** Let us say to Him (for He permits us, not contradicting Him, but desiring to know), O Lord, good Master, in what way does the flesh profit nothing, whilst Thou hast said, "Except a man eat my flesh, and drink my blood, he shall not have life in him?" Or does life profit nothing? And why are we what we are, but that we may have eternal life, which Thou dost promise by Thy flesh? Then what means "the flesh profiteth nothing"? It profiteth nothing, but only in the manner in which they understood it.

**[27:38]** They indeed understood the flesh, just as when cut to pieces in a carcass, or sold in the shambles; not as when it is quickened by the Spirit.

**[27:39]** Wherefore it is said that "the flesh profiteth nothing," in the same manner as it is said that "knowledge puffeth up".

**[27:40]** Then, ought we at once to hate knowledge? Far from it! And what means "Knowledge puffeth up"? Knowledge alone, without charity.

**[27:41]** Therefore he added, "but charity edifieth".

**[27:42]** Therefore add thou to knowledge charity, and knowledge will be profitable, not by itself, but through charity.

**[27:43]** So also here, "the flesh profiteth nothing," only when alone.

**[27:44]** Let the Spirit be added to the flesh, as charity is added to knowledge, and it profiteth very much.

**[27:45]** For if the flesh profited nothing, the Word would not be made flesh to dwell among us.

**[27:46]** If through the flesh Christ has greatly profited us, does the flesh profit nothing? But it is by the flesh that the Spirit has done somewhat for our salvation.

**[27:47]** Flesh was a vessel; consider what it held, not what it was.

**[27:48]** The apostles were sent forth; did their flesh profit us nothing? If the apostles' flesh profited us, could it be that the Lord's flesh should have profited us nothing? For how should the sound of the Word come to us except by the voice of the flesh? Whence should writing come to us? All these are operations of the flesh, but only when the spirit moves it, as if it were its organ.

**[27:49]** Therefore "it is the Spirit that quickeneth; the flesh profiteth nothing," as they understood the flesh, but not so do I give my flesh to be eaten.

**[27:50]** 6.

**[27:51]** Hence "the words," saith He, "which I have spoken to you are Spirit and life".

**[27:52]** For we have said, brethren, that this is what the Lord had taught us by the eating of His flesh and drinking of His blood, that we should abide in Him and He in us.

**[27:53]** But we abide in Him when we are His members, and He abides in us when we are His temple.

**[27:54]** But that we may be His members, unity joins us together.

**[27:55]** And what but love can effect that unity should join us together? And the love of God, whence is it? Ask the apostle: "The love of God," saith he, "is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit which is given to us".

**[27:56]** Therefore "it is the Spirit that quickeneth," for it is the Spirit that makes living members.

**[27:57]** Nor does the Spirit make  any members to be living except such as it finds in the body, which also the Spirit itself quickens.

**[27:58]** For the Spirit which is in thee, O man, by which it consists that thou art a man, does it quicken a member which it finds separated from thy flesh? I call thy soul thy spirit.

**[27:59]** Thy soul quickeneth only the members which are in thy flesh; if thou takest one away, it is no longer quickened by thy soul, because it is not joined to the unity of thy body.

**[27:60]** These things are said to make us love unity and fear separation.

**[27:61]** For there is nothing that a Christian ought to dread so much as to be separated from Christ's body.

**[27:62]** For if he is separated from Christ's body, he is not a member of Christ; if he is not a member of Christ, he is not quickened by the Spirit of Christ.

**[27:63]** "But if any man," saith the apostle, "have not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of His".

**[27:64]** "It is the Spirit," then, "that quickeneth; the flesh profiteth nothing.

**[27:65]** The words that I have spoken to you are spirit and life".

**[27:66]** What means "are spirit and life"? They are to be understood spiritually.

**[27:67]** Hast thou understood spiritually? "They are spirit and life".

**[27:68]** Hast thou understood carnally? So also "are they spirit and life," but are not so to thee.

**[27:69]** 7.

**[27:70]** "But," saith He, "there are some among you that believe not".

**[27:71]** He said not, There are some among you that understand not; but He told the cause why they understand not.

**[27:72]** "There are some among you that believe not," and therefore they understand not, because they believe not.

**[27:73]** For the prophet has said, "If ye believe not, ye shall not understand".

**[27:74]** We are united by faith, quickened by understanding.

**[27:75]** Let us first adhere to Him through faith, that there may be that which may be quickened by understanding.

**[27:76]** For he who adheres not resists; he that resists believes not.

**[27:77]** And how can he that resists be quickened? He is an adversary to the ray of light by which he should be penetrated: he turns not away his eye, but shuts his mind.

**[27:78]** "There are," then, "some who believe not".

**[27:79]** Let them believe and open, let them open and be illumined.

**[27:80]** "For Jesus knew from the beginning who they were that believed, and who should betray Him".

**[27:81]** For Judas also was there.

**[27:82]** Some indeed, were offended; but he remained to watch his opportunity, not to understand.

**[27:83]** And because he remained for that purpose, the Lord kept not silence concerning him.

**[27:84]** He described him not by name, but neither was He silent about him; that all might fear though only one should perish.

**[27:85]** But after He spoke, and distinguished those that believe from those that believe not, He clearly showed the cause why they believed not.

**[27:86]** "Therefore I said unto you," saith He, "that no man can come unto me except it were given to him of my Father".

**[27:87]** Hence to believe is also given to us; for certainly to believe is something.

**[27:88]** And if it is something great, rejoice that thou hast believed, yet be not lifted up; for "What hast thou that thou didst not receive?"  8.

**[27:89]** "From that time many of His disciples went back, and walked no more with Him".

**[27:90]** Went back, but after Satan, not after Christ.

**[27:91]** For our Lord Christ once addressed Peter as Satan, rather because he wished to precede his Lord, and to give counsel that He should not die, He who had come to die, that we might not die for ever; and He says to him, "Get thee behind me, Satan; for thou savorest not the things that be of God, but the things that be of men".

**[27:92]** He did not drive him back to go after Satan, and so called him Satan; but He made him go behind Himself, that by walking after his Lord he should not be a Satan.

**[27:93]** But these went back in the same manner as the apostle says of certain women: "For some are turned back after Satan".

**[27:94]** They walked not further with Him.

**[27:95]** Behold, cut off from the body, for perhaps they were not in the body, they have lost life.

**[27:96]** They must be reckoned among the unbelieving, notwithstanding they were called disciples.

**[27:97]** Not a few, but "many went back".

**[27:98]** This happened, it may be, for our consolation.

**[27:99]** For sometimes it happens that a man may declare the truth, and that what he says may not be understood, and so they that hear it are offended and go away.

**[27:100]** Now the man regrets that he had spoken that truth, and he says to himself, "I ought not to have spoken so, I ought not to have said this".

**[27:101]** Behold; it happened to the Lord: He spoke, and lost many; He remained with few.

**[27:102]** But yet He was not troubled, because He knew from the beginning who they were that believed and that believed not.

**[27:103]** If it happen to us, we are sorely perplexed.

**[27:104]** Let us find comfort in the Lord, and yet let us speak words with prudence.

**[27:105]** 9.

**[27:106]** And now addressing the few that remained: "Then said Jesus to the twelve" (namely, those twelve who remained), "Will ye also," said He, "go away?" Not even Judas departed.

**[27:107]** But it was already manifest to the Lord why he remained: to us he was made manifest afterwards.

**[27:108]** Peter answered in behalf of all, one for many, unity for the  collective whole: "Then Simon Peter answered Him, Lord, to whom shall we go?" Thou drivest us from Thee; give us Thy other self.

**[27:109]** "To whom shall we go?" If we abandon Thee, to whom shall we go? "Thou hast the words of eternal life".

**[27:110]** See how Peter, by the gift of God and the renewal of the Holy Spirit, understood Him.

**[27:111]** How other than because he believed? "Thou hast the words of eternal life".

**[27:112]** For Thou hast eternal life in the ministration of Thy body and blood.

**[27:113]** "And we have believed and have known".

**[27:114]** Not have known and believed, but "believed and known".

**[27:115]** For we believed in order to know; for if we wanted to know first, and then to believe, we should not be able either to know or to believe.

**[27:116]** What have we believed and known? "That Thou art Christ, the Son of God;" that is, that Thou art that very eternal life, and that Thou givest in Thy flesh and blood only that which Thou art.

**[27:117]** 10.

**[27:118]** Then said the Lord Jesus: "Have not I chosen you twelve, and one of you is a devil?" Therefore, should He have said, "I have chosen eleven:" or is a devil also chosen, and among the elect? Persons are wont to be called "elect" by way of praise: or was man elected because some great good was done by him, without his will and knowledge? This belongs peculiarly to God; the contrary is characteristic of the wicked.

**[27:119]** For as wicked men make a bad use of the good works of God; so, on the contrary, God makes a good use of the evil works of wicked men.

**[27:120]** How good it is that the members of the body are, as they can be disposed only by God, their author and framer! Nevertheless what evil use doth wantonness make of the eyes? What ill use doth falsehood make of the tongue? Does not the false witness first both slay his own soul with his tongue, and then, after he has destroyed himself, endeavor to injure another? He makes an ill use of the tongue, but the tongue is not therefore an evil thing; the tongue is God's work, but iniquity makes an ill use of that good work of God.

**[27:121]** How do they use their feet who run into crimes? How do murderers employ their hands? And what ill use do wicked men make of those good creatures of God that lie outside of them? With gold they corrupt judgment and oppress the innocent.

**[27:122]** Bad men make a bad use of the very light; for by evil living they employ even the very light with which they see into the service of their villanies.

**[27:123]** A bad man, when going to do a bad deed, wishes the light to shine for him, lest he stumble; he who has already stumbled and fallen within; that which he is afraid of in his body has already befallen him in his heart.

**[27:124]** Hence, to avoid the tediousness of running through them separately, a bad man makes a bad use of all the good creatures of God: a good man, on the contrary, makes a good use of the evil deeds of wicked men.

**[27:125]** And what is so good as the one God? Since, indeed, the Lord Himself said, "There is none good, but the one God".

**[27:126]** By how much He is better, then, by so much the better use He makes of our evil deeds.

**[27:127]** What worse than Judas? Among all that adhered to the Master, among the twelve, to him was committed the common purse; to him was allotted the dispensing for the poor.

**[27:128]** Unthankful for so great a favor, so great an honor, he took the money, and lost righteousness: being dead, he betrayed life: Him whom he followed as a disciple, he persecuted as an enemy.

**[27:129]** All this evil was Judas's; but the Lord employed his evil for good.

**[27:130]** He endured to be betrayed, to redeem us.

**[27:131]** Behold, Judas's evil was turned to good.

**[27:132]** How many martyrs has Satan persecuted! If Satan left off persecuting, we should not to-day be celebrating the very glorious crown of Saint Laurence.

**[27:133]** If then God employs the evil works of the devil himself for good, what the bad man effects, by making a bad use, is to hurt himself, not to contradict the goodness of God.

**[27:134]** The Master makes use of that man.

**[27:135]** And if He knew not how to make use of him, the Master contriver would not have permitted him to be.

**[27:136]** Therefore, He saith, "One of you is a devil," whilst I have chosen you twelve.

**[27:137]** This saying, "I have chosen you twelve," may be understood in this way, that twelve is a sacred number.

**[27:138]** For the honor of that number was not taken away because one was lost, for another was chosen into the place of the one that perished.

**[27:139]** The number remained a sacred number, a number containing twelve: because they were to make known the Trinity throughout the whole world, that is, throughout the four quarters of the world.

**[27:140]** That is the reason of the three times four.

**[27:141]** Judas, then only cut himself off, not profaned the number twelve: he abandoned his Teacher, for God appointed a successor to take his place.

**[27:142]** 11.

**[27:143]** All this that the Lord spoke concerning His flesh and blood;—and in the grace of that distribution He promised us eternal life, and that He meant those that eat His flesh and drink His blood to be understood, from the fact of their abiding in Him and He in them; and that they understood not who believed not; and that they were offended through their understanding spiritual things  in a carnal sense; and that, while these were offended and perished, the Lord was present for the consolation of the disciples who remained, for proving whom He asked, "Will ye also go away?" that the reply of their steadfastness might be known to us, for He knew that they remained with Him;—let all this, then, avail us to this end, most beloved, that we eat not the flesh and blood of Christ merely in the sacrament, as many evil men do, but that we eat and drink to the participation of the Spirit, that we abide as members in the Lord's body, to be quickened by His Spirit, and that we be not offended, even if many do now with us eat and drink the sacraments in a temporal manner, who shall in the end have eternal torments.

**[27:144]** For at present Christ's body is as it were mixed on the threshing-floor: "But the Lord knoweth them that are His".

**[27:145]** If thou knowest what thou threshest, that the substance is there hidden, that the threshing has not consumed what the winnowing has purged; certain are we, brethren, that all of us who are in the Lord's body, and abide in Him, that He also may abide in us, have of necessity to live among evil men in this world even unto the end.

**[27:146]** I do not say among those evil men who blaspheme Christ; for there are now few found who blaspheme with the tongue, but many who do so by their life.

**[27:147]** Among those, then, we must necessarily live even unto the end.

**[27:148]** 12.

**[27:149]** But what is this that He saith: "He that abideth in me, and I in him"? What, but that which the martyrs heard: "He that persevereth unto the end, the same shall be saved"? How did Saint Laurence, whose feast we celebrate to-day, abide in Him? He abode even to temptation, abode even to tyrannical questioning, abode even to bitterest threatening, abode even to destruction;—that were a trifle, abode even to savage torture.

**[27:150]** For he was not put to death quickly, but tormented in the fire: he was allowed to live a long time; nay, not allowed to live a long time, but forced to die a slow, lingering death.

**[27:151]** Then, in that lingering death, in those torments, because he had well eaten and well drunk, as one who had feasted on that meat, as one intoxicated with that cup, he felt not the torments.

**[27:152]** For He was there who said, "It is the Spirit that quickeneth".

**[27:153]** For the flesh indeed was burning, but the Spirit was quickening the soul.

**[27:154]** He shrunk not back, and he mounted into the kingdom.

**[27:155]** But the holy martyr Xystus, whose day we celebrated five days ago, had said to him, "Mourn not, my son;" for Xystus was a bishop, he was a deacon.

**[27:156]** "Mourn not," said he; "thou shall follow me after three days".

**[27:157]** He said three days, meaning the interval between the day of Saint Xystus's suffering and that of Saint Laurence's suffering, which falls on to-day.

**[27:158]** Three days is the interval.

**[27:159]** What comfort! He says not, "Mourn not, my son; the persecution will cease, and thou wilt be safe;" but, "do not mourn: whither I precede thou shalt follow; nor shall thy pursuit be deferred: three days will be the interval, and thou shalt be with me".

**[27:160]** He accepted the oracle, vanquished the devil, and attained to the triumph.

**[28:1]** Tractate XXVIII.

**[28:2]** Chapter VII.

**[28:3]** 1–13  1.

**[28:4]** In this chapter of the Gospel, brethren, our Lord Jesus Christ has most especially commended Himself to our faith in respect of His humanity.

**[28:5]** For indeed He always keeps in view, both in His words and deeds, that He should be believed to be God and man: God who made us, man who sought us; with the Father, always God; with us, man in time.

**[28:6]** For He would not have sought man whom He had made if Himself had not become that which He had made.

**[28:7]** But remember this, and do not let it slip from your hearts, that Christ became man in such manner that He ceased not to be God.

**[28:8]** While remaining God, He who made man took manhood.

**[28:9]** While, therefore, as man He concealed Himself, He must not be thought to have lost His power, but only to have offered an example to our infirmity.

**[28:10]** For He was detained when He willed to be, and He was put to death when he willed to be.

**[28:11]** But since there were to be His members, that is, His faithful ones, who would not have that power which He, our God, had; by His being hid, by His con  cealing Himself as if He would not be put to death, He indicated that His members would do this, in which members He Himself in fact was.

**[28:12]** For Christ is not simply in the head and not in the body, but Christ whole is in the head and body.

**[28:13]** What, therefore, His members are, that He is; but what He is, it does not necessarily follow that His members are.

**[28:14]** For if His members were not Himself, He would not have said, "Saul, why persecutest thou me?" For Saul was not persecuting Himself on earth, but His members, namely, His believers.

**[28:15]** He would not, however, say, my saints, my servants, or, in short, my brethren, which is more honorable; but, me, that is, my members, whose head I am.

**[28:16]** 2.

**[28:17]** With these preliminary remarks, I think that we shall not have to labor much for the meaning in this chapter; for that is often betokened in the head which was to be in the body.

**[28:18]** "After these things," saith he, "Jesus walked in Galilee: for He would not walk in Judea, because the Jews sought to kill Him".

**[28:19]** This is what I have said; He offered an example to our infirmity.

**[28:20]** He had not lost power, but He was comforting our weakness.

**[28:21]** For it would happen, as I have said, that some believer in Him would retreat into concealment, lest he should be found by the persecutors; and lest the concealment should be objected to him as a crime, that occurred first in the head, which should afterwards be confirmed in the member.

**[28:22]** For it is said, "He would not walk in Judea, because the Jews sought to kill Him," just as if Christ were not able both to walk among the Jews, and not be killed by them.

**[28:23]** For He manifested this power when He willed; for when they would lay hold of Him, as He was now about to suffer, "He said to them, Whom seek ye? They answered, Jesus.

**[28:24]** Then, said He, I am He," not concealing, but manifesting Himself.

**[28:25]** That manifestation, however, they did not withstand, but "going backwards, they fell to the ground".

**[28:26]** And yet, because He had come to suffer, they rose up, laid hold of Him, led Him away to the judge, and slew Him.

**[28:27]** But what was it they did? That which a certain scripture says: "The earth was delivered into the hands of the ungodly".

**[28:28]** The flesh was given into the power of the Jews; and this that thereby the bag, as it were, might be rent asunder, whence our purchase-price might run out.

**[28:29]** 3.

**[28:30]** "Now the Jews' feast of tabernacles was at hand".

**[28:31]** What the feast of tabernacles is, they who read the Scriptures know.

**[28:32]** They used on the holy day to make tabernacles, in likeness of the tabernacles in which they dwelt while they sojourned in the wilderness, after being led out of Egypt.

**[28:33]** This was a holy day, a great solemnity.

**[28:34]** The Jews were celebrating this, as being mindful of the Lord's benefits—they who were about to kill the Lord.

**[28:35]** On this holy day, then (for there were several holy days; but it was called a holy day with the Jews, though it was not one day, but several), "His brethren" spoke to the Lord Christ.

**[28:36]** Understand the phrase, "His brethren," as you know it must be taken, for it is not a new thing you hear.

**[28:37]** The blood relations of the Virgin Mary used to be called the Lord's brethren.

**[28:38]** For it was of the usage of Scripture to call blood relations and all other near kindred by the term brethren, which is foreign to our usage, and not within our manner of speech.

**[28:39]** For who would call an uncle or a sister's son "brother"? Yet the Scripture calls relatives of this kind "brothers".

**[28:40]** For Abraham and Lot are called brothers, while Abraham was Lot's uncle.

**[28:41]** Laban and Jacob are called brothers, while Laban was Jacob's uncle.

**[28:42]** When, therefore, you hear of the Lord's brethren, consider them the blood relations of Mary, who did not a second time bear children.

**[28:43]** For, as in the sepulchre, where the Lord's body was laid, neither before nor after did any dead lie; so, likewise, Mary's womb, neither before nor after conceived anything mortal.

**[28:44]** 4.

**[28:45]** We have said who the brethren were, let us hear what they said: "Pass over hence, and go into Judea, that thy disciples also may see thy work which thou doest".

**[28:46]** The Lord's works were not hid from the disciples, but to these men they were not apparent.

**[28:47]** They might have Christ for a kinsman, but through that very relationship they disdained to believe on Him.

**[28:48]** It is told us in the Gospel; for we dare not hold this as a mere opinion, you have just now heard it.

**[28:49]** They go on advising Him: "For no man doeth anything in secret, and he himself seeketh to be known openly: if thou do these things, show thyself to the world".

**[28:50]** And directly after it says: "For neither did His brethren believe in Him".

**[28:51]** Why did they not believe in Him? Because they sought human glory.

**[28:52]** For as to what His brethren appear to advise Him, they consult for His glory.

**[28:53]** Thou doest marvellous works, make thyself known; that is, appear to all, that thou mayest be praised by all.

**[28:54]** The flesh spoke to the flesh; but the flesh without God, to the flesh with God.

**[28:55]** It was the wisdom of the flesh speak  ing to the Word which became flesh and dwelt among us.

**[28:56]** 5.

**[28:57]** What did the Lord answer to these things? Then saith Jesus to them: "My time is not yet come; but your time is always ready".

**[28:58]** What is this? Had not Christ's time yet come? Why then was Christ come, if His time had not yet come? Have we not heard the apostle say, "But when the fullness of time came, God sent His Son"? If, therefore, He was sent in the fullness of time, He was sent when He ought to be sent, He came when it behoved that He should come.

**[28:59]** What means then, "My time is not yet come"? Understand, brethren, with what intention they spoke, when they appeared to advise Him as their brother.

**[28:60]** They were giving Him counsel to pursue glory; as advising in a worldly manner and with an earthly disposition, that He should not be unknown to fame, nor hide Himself in obscurity.

**[28:61]** This is what the Lord says in answer to those who were giving Him counsel of glory, "My time is not yet come;"—the time of my glory is not yet come.

**[28:62]** See how profound it is: they were advising Him as to glory; but He would have loftiness preceded by humility, and willed to prepare the way to elevation itself through humility.

**[28:63]** For those disciples, too, were of course seeking glory who wished to sit, one at His right hand and the other at His left: they thought only of the goal, and saw not by what way it must be reached; the Lord recalled them to the way, that they might come to their fatherland in due order.

**[28:64]** For the fatherland is on high, the way thither lies low.

**[28:65]** That land is the life of Christ, the way is Christ's death; that land is the habitation of Christ, the way is Christ's suffering.

**[28:66]** He that refuses the way, why seeks he the fatherland? In a word, to these also, while seeking elevation, He gave this answer: "Can ye drink the cup which I am about to drink?"  Behold the way by which you must come to that height which you desire.

**[28:67]** The cup He made mention of was indeed that of His humility and suffering.

**[28:68]** 6.

**[28:69]** Therefore also here: "My time is not yet come; but your time," that is the glory of the world, "is always ready".

**[28:70]** This is the time of which Christ, that is the body of Christ, speaks in prophecy: "When I shall have received the fit time, I will judge righteously".

**[28:71]** For at present it is not the time of judging, but of tolerating the wicked.

**[28:72]** Therefore, let the body of Christ bear at present, and tolerate the wickedness of evil livers.

**[28:73]** Let it, however, have righteousness now, for by righteousness it shall come to judgment.

**[28:74]** And what saith the Holy Scripture in the psalm to the members,—namely, that tolerate the wickedness of this world? "The Lord will not cast off His people".

**[28:75]** For, in fact, His people labors among the unworthy, among the unrighteous, among blasphemers, among murmurers, detractors, persecutors, and, if they are allowed, destroyers.

**[28:76]** Yes, it labors; but "the Lord will not cast off His people, and He will not forsake His inheritance until justice is turned into judgment".

**[28:77]** "Until the justice," which is now in His saints, "be turned into judgment;" when that shall be fulfilled which was said to them, "Ye shall sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

**[28:78]** The apostle had righteousness, but not yet that judgment of which he says, "Know ye not that we shall judge angels?" Be it now, therefore, the time for living rightly; the time for judging them that have lived ill shall be hereafter.

**[28:79]** "Until righteousness," saith he, "is turned into judgment".

**[28:80]** The time of judgment will be that of which the Lord has here said, "My time is not yet come".

**[28:81]** For there will be a time of glory, when He who came in humility will come in loftiness; He who came to be judged will come to judge; He who came to be slain by the dead will come to judge the quick and the dead.

**[28:82]** "God," saith the psalm, "will come manifest, our God, and He will not be silent".

**[28:83]** What is "shall come manifest"? Because He came concealed.

**[28:84]** Then He will not be silent; for when He came concealed, "He was led as a sheep to the slaughter; and as a lamb before its shearer, He opened not His mouth".

**[28:85]** He shall come, and shall not keep silence.

**[28:86]** "I was silent," saith He, "shall I always be silent?"  7.

**[28:87]** But what is necessary at the present time for those who have righteousness? That which is read in that psalm: "Until righteousness is turned into judgment, and they that have it are upright of heart".

**[28:88]** You ask, perhaps, who are the upright in heart? We find in Scripture those to be upright in heart who bear the evils of the world, and do not accuse God.

**[28:89]** See, brethren, an uncommon thing is that which I speak of.

**[28:90]** For I know not how it is that, when any evil befalls a man, he runs to accuse God, when he ought to accuse himself.

**[28:91]** When thou gettest any good, thou praisest thyself; when thou sufferest any evil, thou accusest God.

**[28:92]** This is then the crooked heart, not the upright.

**[28:93]** When thou art cured of this distorting and  perversity, what thou didst use to do will be turned into the contrary.

**[28:94]** For what didst thou use to do before? Thou didst praise thyself in the good things of God, and didst accuse God in thine own evil things; with thy heart converted and made right, thou wilt praise God in His good things, and accuse thyself in thy own evil things.

**[28:95]** These are the upright in heart.

**[28:96]** In short, that man, who was not yet right in heart when the success of the wicked and the distress of the good grieved him, says, when he is corrected: "How good is the God of Israel to the upright in heart! But as for me," when I was not right in heart, "my feet were almost gone; my steps had well-nigh slipped".

**[28:97]** Why? "Because I was envious at sinners, beholding the peace of sinners".

**[28:98]** I saw, saith he, the wicked prosperous, and I was displeased at God; for I did wish that God should not permit the wicked to be happy.

**[28:99]** Let man understand: God never does permit this; but a bad man is thought to be happy, for this reason, because men are ignorant of what happiness is.

**[28:100]** Let us then be right in heart: the time of our glory is not yet come.

**[28:101]** Let it be told to the lovers of this world, such as the brethren of the Lord were, "your time is always ready;" our time "is not yet come".

**[28:102]** For let us, too, dare to say this.

**[28:103]** And since we are the body of our Lord Jesus Christ, since we are His members, since we joyfully acknowledge our head, let us say it without hesitation; since, for our sakes, He deigned also Himself to say this.

**[28:104]** And when the lovers of this world revile us, let us say to them, "Your time is always ready; our time is not yet come".

**[28:105]** For the apostle has said to us, "For ye are dead, and your life is hid with Christ in God".

**[28:106]** When will our time come? "When Christ," saith he, "your life shall appear, then shall ye also appear with Him in glory".

**[28:107]** 8.

**[28:108]** What said He further? "The world cannot hate you".

**[28:109]** What is this, but, The world cannot hate its lovers, the false witnesses? For you call the things that are evil, good; and the things that are good, evil.

**[28:110]** "But me it hateth, because I bear witness concerning it, that its works are evil.

**[28:111]** Go ye up to this feast".

**[28:112]** What means "to this"? Where ye seek human glory.

**[28:113]** What means "to this"? Where ye wish to prolong carnal joys, not to meditate on eternal joys.

**[28:114]** "I go not up to this feast, because my time is not yet full come".

**[28:115]** On this feast-day you seek human glory; but my time, that is, the time of my glory, is not yet come.

**[28:116]** That will be my feast-day, not running before and passing over these days, but remaining for ever; that will be festivity, joy without end, eternity without a blot, serenity without a cloud.

**[28:117]** "When He had said these words unto them, He abode still in Galilee.

**[28:118]** But when His brethren were gone up, then went He also up unto the feast, not openly, but as it were in secret".

**[28:119]** Therefore "not to this feast-day," because His desire was not for temporal glory, but to teach something to profit, to correct men, to admonish them of an eternal feast-day, to turn away their love from this world, and to turn it to God.

**[28:120]** But what means this, "He went up as it were in secret to the feast"? This action of the Lord also is not without meaning.

**[28:121]** It appears to me that, even from this circumstance that He went up as it were in secret, He had intended to signify something; for the things that follow will show that He thus went up on the middle of the feast, that is, when those days were half over, to teach even openly.

**[28:122]** But he said, "As it were in secret," meaning, not to show Himself to men.

**[28:123]** It is not without meaning that Christ went up "as it were in secret" to that feast, because He Himself lay hid in that feast-day.

**[28:124]** What I have said as yet is also under cover of secrecy.

**[28:125]** Let it be manifested then, let the veil be lifted, and let that which was secret appear.

**[28:126]** 9.

**[28:127]** All things that were spoken to the ancient people Israel in the manifold Scripture of the holy law, what things they did, whether in sacrifices, or in priestly offices, or in feast-days, and, in a word, in what things soever they worshipped God, what things soever were spoken to and given them in precept, were shadows of things to come.

**[28:128]** Of what things to come? Things which find their fulfillment in Christ.

**[28:129]** Whence the apostle says, "For all the promises of God are in Him yea;" that is, they are fulfilled in Him.

**[28:130]** Again he says in another place, "All happened to them in a figure; but they were written for our sakes, upon whom the end of the ages is come".

**[28:131]** And he said elsewhere, "For Christ is the end of the law;" likewise in another place, "Let no man judge you in meat, or in drink, or in respect of an holy day, or of a new moon, or of Sabbath-days, which is a shadow of things to come".

**[28:132]** If, therefore, all these things were shadows of things to come, also the feast of tabernacles was a shadow of things to come.

**[28:133]** Let us examine, then, of what thing to come was this feast-day a shadow.

**[28:134]** I have explained what this feast of tabernacles was: it was a celebration of taber  nacles, because the people, after their deliverance from Egypt, while directing their course through the wilderness to the land of promise, dwelt in tents.

**[28:135]** Let us observe what it is, and we shall be that thing; we, I say, who are members of Christ, if such we are; but we are, He having made us worthy, not we having earned it for ourselves.

**[28:136]** Let us then consider ourselves, brethren: we have been led out of Egypt, where we were slaves to the devil as to Pharaoh; where we applied ourselves to works of clay, engaged in earthly desires, and where we toiled exceedingly.

**[28:137]** And to us, while laboring, as it were, at the bricks, Christ cried aloud, "Come unto me, all ye that labor and are heavy laden".

**[28:138]** Thence we were led out by baptism as through the Red Sea,—red because consecrated by the blood of Christ.

**[28:139]** All our enemies that pursued us being dead, that is, all our sins being blotted out, we have been brought over to the other side.

**[28:140]** At the present time, then, before we come to the land of promise, namely, the eternal kingdom, we are in the wilderness in tabernacles.

**[28:141]** They who acknowledge these things are in tabernacles; for it was to be that some would acknowledge this.

**[28:142]** For that man, who understands that he is a sojourner in this world, is in tabernacles.

**[28:143]** That man understands that he is travelling in a foreign country, when he sees himself sighing for his native land.

**[28:144]** But whilst the body of Christ is in tabernacles, Christ is in tabernacles; but at that time He was so, not evidently but secretly.

**[28:145]** For as yet the shadow obscured the light; when the light came, the shadow was removed.

**[28:146]** Christ was in secret: He was in the feast of tabernacles, but there hidden.

**[28:147]** At the present time, when these things are already made manifest, we acknowledge that we are journeying in the wilderness: for if we know it, we are in the wilderness.

**[28:148]** What is it to be in the wilderness? In the desert waste.

**[28:149]** Why in the desert waste? Because in this world, where we thirst in a way in which is no water.

**[28:150]** But yet, let us thirst that we may be filled.

**[28:151]** For, "Blessed are they that hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be filled".

**[28:152]** And our thirst is quenched from the rock in the wilderness: for "the Rock was Christ," and it was smitten with a rod that the water might flow.

**[28:153]** But that it might flow, the rock was smitten twice: because there are two beams of the cross.

**[28:154]** All these things, then, which were done in a figure, are made manifest to us.

**[28:155]** And it is not without meaning that it was said of the Lord, "He went up to the feast-day, but not openly, but as it were in secret".

**[28:156]** For Himself in secret was the thing prefigured, because Christ was hid in that same festal-day; for that very festal-day signified Christ's members that were to sojourn in a foreign land.

**[28:157]** 10.

**[28:158]** "Then the Jews sought Him on the feast-day:" before He went up.

**[28:159]** For His brethren went up before Him, and He went not up then when they supposed and wished: that this too might be fulfilled which He said, "Not to this, that is, the first or second day, to which you wish me to go.

**[28:160]** But He went up afterwards, as the Gospel tells us, "on the middle of the feast;' that is, when as many days of that feast had passed as there remained.

**[28:161]** For they celebrated that same festival, so far we can understand, on several successive days.

**[28:162]** 11.

**[28:163]** "They said, therefore, Where is he? And there was much murmuring among the people concerning Him".

**[28:164]** Whence the murmuring? Of strife.

**[28:165]** What was the strife? "Some said, He is a good man; but others said, Nay; but he deceiveth the people".

**[28:166]** We must understand this of all His servants: this is said now of them.

**[28:167]** For whoever becomes eminent in some spiritual grace, of him some will assuredly say, "He is a good man;" others, "Nay; but he deceiveth the people".

**[28:168]** Whence is this? "Because our life is hid with Christ in God".

**[28:169]** On this account people may say during the winter, This tree is dead; for example, a fig tree, pear tree, or some kind of fruit tree, it is like a withered tree, and so long as it is winter it does not appear whether it is so or not.

**[28:170]** But the summer proves, the judgment proves.

**[28:171]** Our summer is the appearing of Christ: "God shall come manifest, our God, and He will not be silent;" "fire shall go before Him:" that fire "shall burn up His enemies:" that fire shall lay hold of the withered trees.

**[28:172]** For then shall the dry trees be apparent, when it shall be said to them, "I was hungry, and ye gave me not to eat;" but on the other side, namely, on the right, will be seen abundance of fruit, and magnificence of leaves; the green will be eternity.

**[28:173]** To those, then, as withered trees, it shall be said, "Go into everlasting fire.

**[28:174]** For behold," it saith, "the axe is laid to the root of the trees: every tree, therefore, that bringeth not forth good fruit shall be cut down, and cast into the fire".

**[28:175]** Let them then say of thee, if thou art growing in Christ, let men say of thee, "He deceiveth the people".

**[28:176]** This is said of Christ Himself; it is said of the whole body  of Christ.

**[28:177]** Think of the body of Christ still in the world, think of it still on the threshing-floor; see how it is blasphemed by the chaff.

**[28:178]** The chaff and the grain are, indeed, threshed together; but the chaff is consumed, the corn is purged.

**[28:179]** What was said of the Lord then, avails for consolation, whenever it will be said of any Christian.

**[28:180]** 12.

**[28:181]** "Howbeit no man spake openly of Him for fear of the Jews".

**[28:182]** But who were they that did not speak of Him for fear of the Jews? Undoubtedly they who said, "He is a good man:" not they who said, "He deceiveth the people".

**[28:183]** As for them who said "He deceiveth the people," their din was heard like the noise of dry leaves.

**[28:184]** "He deceiveth the people," they sounded more and more loudly: "He is a good man," they whispered more and more constrainedly.

**[28:185]** But now, brethren, notwithstanding that glory of Christ which is to make us immortal is not yet come, yet now, I say, His Church so increases, He has deigned to spread it abroad through the whole world, that it is now only whispered.

**[28:186]** "He deceiveth the people;" and more and more loudly it sounds forth, "He is a good man".

**[29:1]** Tractate XXIX.

**[29:2]** Chapter VII.

**[29:3]** 14–18  1.

**[29:4]** What follows of the Gospel and was read to-day, we must next in order look at, and speak from it as the Lord may grant us.

**[29:5]** Yesterday it was read thus far, that although they had not seen the Lord Jesus in the temple on the feast-day, yet they were speaking about Him: "And some said, He is a good man: but others said, Nay; but he seduceth the people".

**[29:6]** For this was said for the comfort of those who, afterwards preaching God's word, were to be seducers, and yet true men.

**[29:7]** For if to seduce is to deceive, neither was Christ a seducer, nor His apostles, nor ought any Christian to be such; but if to seduce (to lead aside) is by persuading to lead one from something to something else, we ought to inquire into the whence and the whither: if from evil to good, the seducer is a good man; if from good to evil, the seducer is a bad man.

**[29:8]** In that sense, then, in which men are seduced from evil to good, would that all of us both were called, and actually were seducers!  2.

**[29:9]** Then afterwards the Lord went up to the feast, "about the middle of the feast, and taught".

**[29:10]** "And the Jews marvelled, saying, How knoweth this man letters, having never learned?" He who was in secret taught, He was speaking openly and was not restrained.

**[29:11]** For that hiding of Himself was for the sake of example; this showing Himself openly was an intimation of His power.

**[29:12]** But as He taught, "the Jews marvelled;" all indeed, so far as I think, marvelled, but all were not converted.

**[29:13]** And why this wondering? Because all knew where He was born, where He had been brought up; they had never seen Him learning letters, but they heard Him disputing about the law, bringing forward testimonies of the law, which none could bring forward unless he had read, and none could read unless he had learned letters: and therefore they marvelled.

**[29:14]** But their marvelling was made an occasion to the Master of insinuating the truth more deeply into their minds.

**[29:15]** By reason, indeed of their wondering and words, the Lord said something profound, and worthy of being more diligently looked into and discussed.

**[29:16]** On account of which I would urge you, my beloved, to earnestness, not only in hearing for yourselves, but also in praying for us.

**[29:17]** 3.

**[29:18]** How then did the Lord answer those that were marvelling how He knew letters which He had not learned? "My doctrine," saith He, "is not mine, but His that sent me".

**[29:19]** This is the first profundity.

**[29:20]** For He seems as if in a few words He had spoken contraries.

**[29:21]** For He says not, This doctrine is not mine; but, "My doctrine is not mine".

**[29:22]** If not Thine, how Thine? If Thine, how not Thine? For Thou sayest both: both, "my doctrines;" and, "not mine".

**[29:23]** For if He had said, This doctrine is not mine, there would have been no question.

**[29:24]** But now, brethren, in the first place, consider well the question, and so in due order expect the solution.

**[29:25]** For he who sees not the question proposed, how can he understand what is expounded? The subject of inquiry, then, is  that which He says, "My, not mine" this appears to be contrary; how "my," how "not mine"? If we carefully look at what the holy evangelist himself says in the beginning of his Gospel, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God;" thence hangs the solution of this question.

**[29:26]** What then is the doctrine of the Father, but the Father's Word? Therefore, Christ Himself is the doctrine of the Father, if He is the Word of the Father.

**[29:27]** But since the Word cannot be of none, but of some one, He said both "His doctrine," namely, Himself, and also, "not His own," because He is the Word of the Father.

**[29:28]** For what is so much "Thine" as Thyself? And what so much not Thine as Thyself, if that Thou art is of another?  4.

**[29:29]** The Word then is God; and it is also the Word of a stable, unchangeable doctrine, not such as can be sounded by syllables and fleeting, but abiding with the Father, to which abiding doctrine let us be converted, being admonished by the transitory sounds of the voice.

**[29:30]** For that which is transitory does not so admonish us as to call us to transitory things.

**[29:31]** We are admonished to love God.

**[29:32]** All this that I have said were syllables; they smote through the air to reach your sense of hearing, and by sounding passed away: that, however, which I advise you ought not so to pass away, because He whom I exhort you to love passes not away; and when you, exhorted in transient syllables, shall have been converted, you shall not pass away, but shall abide with Him who is abiding.

**[29:33]** There is therefore in the doctrine this great matter, this deep and eternal thing which is permanent: whither all things that pass away in time call us, when they mean well and are not falsely put forward.

**[29:34]** For, in fact, all the signs which we produce by sounds do signify something which is not sound.

**[29:35]** For God is not the two short syllables "Deus," and it is not the two short syllables that we worship, and it is not the two short syllables that we adore, nor is it to the two short syllables that we desire to come—two syllables which almost cease to sound before they have begun to sound; nor in sounding them is there room for the second until the first has passed away.

**[29:36]** There remains, then, something great which is called "God," although the sound does not remain when we say the word "God".

**[29:37]** Thus direct your thoughts to the doctrine of Christ, and ye shall arrive at the Word of God; and when you have arrived at the Word of God, consider this, "The Word was God," and you will see that it was said truly, "my doctrine:" consider also whose the Word is, and you will see that it was rightly said, "is not mine".

**[29:38]** 5.

**[29:39]** Therefore, to speak briefly, beloved, it seems to me that the Lord Jesus Christ said, "My doctrine is not mine," meaning the same thing as if He said, "I am not from myself".

**[29:40]** For although we say and believe that the Son is equal to the Father, and that there is not any diversity of nature and substance in them, that there has not intervened any interval of time between Him that begets and Him that is begotten, nevertheless we say these things, while keeping and guarding this, that the one is the Father, the other the Son.

**[29:41]** But Father He is not if He have not a Son, and Son He is not if He have not a Father: but yet the Son is God from the Father; and the Father is God, but not from the Son.

**[29:42]** The Father of the Son, not God from the Son: but the other is Son of the Father, and God from the Father.

**[29:43]** For the Lord Christ is called Light from Light.

**[29:44]** The Light then which is not from Light, and the equal Light which is not from Light, are together one Light not two Lights.

**[29:45]** 6.

**[29:46]** If we have understood this, thanks be to God; but if any has not sufficiently understood, man has done as far as he could: as for the rest, let him see whence he may hope to understand.

**[29:47]** As laborers outside, we can plant and water; but it is of God to give the increase.

**[29:48]** "My doctrine," saith He, "is not mine, but His that sent me".

**[29:49]** Let him who says he has not yet understood hear counsel.

**[29:50]** For since it was a great and profound matter that had been spoken, the Lord Christ Himself did certainly see that all would not understand this so profound a matter, and He gave counsel in the sequel.

**[29:51]** Dost thou wish to understand? Believe.

**[29:52]** For God has said by the prophet: "Except ye believe, ye shall not understand".

**[29:53]** To the same purpose what the Lord here also added as He went on—"If any man is willing to do His will, he shall know concerning the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak from myself".

**[29:54]** What is the meaning of this, "If any man be willing to do His will"? But I had said, if any man believe; and I gave this counsel: If thou hast not understood, said I, believe.

**[29:55]** For understanding is the reward of faith.

**[29:56]** Therefore do not seek to understand in order to believe, but believe that thou mayest understand; since, "except ye believe, ye shall not understand".

**[29:57]** Therefore when I would counsel the obedience of believing toward the possibility of understanding, and say that our Lord Jesus Christ has added this very thing in  the following sentence, we find Him to have said, "If any man be willing to do His will, he shall know of the doctrine".

**[29:58]** What is "he shall know"? It is the same thing as "he shall understand".

**[29:59]** But what is "If any man be willing to do His will"? It is the same thing as to believe.

**[29:60]** All men indeed perceive that "shall know" is the same thing as "shall understand:" but that the saying, "If any man be willing to do His will," refers to believing, all do not perceive; to perceive this more accurately, we need the Lord Himself for expounder, to show us whether the doing of the Father's will does in reality refer to believing.

**[29:61]** But who does not know that this is to do the will of God, to work the work of God; that is, to work that work which is pleasing to Him? But the Lord Himself says openly in another place: "This is the work of God, that ye believe on Him whom He has sent".

**[29:62]** "That ye believe on Him," not, that ye believe Him.

**[29:63]** But if ye believe on Him, ye believe Him; yet he that believes Him does not necessarily believe on Him.

**[29:64]** For even the devils believed Him, but they did not believe on Him.

**[29:65]** Again, moreover, of His apostles we can say, we believe Paul; but not, we believe on Paul: we believe Peter; but not, we believe on Peter.

**[29:66]** For, "to him that believeth on Him that justifieth the ungodly, his faith is counted unto him for righteousness".

**[29:67]** What then is "to believe on Him"? By believing to love Him, by believing to esteem highly, by believing to go into Him and to be incorporated in His members.

**[29:68]** It is faith itself then that God exacts from us: and He finds not that which He exacts, unless He has bestowed what He may find.

**[29:69]** What faith, but that which the apostle has most amply defined in another place, saying, "Neither circumcision availeth anything, nor uncircumcision, but faith that worketh by love?"  Not any faith of what kind soever, but "faith that worketh by love:" let this faith be in thee, and thou shall understand concerning the doctrine.

**[29:70]** What indeed shall thou understand? That "this doctrine is not mine, but His that sent me;" that is, thou shall understand that Christ the Son of God, who is the doctrine of the Father, is not from Himself, but is the Son of the Father.

**[29:71]** 7.

**[29:72]** This sentence overthrows the Sabellian heresy.

**[29:73]** The Sabellians have dared to affirm that the Son is the very same as He who is also the Father: that the names are two, but the reality one.

**[29:74]** If the names were two and reality one, it would not be said, "My doctrine is not mine".

**[29:75]** Anyhow, if Thy doctrine is not Thine, O Lord, whose is it, unless there be another whose it is? The Sabellians understand not what Thou saidst; for they see not the trinity, but follow the error of their own heart.

**[29:76]** Let us worshippers of the trinity and unity of Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, and one God, understand concerning Christ's doctrine, how it is not His.

**[29:77]** And He said that He spoke not from Himself for this reason, because Christ is the Son of the Father, and the Father is the Father of Christ; and the Son is from God the Father, God, but God the Father is God not from God the Son.

**[29:78]** 8.

**[29:79]** "He that speaketh of himself seeketh his own glory: 'This will be he who is called Antichrist,' exalting himself," as the apostle says, "above all that is called God, and that is worshipped".

**[29:80]** The Lord, declaring that this same it is that will seek his own glory, not the glory of the Father, says to the Jews: "I am come in my Father's name, and ye have not received me; another will come in his own name, him ye will receive".

**[29:81]** He intimated that they would receive Antichrist, who will seek the glory of his own name, puffed up, not solid; and therefore not stable, but assuredly ruinous.

**[29:82]** But our Lord Jesus Christ has shown us a great example of humility: for doubtless He is equal with the Father, for "in the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God;" yea, doubtless, He Himself said, and most truly said, "Am I so long time with you, and ye have not known me, Philip? He that hath seen me hath seen the Father".

**[29:83]** Yea, doubtless, Himself said, and most truly said, "I and the Father are one".

**[29:84]** If, therefore, He is one with the Father, equal to the Father, God from God, God with God, coeternal, immortal, alike unchangeable, alike without time, alike Creator and disposer of times; and yet because He came in time, and took the form of a servant, and in condition was found as a man, He seeks the glory of the Father, not His own; what oughtest thou to do, O man, who, when thou doest anything good, seekest thy own glory; but when thou doest anything ill, dost meditate calumny against God? Consider thyself: thou art a creature, acknowledge thy Creator: thou art a servant, despise not thy Lord: thou art adopted, not for thy own merits; seek His glory from whom thou hast this grace, that thou art a man adopted; His, whose glory He sought who is from Him, the Only-begotten.

**[29:85]** "But He that seeketh His glory that sent Him, the same is true, and no unrighteousness is in Him".

**[29:86]** In Antichrist,  however, there is unrighteousness, and he is not true; because he will seek his own glory, not His by whom he was sent: for, indeed, he was not sent, but only permitted to come.

**[29:87]** Let us all, therefore, that belong to the body of Christ, seek not our own glory, that we be not led into the snares of Antichrist.

**[29:88]** But if Christ sought His glory that sent Him, how much more ought we to seek the glory of Him who made us?.

**[30:1]** Tractate XXX.

**[30:2]** Chapter VII.

**[30:3]** 19–24  1.

**[30:4]** The passage of the holy Gospel of which we have before discoursed to you, beloved, is followed by that of to-day, which has just now been read.

**[30:5]** Both the disciples and the Jews heard the Lord speaking; both men of truth and liars heard the Truth speaking; both friends and enemies heard Charity speaking; both good men and bad men heard the Good speaking.

**[30:6]** They heard, but He discerned; He saw and foresaw whom His discourse profited and would profit.

**[30:7]** Among those who were then, He saw; among us who were to be, He foresaw.

**[30:8]** Let us therefore hear the Gospel, just as if we were listening to the Lord Himself present: nor let us say, O happy they who were able to see Him! because there were many of them who saw, and also killed Him; and there are many among us who have not seen Him, and yet have believed.

**[30:9]** For the precious truth that sounded forth from the mouth of the Lord was both written for our sakes, and preserved for our sakes, and recited for our sakes, and will be recited also for the sake of our prosperity, even until the end of the world.

**[30:10]** The Lord is above; but the Lord, the Truth, is also here.

**[30:11]** For the body of the Lord, in which He rose again from the dead, can be only in one place; but His truth is everywhere diffused.

**[30:12]** Let us then hear the Lord, and let us also speak that which He shall have granted to us concerning His own words.

**[30:13]** 2.

**[30:14]** "Did not Moses," saith He, "give you the law, and yet none of you doeth the law? Why do ye seek to kill me?" For ye seek to kill me just for this reason, that none of you doeth the law; for if ye did do the law, ye would recognize Christ in its very letters, and ye would not kill Him when present with you.

**[30:15]** And they answered: "The crowd answered Him;" answered as a tumultuous crowd, things not pertaining to order, but to confusion; in a word, the crowd was disturbed.

**[30:16]** See what answer it made: "Thou hast a devil: who seeks to kill thee?" As if it were not worse to say, "Thou hast a devil," than to kill Him.

**[30:17]** To Him, indeed, was it said, that He had a devil, who was casting out devils.

**[30:18]** What else can a turbulent disorderly crowd say? What else can filth stirred up do but stink? The crowd was disturbed; by what? By the truth.

**[30:19]** For the eyes that have not soundness cannot endure the brightness of the light.

**[30:20]** 3.

**[30:21]** But the Lord, manifestly not disturbed, but calm in His truth, rendered not evil for evil nor railing for railing; although, if He were to say to these men, You have a devil, He would certainly be saying what was true.

**[30:22]** For they would not have said such things to the Truth, unless the falsehood of the devil had instigated them.

**[30:23]** What then did He answer? Let us calmly hear, and drink in the serene word: "I have done one work, and ye all marvel".

**[30:24]** As if He said, What if ye were to see all my works? For they were His works which they saw in the world, and yet they saw not Him who made them all: He did one thing, and they were disturbed because he made a man whole on the Sabbath-day.

**[30:25]** As if, indeed, when any sick man recovered his health on the Sabbath-day, it had been any other that made such a man whole than He who offended them, because He made one man whole on the Sabbath-day.

**[30:26]** For who else has made others whole than He who is health itself,—He who gives even to the beasts that health which He gave to this man? For it was bodily health.

**[30:27]** The health of the flesh is repaired, and the flesh dies; and when it is repaired, death is only put off, not taken away.

**[30:28]** However, even that same health, brethren, is from the Lord, through whomsoever it may be given: by whose care and ministry soever it may be imparted, it is given by Him from whom all health is, to whom it  is said in the psalm, "O Lord, Thou wilt save men and beasts; as Thou hast multiplied Thy mercy, O God".

**[30:29]** For because Thou art God Thy multiplied mercy reaches even to the safety of human flesh, reaches even to the safety of dumb animals; but Thou who givest health of flesh common to men and beasts, is there no health which Thou reservest for men? There is certainly another which is not only not common to men and beasts, but to men themselves is not common to good and bad.

**[30:30]** In a word, when he had there spoken of this health which men and cattle receive in common, because of that health which men, but only the good, ought to hope for, he added as he went on: "But the sons of men shall put their trust under the cover of Thy wings.

**[30:31]** They shall be fully satisfied with the fatness of Thy house; and Thou shalt give them drink from the torrent of Thy pleasure.

**[30:32]** For with Thee is the fountain of life; and in Thy light shall they see light".

**[30:33]** This is the health which belongs to good men, those whom he called "sons of men;" whilst he had said above, "O Lord, Thou shall save men and beasts".

**[30:34]** How then? Were not those men sons of men, that after he had said men, he should go on and say, But the sons of men: as if men and sons of men meant different things? Yet I do not believe that the Holy Spirit had said this without some indication of distinction.

**[30:35]** The term men refers to the first Adam, sons of men to Christ.

**[30:36]** Perhaps, indeed, men relate to the first man; but sons of men relate to the Son of man.

**[30:37]** 4.

**[30:38]** "I have done one work, and ye all marvel".

**[30:39]** And immediately He subjoined: "Moses therefore gave unto you circumcision".

**[30:40]** It was well done that ye received circumcision from Moses.
