**[30:41]** "Not that it is of Moses, but of the fathers;" since it was Abraham that first received circumcision from the Lord.

**[30:42]** "And ye circumcise on the Sabbath-day".

**[30:43]** Moses has convicted you: ye have received in the law to circumcise on the eighth day; ye have received in the law to cease from labor on the seventh day; if the eighth day from the child's birth fall on the seventh day of the week, what will ye do? Will ye abstain from work to keep the Sabbath, or will ye circumcise to fulfill the sacrament of the eighth day? But I know, saith He, what ye do.

**[30:44]** "Ye circumcise a man".

**[30:45]** Why? Because circumcision relates to what is a kind of seal of salvation, and men ought not to abstain from the work of salvation on the Sabbath-day.

**[30:46]** Therefore be ye not "angry with me, because I have made a man every whit whole on the Sabbath-day".

**[30:47]** "If," saith He, "a man on the Sabbath-day receiveth circumcision that the law should not be broken" (for it was something saving that was ordained by Moses in that ordinance of circumcision), why are ye angry at me for working a healing on the Sabbath-day?  5.

**[30:48]** Perhaps, indeed, that circumcision pointed to the Lord Himself, at whom they were indignant, because He worked cures and healing.

**[30:49]** For circumcision was commanded to be applied on the eighth day: and what is circumcision but the spoiling of the flesh? This circumcision, then, signified the removal of carnal lusts from the heart.

**[30:50]** Therefore not without cause was it given, and ordered to be made in that member; since by that member the creature of mortal kind is procreated.

**[30:51]** By one man came death, just as by one man the resurrection of the dead; and by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin.

**[30:52]** Therefore every man is born with a foreskin, because every man is born with the vice of propagation; and God cleanses not, either from the vice with which we are born, or from the vices which we add thereto by ill living, except by the stony knife, the Lord Christ.

**[30:53]** For Christ was the Rock.

**[30:54]** Now they used to circumcise with stone knives, and by the name of rock they prefigured Christ; and yet when He was present with them they did not acknowledge Him, but besides, they sought to kill Him.

**[30:55]** But why on the eighth day, unless because after the seventh day of the week the Lord rose again on the Lord's day? Therefore Christ's resurrection, which happened on the third day indeed of His passion, but on the eighth day in the days of the week, that same resurrection it is that doth circumcise us.

**[30:56]** Hear of those that were circumcised with the real stone, while the apostle admonishes them: "If then ye be risen with Christ, seek those things which are above, where Christ is, sitting on the right hand of God; set your affection on things above, not on things on the earth".

**[30:57]** He speaks to the circumcised: Christ has risen; He has taken away from you carnal desires, evil lusts, the superfluity with which you were born, and that far worse which you had added thereto by ill living; being circumcised by the Rock, why do you still set your affections on the earth? And finally, for that "Moses gave you the law, and ye circumcise a man on the Sabbath-day," understand that by this is signified the good work which I have done, in that I have made a man every whit whole on the Sabbath-day; because he was cured that  he might be whole in body, and also he believed that he might be whole in soul.

**[30:58]** 6.

**[30:59]** "Judge not according to personal appearance, but judge righteous judgment".

**[30:60]** What is this? Just now, you who by the law of Moses circumcise on the Sabbath-day are not angry with Moses; and because I made a man whole on the Sabbath-day you are angry with me.

**[30:61]** You judge by the person; give heed to the truth.

**[30:62]** I do not prefer myself to Moses, says the Lord, who was also the Lord of Moses.

**[30:63]** So consider us as you would two men, as both men; judge between us, but judge a true judgment; do not condemn him by honoring me, but honor me by understanding him.

**[30:64]** For this He said to them in another place: "If ye believed Moses ye would certainly believe me also, for he wrote of me".

**[30:65]** But in this place He willed not to say this, Himself and Moses being as it were placed before these men for judgment.

**[30:66]** Because of Moses' law you circumcise, even when it happens to be the Sabbath-day, and will ye not that I should show the beneficence of healing during the Sabbath? For the Lord of circumcision and the Lord of the Sabbath is the same who is the Author of health; and they are servile works that ye are forbidden to do on the Sabbath; if ye really understand what servile works are, ye sin not.

**[30:67]** For he that committeth sin is the servant of sin.

**[30:68]** Is it a servile work to heal a man on the Sabbath-day? Ye do eat and drink (to infer somewhat from the admonition of our Lord Jesus Christ, and from His words); at any rate, why do ye eat and drink on the Sabbath, but because that what ye do pertains to health? By this ye show that the works of health are not in any wise to be omitted on the Sabbath.

**[30:69]** Therefore "do not judge by person, but judge righteous judgment".

**[30:70]** Consider me as ye would a man; consider Moses as a man: if ye will judge according to the truth, ye will condemn neither Moses nor me; and when ye know the truth ye will know me, because I am the Truth.

**[30:71]** 7.

**[30:72]** It requires great labor in this world, brethren to get clear of the vice which the Lord has noted in this place, so as not to judge by appearance, but to keep right judgment.

**[30:73]** The Lord, indeed, admonished the Jews, but He warned us also; them He convicted, us He instructed; them He reproved, us He encouraged.

**[30:74]** Let us not imagine that this was not said to us, simply because we were not there at that time.

**[30:75]** It was written, it is read; when it was recited we heard it; but we heard it as said to the Jews; let us not place ourselves behind ourselves and watch Him reproving enemies, while we ourselves do that which the truth may reprove in us.

**[30:76]** The Jews indeed judged by appearance, but for that reason they belong not to the New Testament, they have not the kingdom of heaven in Christ, nor are joined to the society of the holy angels; they sought earthly things of the Lord; for a land of promise, victory over enemies, fruitfulness of child-bearing, increase of children, abundance of fruit,—all which things were indeed promised to them by God, the True and the Good, promised to them, however, as unto carnal men,—all these things made for them the Old Testament.

**[30:77]** What is the Old Testament? The inheritance, as it were, belonging to the old man.

**[30:78]** We have been renewed, have been made a new man, because He who is the new man has come.

**[30:79]** What is so new as to be born of a virgin? Therefore, because there was not in Him what instruction might renew, because He had no sin, there was given Him a new origin of birth.

**[30:80]** In Him a new birth, in us a new man.

**[30:81]** What is a new man? A man renewed from oldness.

**[30:82]** Renewed unto what? Unto desiring heavenly things, unto longing for things eternal, unto earnestly seeking the country which is above and fears no foe, where we do not lose a friend nor fear an enemy; where we live with good affection, without any want; where no longer any advances, because none fails; where no man is born, because no man dies; where there is no hungering nor thirsting; where immortality is fullness, and truth our aliment.

**[30:83]** Having these promises, and pertaining to the New Testament, and being made heirs of a new inheritance, and co-heirs of the Lord Himself, we have a far different hope from theirs: let us not judge by appearance, but hold right judgment.

**[30:84]** 8.

**[30:85]** Who is he that judges not according to the person? He that loves equally.

**[30:86]** Equal love causes that persons be not accepted.

**[30:87]** It is not when we honor men in diverse measure according to their degrees that we ought to fear lest we are accepting persons.

**[30:88]** For where we judge between two, and at times between relations, sometimes it happens that judgment has to be made between father and son; the father complains of a bad son, or the son complains of a harsh father; we regard the honor which is due to the father from the son; we do not make the son equal to the father in honor, but we give him preference if he has a good cause: let us regard the son on an equality with the father in the truth, and thus shall we bestow the honor due, so that equity destroy not merit.

**[30:89]** Thus we profit by the words of the Lord, and that we may profit, we are assisted by His grace.

**[31:1]** Tractate XXXI.

**[31:2]** Chapter VII.

**[31:3]** 25–36  1.

**[31:4]** You remember, beloved, in the former discourses,—for it was both read in the Gospel and also discussed by us according to our ability,—how that the Lord Jesus went up to the feast-day, as it were in secret, not because He feared lest He should be laid hold of,—He who had the power not to be laid hold of,—but to signify that even in that very feast which was celebrated by the Jews He Himself was hidden, and that the mystery of the feast was His own.

**[31:5]** In the passage read to-day then, that which was supposed to be timidity appeared as power; for He spoke openly on the feast-day, so that the crowds marvelled, and said that which we have heard when the passage was read: "Is not this he whom they sought to kill? And, lo, he speaketh openly, and they say nothing.

**[31:6]** Do the rulers know indeed that this is the Christ?" They who knew with what fierceness He was sought after, wondered by what power He was kept from being taken.

**[31:7]** Then, not fully understanding His power, they fancied it was the knowledge of the rulers, that these rulers knew Him to be the very Christ, and that for this reason they spared Him whom they had with so much eagerness sought out to be put to death.

**[31:8]** 2.

**[31:9]** Then those same persons who had said, "Did the rulers know that this is the Christ?" proposed a question among themselves, by which it appeared to them that He was not the Christ; for they said in addition, "But we know this man whence he is: but when Christ cometh, no man knoweth whence he is".

**[31:10]** As to how this opinion among the Jews arose, that "when Christ comes, no man knoweth whence He is" (for it did not arise without reason), if we consider the Scriptures, we find, brethren, that the Holy Scriptures have declared of Christ that "He shall be called a Nazarene".

**[31:11]** Therefore they foretold whence He is.

**[31:12]** Again, if we seek the place of His nativity, as that whence He is by birth, neither was this hidden from the Jews, because of the Scriptures which had foretold these things.

**[31:13]** For when the Magi, on the appearing of a star, sought Him out to worship Him, they came to Herod and told him what they sought and what they meant: and he, having called together those who had knowledge of the law, inquired of them where Christ should be born: they told him, "In Bethlehem of Judah," and also brought forward the prophetic testimony.

**[31:14]** If, therefore, the prophets had foretold both the place where the origin of His flesh was, and the place where His mother would bring Him forth, whence did spring that opinion among the Jews which we have just heard, but from this, that the Scriptures had proclaimed beforehand, and had foretold both? In respect of His being man, the Scriptures foretold whence He should be; in respect of His being God, this was hidden from the ungodly, and it required godly men to discover it.

**[31:15]** Moreover, they said this, "When Christ comes, no man knoweth whence He is," because that which was spoken by Isaiah produced this opinion in them, viz.

**[31:16]** "And His generation, who shall tell?" In short, the Lord Himself made answer to both, that they both did, and also did not know whence He was; that He might testify to the holy prophecy which before was predicted of Him, both as to the humanity of infirmity and also as to the divinity of majesty.

**[31:17]** 3.

**[31:18]** Hear, therefore, the word of the Lord, brethren; see how He confirmed to them both what they said, "We know this man whence he is," and also what they said, "When Christ cometh, no man knoweth whence He is.

**[31:19]** Then cried Christ in the temple, saying, Ye both know me, and ye know whence I am: and I am not come of myself, but He that sent me is true, whom ye know not".

**[31:20]** That is to say, ye both know me, and ye know me not; ye both know whence I am, and ye know not whence I am.

**[31:21]** Ye know whence I am: Jesus of Nazareth, whose parents also ye knew.

**[31:22]** For in this case, the birth of the Virgin alone was hidden, to whom, however, her husband was witness; for the same was able faithfully to declare this, who was also able as a husband to be jealous.

**[31:23]** Therefore, this birth of the Virgin excepted, they knew all that in Jesus pertains to man: His face was known, His country was known, His family was known; where He was born was to be known by inquiry.

**[31:24]** Rightly then did He say, "Ye both know me, and ye know whence I am," according to the flesh and form of man which He bore; but according to His  divinity, "And I am not come of myself, but He that sent me is true, whom ye know not;" but yet that ye may know Him, believe on Him whom He has sent, and ye will know Him.

**[31:25]** For, "No man has seen God at any time, except the only-begotten Son, who is in the bosom of the Father, He hath declared Him:"  and, "None knoweth the Father but the Son, and he to whom the Son wills to reveal Him".

**[31:26]** 4.

**[31:27]** Lastly, when He had said, "But He that sent me is true, whom ye know not," in order to show them whence they might know that which they did not know, He subjoined, "I know Him".

**[31:28]** Therefore seek from me to know Him.

**[31:29]** But why is it that I know Him? "Because I am from Him, and He sent me".

**[31:30]** Gloriously has He shown both.

**[31:31]** "I am from Him," said He; because the Son is from the Father, and whatever the Son is, He is of Him whose Son He is.

**[31:32]** Hence we say that the Lord Jesus is God of God: we do not say that the Father is God of God, but simply God: and we say that the Lord Jesus is Light of Light; we do not say that the Father is Light of Light, but simply Light.

**[31:33]** Accordingly, to this belongs that which He said "I am from Him".

**[31:34]** But as to my being seen of you in the flesh, "He sent me".

**[31:35]** When thou hearest "He sent me," do not understand a difference of nature to be meant, but the authority of Him that begets.

**[31:36]** 5.

**[31:37]** "Then they sought to take Him: but no man laid hands on Him, because His hour was not yet come;" that is, because He was not willing.

**[31:38]** For what is this.

**[31:39]** "His hour was not yet come"? The Lord was not born under fate.

**[31:40]** This is not to be believed concerning thee, much less concerning Him by whom thou wast made.

**[31:41]** If thy hour is His good will, what is His hour but His good will? He meant not therefore an hour in which He should be forced to die, but that in which He would deign to be put to death.

**[31:42]** But He was awaiting the time in which He should die, for He awaited also the time in which He should be born.

**[31:43]** The apostle, speaking of this time, says, "But when the fullness of time came, God sent His Son".

**[31:44]** For this cause many say, Why did not Christ come before? To whom we must make answer, Because the fullness of time had not yet come, while He by whom the times were made sets their bounds; for He knew when He ought to come.

**[31:45]** In the first place, it was necessary that He should be foretold through a long series of times and years; for it was not something insignificant that was to come: He who was to be ever held, had to be for a long time foretold.

**[31:46]** The greater the judge that was coming, the longer the train of heralds that preceded him.

**[31:47]** In short, when the fullness of time came, He also came who was to deliver us from time.

**[31:48]** For being delivered from time, we shall come to that eternity where there is no time: there it is not said, When shall the hour come, for the day is everlasting, a day which is neither preceded by a yesterday, nor cut off by a morrow.

**[31:49]** But in this world days roll on, some are passing away, others come; none abides; and the moments in which we are speaking drive out one another in turn, nor stands the first syllable for the second to sound.

**[31:50]** Since we began to speak we are somewhat older, and without doubt I am just now older than I was in the morning; thus, nothing stands, nothing remains fixed in time.

**[31:51]** Therefore ought we to love Him by whom the times were made, that we may be delivered from time and be fixed in eternity, where there is no more changeableness of times.

**[31:52]** Great, therefore, is the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ, in that for our sakes He was made in time, by whom the times were made; that He was made among all things, by whom all things were made; that He became what He made.

**[31:53]** For He was made what He had made; for He was made man who had made man, lest what He had made should perish.

**[31:54]** According to this dispensation, the hour of His birth had now come, and He was born; but not yet had come the hour of His suffering, therefore not yet had He suffered.

**[31:55]** 6.

**[31:56]** In short, that ye may know that the words refer, not to the necessity of His dying, but to His power,—I speak this for the sake of some who, when they hear "His hour was not yet come," are determined on believing in fate, and their hearts become infatuated;—that ye may know, then, that it was His power of dying, recollect the passion, look at Him crucified.

**[31:57]** While hanging on the tree, He said, "I thirst".

**[31:58]** They, having heard this, offered to Him on the cross vinegar by a sponge on a reed.

**[31:59]** He received it, and said, "It is finished;" and, bowing His head, gave up the ghost.

**[31:60]** You see His power of dying, that He waited for this—until all things should be fulfilled that had been foretold concerning Him—to take place before His death.

**[31:61]** For the prophet had said, "They gave me gall for my meat; and in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink".

**[31:62]** He waited for all these things to be fulfilled: after they were completed, He said, "It is finished;"  and He departed by power, because He came not by necessity.

**[31:63]** Hence some wondered more at this His power to die than at His ability to work miracles.

**[31:64]** For they came to the cross to take the bodies down from the tree, for the Sabbath was drawing near, and the thieves were found still living.

**[31:65]** The punishment of the cross was so much the harder because it tortured men so long, and all that were crucified were killed by a lingering death.

**[31:66]** But the thieves, that they might not remain on the tree, were forced to die by having their legs broken, that they might be taken down thence.

**[31:67]** The Lord, however, was found to be already dead, and the men marvelled; and they who despised Him when living, so wondered at Him when dead, that some of them said, "Truly this was the Son of God".

**[31:68]** Whence also that, brethren, where He says to those that seek Him, "I am He;" and they, going backward, all fell to the ground? Consequently there was in Him supreme power.

**[31:69]** Nor was He forced to die at an hour; but He waited the hour on which His will might fittingly be done, not that on which necessity might be fulfilled against His will.

**[31:70]** 7.

**[31:71]** "But many of the people believed on Him".

**[31:72]** The Lord made whole the humble and the poor.

**[31:73]** The rulers were mad, and therefore they not only did not acknowledge the Physician, but even were eager to slay Him.

**[31:74]** There was a certain crowd of people which quickly saw its own sickness, and without delay recognized His remedy.

**[31:75]** See what that very crowd, moved by His miracles, said: "When Christ cometh will He do more signs than these?" Surely, unless there will be two Christs, this is the Christ.

**[31:76]** Consequently, in saying these things, they believed on Him.

**[31:77]** 8.

**[31:78]** But those rulers, having heard the assurance of the multitude, and that murmuring noise of the people in which Christ was being glorified, "sent officers to take Him".

**[31:79]** To take whom? Him not yet willing to be taken.

**[31:80]** Because then they could not take Him while He would not, they were sent to hear Him teaching.

**[31:81]** Teaching what? "Then said Jesus, Yet a little while I am with you".

**[31:82]** What ye wish to do now ye will do, but not just now; because I am not just now willing.

**[31:83]** Why am I now as yet unwilling? Because "yet a little while I am with you; and then I go unto Him that sent me".

**[31:84]** I must complete my dispensation, and in this manner come to my suffering.

**[31:85]** 9.

**[31:86]** "Ye shall seek me, and shall not find me: and where I am, thither ye cannot come".

**[31:87]** Here He has already foretold His resurrection; for they would not acknowledge Him when present, and afterwards they sought Him when they saw the multitude already believing on Him.

**[31:88]** For great signs were wrought, even when the Lord was risen again and ascended into heaven.

**[31:89]** Then mighty deeds were done by His disciples, but He wrought by them as He wrought by Himself: since, indeed, He had said to them, "Without me ye can do nothing".

**[31:90]** When that lame man who sat at the gate rose up at Peter's voice, and walked on his feet, so that men marvelled, Peter spoke to them to this effect, that it was not by his own power that he did this, but in the virtue of Him whom they slew.

**[31:91]** Many pricked in the heart said, "What shall we do?" For they saw themselves bound by an immense crime of impiety, since they slew Him whom they ought to have revered and worshipped; and this crime they thought inexpiable.

**[31:92]** A great wickedness indeed it was, the thought of which might make them despair; yet it did not behove them to despair, for whom the Lord, as He hung on the cross, deigned to pray.

**[31:93]** For He had said, "Father, forgive them; for they know not what they do".

**[31:94]** He saw some who were His own among many who were aliens; for these He sought pardon, from whom at the time He was still receiving injury.

**[31:95]** He regarded not that He was being put to death by them, but only that He was dying for them.

**[31:96]** It was a great thing that was forgiven them, it was a great thing that was done by them and for them, so that no man should despair of the forgiveness of his sin when they who slew Christ obtained pardon.

**[31:97]** Christ died for us, but surely He was not put to death by us? But those men indeed saw Christ dying by their own villany; and yet they believed on Christ pardoning their villanies.

**[31:98]** Until they drank the blood they had shed, they despaired of their own salvation.

**[31:99]** Therefore said He this: "Ye shall seek me, and shall not find me: and where I am, ye cannot come;" because they were to seek Him after the resurrection, being pricked in their heart with remorse.

**[31:100]** Nor did He say "where I will be," but "where I am".

**[31:101]** For Christ was always in that place whither He was about to return; for He came in such manner that He did not depart from that place.

**[31:102]** Hence He says in another place, "No man has ascended into heaven, but He who came down from heaven, the Son of man who is in heaven".

**[31:103]** He said not, who was in heaven.

**[31:104]** He spoke on the earth, and declared that He  was at the same time in heaven.

**[31:105]** He came in such wise that He departed not thence; and He so returned as not to abandon us.

**[31:106]** What do ye marvel at? This is God's doing.

**[31:107]** For man, as regards his body, is in a place, and departs from a place; and when he comes to another place, he will not be in that place whence he came: but God fills all things, and is all everywhere; He is not held in places according to space.

**[31:108]** Nevertheless the Lord Christ was, as regards His visible flesh, on the earth: as regards His invisible majesty, He was in heaven and on earth; and therefore He says, "Where I am, thither ye cannot come".

**[31:109]** Nor did He say, "Ye shall not be able".

**[31:110]** but "ye are not able to come;" for at that time they were such as were not able.

**[31:111]** And that ye may know that this was not said to cause despair, He said something of the same kind also to His disciples: "Whither I go ye cannot come".

**[31:112]** Yet while praying in their behalf, He said, "Father, I will that where I am they also may be with me".

**[31:113]** And, finally, this He expounded to Peter, and says to him, "Whither I go thou canst not follow me now, but thou shalt follow me hereafter".

**[31:114]** 10.

**[31:115]** "Then said the Jews," not to Him, but "to themselves, Whither will this man go, that we shall not find him? will he go unto the dispersion among the Gentiles, and teach the Gentiles?" For they knew not what they said; but, it being His will, they prophesied.

**[31:116]** The Lord was indeed about to go to the Gentiles, not by His bodily presence, but still with His feet.

**[31:117]** What were His feet? Those which Saul desired to trample upon by persecution, when the Head cried out to him, "Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?" What is this saying that He said, "Ye shall seek me, and shall not find me: and where I am, thither ye cannot come?" Wherefore the Lord said this they knew not, and yet they did predict something that was to be without knowing it.

**[31:118]** For this is what the Lord said that they knew not the place, if place however it must be called, which is the bosom of the Father, from which Christ never departed; nor were they competent to conceive where Christ was, whence Christ never withdrew, whither He was to return, where He was all the while dwelling.

**[31:119]** How was it possible for the human heart to conceive this, least of all to explain it with the tongue? This, then, they in no wise understood; and yet by occasion of this they foretold our salvation, that the Lord would go to the dispersion of the Gentiles, and would fulfill that which they read but did not understand.

**[31:120]** "A people whom I have not known served me, and by the hearing of the ear obeyed me".

**[31:121]** They before whose eyes He was, heard Him not; those heard Him in whose ears He was sounded.

**[31:122]** 11.

**[31:123]** For of that Church of the Gentiles which was to come, the woman that had the issue of blood was a type: she touched and was not seen; she was not known and yet was healed.

**[31:124]** It was in reality a figure what the Lord asked: "Who touched me?" As if not knowing, He healed her as unknown: so has He done also to the Gentiles.

**[31:125]** We did not get to know Him in the flesh, yet we have been made worthy to eat His flesh, and to be members in His flesh.

**[31:126]** In what way? Because He sent to us.

**[31:127]** Whom? His heralds, His disciples, His servants, His redeemed whom He created, but whom He redeemed, His brethren also.

**[31:128]** I have said but little of all that they are: His own members, Himself; for He sent to us His own members, and He made us His members.

**[31:129]** Nevertheless, Christ has not been among us with the bodily form which the Jews saw and despised; because this also was said concerning Him, even as the apostle says: "Now I say that Christ was a minister of the circumcision for the truth of God, to confirm the promises made unto the fathers".

**[31:130]** He owed it to have come to those by whose fathers and to whose fathers He was promised.

**[31:131]** For this reason He says also Himself: "I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel".

**[31:132]** But what says the apostle in the following words? "And that the Gentiles might glorify God for His mercy".

**[31:133]** What, moreover, saith the Lord Himself? "Other sheep I have which are not of this fold".

**[31:134]** He who had said, "I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel," how has He other sheep to which He was not sent, except that He intimated that He was not sent to show His bodily presence but to the Jews only, who saw and killed Him? And yet many of them, both before and afterwards, believed.

**[31:135]** The first harvest was winnowed from the cross, that there might be a seed whence another harvest might spring up.

**[31:136]** But at this present time, when roused by the fame of the gospel, and by its goodly odor, His faithful ones among all nations believe, He shall be the expectation of the Gentiles, when He shall come who has already come; when He shall be seen by all, He who was then not seen by some, by some was seen; when He shall come to judge who came to be judged; when He shall come to distinguish who came not to be distinguish  ed.

**[31:137]** For Christ was not discerned by the ungodly, but was condemned with the ungodly; for it was said concerning Him, "He was accounted among the wicked".

**[31:138]** The robber escaped, Christ was condemned.

**[31:139]** He who was loaded with criminal accusations received pardon; He who has released from their crimes all who confess Him, was condemned.

**[31:140]** Nevertheless even the cross itself, if thou considerest it well, was a judgment-seat; for the Judge being set up in the middle, one thief who believed was delivered, the other who reviled was condemned.

**[31:141]** Already He signified what He is to do with the quick and the dead: some He will set on His right hand and others on His left.

**[31:142]** That thief was like those that shall be on the left hand, the other like those that shall be on the right.

**[31:143]** He was undergoing judgment, and He threatened judgment.

**[32:1]** Tractate XXXII.

**[32:2]** Chapter VII.

**[32:3]** 37–39  1.

**[32:4]** Among the dissensions and doubtings of the Jews concerning the Lord Jesus Christ, among other things which He said, by which some were confounded, others taught: "On the last day of that feast" (for it was then that these things were done) which is called the feast of tabernacles; that is, the building of tents, of which feast you remember, my beloved, that we have already discoursed, the Lord Jesus Christ calls, not by speaking in any way soever, but by crying aloud, that whoso thirsts may come to Him.

**[32:5]** If we thirst, let us come; and not by our feet, but by our affections; let us come, not by removing from our place, but by loving.

**[32:6]** Although, according to the inner man, he that loves does also move from a place.

**[32:7]** But it is one thing to move with the body, another thing to move with the heart: he migrates with the body who changes his place by a motion of the body; he migrates with the heart who changes his affection by a motion of the heart.

**[32:8]** If thou lovest one thing, and didst love another thing before, thou art not now where thou wast.

**[32:9]** 2.

**[32:10]** Accordingly, the Lord cries aloud to us: for, "He stood and cried out, if any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink.

**[32:11]** He that believeth on me, as the Scripture saith, out of his belly shall flow rivers of living water".

**[32:12]** We are not obliged to delay to inquire what this meant, since the evangelist has explained it.

**[32:13]** For why the Lord said, "If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink;" and, "He that believeth on me, out of his belly shall flow rivers of living water;" the evangelist has subsequently explained, saying: "But this spake He of the Spirit which they that believe on Him should receive.

**[32:14]** For the Spirit was not yet given, because Jesus was not yet glorified".

**[32:15]** There is therefore an inner thirst and an inner belly, because there is an inner man.

**[32:16]** And that inner man is indeed invisible, but the outer man is visible; but yet better is the inner than the outer.

**[32:17]** And this which is not seen is the more loved; for it is certain that the inner man is loved more than the outer.

**[32:18]** How is this certain? Let every man prove it in himself.

**[32:19]** For although they who live ill may surrender their minds to the body, yet they do wish to live, and to live is the property of the mind only; and they who rule, manifest themselves more than those things that are ruled.

**[32:20]** Now it is minds that rule, bodies are ruled.

**[32:21]** Every man rejoices in pleasure, and receives pleasure by the body: but separate the mind from it, and nothing remains in the body to rejoice; and if there is joy of the body, it is the mind that rejoices.

**[32:22]** If it has joy of its dwelling, ought it not to have joy of itself? And if the mind has whereof it may have delight outside itself, does it remain without delights within? It is quite certain that a man loves his soul more than his body.

**[32:23]** But further, a man loves the soul even in another man more than the body.

**[32:24]** What is it that is loved in a friend, where the love is the purer and more sincere? What in the friend is loved—the mind, or the body? If fidelity is loved, the mind is loved; if benevolence is loved, the mind is the seat of benevolence: if this is what thou lovest in another, that he too loves thee, it is the mind thou lovest, because it is not the flesh, but the mind that loves.

**[32:25]** For therefore thou lovest, because he loves thee: ask why he loves thee, and then  see what it is thou lovest.

**[32:26]** Consequently, it is more loved, and yet is not seen.

**[32:27]** 3.

**[32:28]** I would say something further, by which it may more clearly appear to you, beloved, how much the mind is loved, and how it is preferred to the body.

**[32:29]** Those wanton lovers even, who delight in beauty of bodies, and are charmed by shapeliness of limbs, love the more when they are loved.

**[32:30]** For when a man loves, and finds that he is regarded with hatred, he feels more anger than liking.

**[32:31]** Why does he feel anger rather than liking? Because the love that he bestows is not given him in return.

**[32:32]** If, therefore, even the lovers of bodies desire to be loved in return, and this delights them more when they are loved, what shall we say of the lovers of minds? And if the lovers of minds are great, what shall we say of the lovers of God who makes minds beautiful? For as the mind gives grace to the body, so it is God that gives grace to the mind.

**[32:33]** For it is only the mind that causes that in the body by which it is loved; when the mind has left it, it is a corpse at which thou hast a horror; and how much soever thou mayest have loved its beautiful limbs, thou makest haste to bury it.

**[32:34]** Hence, the ornament of the body is the mind; the ornament of the mind is God.

**[32:35]** 4.

**[32:36]** The Lord, therefore, cries aloud to us to come and drink, if we thirst within; and He says that when we have drunk, rivers of living water shall flow from our belly.

**[32:37]** The belly of the inner man is the conscience of the heart.

**[32:38]** Having drunk that water then, the conscience being purged begins to live; and drinking in, it will have a fountain, will be itself a fountain.

**[32:39]** What is the fountain, and what the river that flows from the belly of the inner man? Benevolence, whereby a man will consult the interest of his neighbor.

**[32:40]** For if he imagines that what he drinks ought to be only for his own satisfying, there is no flowing of living water from his belly; but if he is quick to consult for the good of his neighbor, then he becomes not dry, because there is a flowing.

**[32:41]** We will now see what it is that they drink who believe in the Lord; because we surely are Christians, and if we believe, we drink.

**[32:42]** And it is every man's duty to know in himself whether or not he drinks, and whether he lives by what he drinks; for the fountain does not forsake us if we forsake not the fountain.

**[32:43]** 5.

**[32:44]** The evangelist explained, as I have said, whereof the Lord had cried out, to what kind of drink He had invited, what He had procured for them that drink, saying, "But this spake He of the Spirit, which they that believe on Him should receive: for the Spirit was not yet given, because Jesus was not yet glorified".

**[32:45]** What spirit does He speak of, if not the Holy Spirit? For every man has in himself a spirit of his own, of which I spoke when I was commending to you the consideration of the mind.

**[32:46]** For every man's mind is his own spirit: of which the Apostle Paul says, "For what man knoweth the things of a man, but the spirit of the man which is in himself?" And then he added, "So also the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God".

**[32:47]** None knows the things that are ours but our own spirit.

**[32:48]** I indeed do not know what are thy thoughts, nor dost thou know what are mine; for those things which we think within are our own, peculiar to ourselves; and his own spirit is the witness of every man's thoughts.

**[32:49]** "So also the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God".

**[32:50]** We with our spirit, God with His: so, however, that God with His Spirit knows also what goes on within us; but we are not able, without His own Spirit, to know what takes place in God.

**[32:51]** God, however, knows in us even what we know not in ourselves.

**[32:52]** For Peter did not know his own weakness, when he heard from the Lord that he would deny Him thrice: the sick man was ignorant of his own condition; the Physician knew him to be sick.

**[32:53]** There are then certain things which God knows in us, while we ourselves know them not.

**[32:54]** So far, however, as belongs to men, no man knows a man as he does himself: another does not know what is going on within him, but his own spirit knows it.

**[32:55]** But on receiving the Spirit of God, we learn also what takes place in God: not the whole, for we have not received the whole.

**[32:56]** We know many things from the pledge; for we have received a pledge, and the fullness of this pledge shall be given hereafter.

**[32:57]** Meanwhile, let the pledge console us in our pilgrimage here; because he who has condescended to bind himself to us by a pledge, is prepared to give us much.

**[32:58]** If such is the token, what must that be of which it is the token?  6.

**[32:59]** But what is meant by this which he says, "For the Spirit was not yet given, because Jesus was not yet glorified?" He is understood to say this in a sense that is evident.

**[32:60]** For the meaning is not that the Spirit of God, which was with God, was not in being; but was not yet in them who had believed on Jesus.

**[32:61]** For thus the Lord Jesus disposed not to give them the Spirit of which we speak, until after His resurrection; and this not without a cause.

**[32:62]** And perhaps if we inquire, He will favor us to find; and if we knock, He will open for us to enter.

**[32:63]** Piety knocks, not the  hand, though the hand also knocks, if it cease not from works of mercy.

**[32:64]** What then is the cause why the Lord Jesus Christ determined not to give the Holy Spirit until He should be glorified? which thing before we speak of as we may be able, we must first inquire, lest that should trouble any one, in what manner the Spirit was not yet in holy men, whilst we read in the Gospel concerning the Lord Himself newly born, that Simeon by the Holy Spirit recognized Him; that Anna the widow, a prophetess, also recognized Him; that John, who baptized Him, recognized Him; that Zacharias, being filled with the Holy Ghost, said many things; that Mary herself received the Holy Ghost to conceive the Lord.

**[32:65]** We have therefore many preceding evidences of the Holy Spirit before the Lord was glorified by the resurrection of His flesh.

**[32:66]** Nor was it another spirit that the prophets also had, who proclaimed beforehand the coming of Christ.

**[32:67]** But still, there was to be a certain manner of this giving, which had not at all appeared before.

**[32:68]** For nowhere do we read before this, that men being gathered together had, by receiving the Holy Ghost, spoken in the tongues of all nations.

**[32:69]** But after His resurrection, when He first appeared to His disciples, He said to them: "Receive ye the Holy Ghost".

**[32:70]** Of this giving then it is said, "The Spirit was not given, because Jesus was not yet glorified.

**[32:71]** And He breathed upon their faces," He who with His breath enlivened the first man, and raised him up from the clay, by which breath He gave a soul to the limbs; signifying that He was the same who breathed upon their faces, that they might rise out of the mire and renounce their miry works.

**[32:72]** Then, after His resurrection, which the evangelist calls His glorifying, did the Lord first give the Holy Ghost to His disciples.

**[32:73]** Then having tarried with them forty days, as the book of the Acts of the Apostles shows, while they were seeing Him and companying with Him, He ascended into heaven in their sight.

**[32:74]** There at the end of ten days, on the day of Pentecost, He sent the Holy Ghost from above.

**[32:75]** Which having received, they, who had been gathered together in one place, as I have said, being filled withal, spoke in the tongues of all nations.

**[32:76]** 7.

**[32:77]** How then, brethren, because he that is baptized in Christ, and believes on Him, does not speak now in the tongues of all nations, are we not to believe that he has received the Holy Ghost? God forbid that our heart should be tempted by this faithlessness.

**[32:78]** Certain we are that every man receives: but only as much as the vessel of faith that he shall bring to the fountain can contain, so much does He fill of it.

**[32:79]** Since, therefore, the Holy Ghost is even now received by men, some one may say, Why is it that no man speaks in the tongues of all nations? Because the Church itself now speaks in the tongues of all nations.

**[32:80]** Before, the Church was in one nation, where it spoke in the tongues of all.

**[32:81]** By speaking then in the tongues of all, it signified what was to come to pass; that by growing among the nations, it would speak in the tongues of all.

**[32:82]** Whoso is not in this Church, does not now receive the Holy Ghost.

**[32:83]** For, being cut off and divided from the unity of the members, which unity speaks in the tongues of all, let him declare for himself; he has it not.

**[32:84]** For if he has it, let him give the sign which was given then.

**[32:85]** What do we mean by saying, Let him give the sign which was then given? Let him speak in all tongues.

**[32:86]** He answers me: How then, dost thou speak in all tongues? Clearly I do; for every tongue is mine, namely, of the body of which I am a member.

**[32:87]** The Church, spread among the nations, speaks in all tongues; the Church is the body of Christ, in this body thou art a member: therefore, since thou art a member of that body which speaks with all tongues, believe that thou too speakest with all tongues.

**[32:88]** For the unity of the members is of one mind by charity; and that unity speaks as one man then spoke.

**[32:89]** 8.

**[32:90]** Consequently, we too receive the Holy Ghost if we love the Church, if we are joined together by charity, if we rejoice in the Catholic name and faith.

**[32:91]** Let us believe, brethren; as much as every man loves the Church of Christ, so much has he the Holy Ghost.

**[32:92]** For the Spirit is given, as the apostle saith, "to manifestation".

**[32:93]** To what manifestation? Just as the same apostle saith, "For to one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom, to another the word of knowledge after the same Spirit, to another faith in the same Spirit, to another the gift of healing in one Spirit, to another the working of miracles in the same Spirit".

**[32:94]** For there are many gifts given to manifestation, but thou, it may be, hast nothing of all those I have said.

**[32:95]** If thou lovest, it is not nothing that thou hast: if thou lovest unity, whoever has aught in that unity has it also for thee.

**[32:96]** Take away envy, and what I have is thine too.

**[32:97]** The envious temper puts men apart, soundness of mind unites them.

**[32:98]** In the body, the eye alone sees; but is it for itself alone that the eye sees? It  sees both for the hand and the foot, and for all the other members.

**[32:99]** If a blow be coming against the foot, the eye does not turn away from it, so as not to take precaution.

**[32:100]** Again, in the body, the hand alone works, but is it for itself alone the hand works? For the eye also it works: for if a coming blow comes, not against the hand, but only against the face, does the hand say, I will not move, because it is not coming to me? So the foot by walking serves all the members: all the other members are silent, and the tongue speaks for all.

**[32:101]** We have therefore the Holy Spirit if we love the Church; but we love the Church if we stand firm in its union and charity.

**[32:102]** For the apostle himself, after he had said that diverse gifts were bestowed on diverse men, just as the offices of the several members, saith, "Yet I show you a still more pre-eminent way;" and begins to speak of charity.

**[32:103]** This he put before tongues of men and angels, before miracles of faith, before knowledge and prophecy, before even that great work of mercy by which a man distributes to the poor all that he possesses; and, lastly, put it before even the martyrdom of the body: before all these so great things he put charity.

**[32:104]** Have it, and thou shalt have all: for without it, whatever thou canst have will profit nothing.

**[32:105]** But that thou mayest know that the charity of which we are speaking refers to the Holy Spirit (for the question now in hand in the Gospel is concerning the Holy Spirit), hear the apostle when he says, "The charity of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit which is given to us".

**[32:106]** 9.

**[32:107]** Why then was it the will of the Lord, seeing that the Spirit's benefits in us are the greatest, because by Him the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts, to give us that Spirit after His resurrection? Why did He signify by this? In order that in our resurrection our love may be inflamed, and may part from the love of the world to run wholly towards God.

**[32:108]** For here we are born and die: let us not love this world; let us migrate hence by love; by love let us dwell above, by that love by which we love God.

**[32:109]** In this sojourn of our life let us meditate on nothing else, but that here we shall not always be, and that by good living we shall prepare a place for ourselves there, whence we shall never migrate.

**[32:110]** For our Lord Jesus Christ, after that He is risen again, "now dieth no more;" "death," as the apostle says, "shall no more have dominion over Him".

**[32:111]** Behold what we must love.

**[32:112]** If we live, if we believe on Him who is risen again, He will give us, not that which men love here who love not God, or love the more the less they love Him, but love this the less the more they love Him; but let us see what He has promised us.

**[32:113]** Not earthly and temporal riches, not honors and power in this world; for you see all these things given to wicked men, that they may not be highly prized by the good.

**[32:114]** Not, in short, bodily health itself, though it is He that gives that also, but that, as you see, He gives even to the beasts.

**[32:115]** Not long life; for what, indeed, is long that will some day have an end? It is not length of days that He has promised to His believers, as if that were a great thing, or decrepit old age, which all wish for before it comes, and all murmur at when it does come.

**[32:116]** Not beauty of person, which either bodily disease or that same old age which is desired drives away.

**[32:117]** One wishes to be beautiful, and also to live to be old: these two desires cannot agree together; if thou shalt be old, thou wilt not be beautiful; when old age comes, beauty will flee away; the vigor of beauty and the groaning of old age cannot dwell together in one body.

**[32:118]** All these things, then, are not what He promised us when He said, "He that believeth in me, let him come and drink, and out of his belly shall flow rivers of living water".

**[32:119]** He has promised us eternal life, where we shall have no fear, where we shall not be troubled, whence we shall have no migration, where we shall not die; where there is neither bewailing a predecessor deceased, nor a hoping for a successor.

**[32:120]** Accordingly, because such is what He has promised to us that love Him, and glow with the charity of the Holy Spirit, therefore He would not give us that same Spirit until He should be glorified, so that He might show in His body the life which we have not now, but which we hope for in the resurrection.

**[33:1]** Tractate XXXIII.

**[33:2]** Chapter VII.

**[33:3]** 40–53; VIII.

**[33:4]** 1–11  1.

**[33:5]** You remember, my beloved, that in the last discourse, by occasion of the passage of the Gospel read, we spoke to you concerning the Holy Spirit.

**[33:6]** When the Lord had invited those that believe on Him to this drinking, speaking among those who meditated to lay hold of Him, and sought to kill Him, and were not able, because it was not His will: well, when He had spoken these things, there arose a dissension among the multitude concerning Him; some thinking that He was the very Christ, others saying that Christ shall not arise from Galilee.

**[33:7]** But they who had been sent to take Him returned clear of the crime and full of admiration.

**[33:8]** For they even gave witness to His divine doctrine, when those by whom they had been sent asked, "Why have ye not brought him?" They answered that they had never heard a man so speak: "For not any man so speaks".

**[33:9]** But He spake thus, because He was God and man.

**[33:10]** But the Pharisees, repelling their testimony, said to them: "Are ye also deceived?" We see, indeed, that you also have been charmed by his discourses.

**[33:11]** "Hath any one of the rulers or the Pharisees believed on him? But this multitude who know not the law are cursed".

**[33:12]** They who knew not the law believed on Him who had sent the law; and those men who were teaching the law despised Him, that it might be fulfilled which the Lord Himself had said, "I am come that they who see not may see, and they that see may be made blind".

**[33:13]** For the Pharisees, the teachers of the law, were made blind, and the people that knew not the law, and yet believed on the author of the law, were enlightened.

**[33:14]** 2.

**[33:15]** "Nicodemus," however, "one of the Pharisees, who had come to the Lord by night,"—not indeed as being himself unbelieving, but timid; for therefore he came by night to the light, because he wished to be enlightened and feared to be known;—Nicodemus, I say, answered the Jews, "Doth our law judge a man before it hear him, and know what he doeth?" For they perversely wished to condemn before they examined.

**[33:16]** Nicodemus indeed knew, or rather believed, that if only they were willing to give Him a patient hearing, they would perhaps become like those who were sent to take Him, but preferred to believe.

**[33:17]** They answered, from the prejudice of their heart, what they had answered to those officers, "Art thou also a Galilean?" That is, one seduced as it were by the Galilean.

**[33:18]** For the Lord was said to be a Galilean, because His parents were from the city of Nazareth.

**[33:19]** I have said "His parents" in regard to Mary, not as regards the seed of man; for on earth He sought but a mother, He had already a Father on high.

**[33:20]** For His nativity on both sides was marvellous: divine without mother, human without father.

**[33:21]** What, then, said those would-be doctors of the law to Nicodemus? "Search the Scriptures, and see that out of Galilee ariseth no prophet".

**[33:22]** Yet the Lord of the prophets arose thence.

**[33:23]** "They returned," saith the evangelist, "every man to his own house".

**[33:24]** 3.

**[33:25]** "Thence Jesus went unto the mount;" namely, to mount "Olivet,"—unto the fruitful mount, unto the mount of ointment, unto the mount of chrism.

**[33:26]** For where, indeed, but on mount Olivet did it become the Christ to teach? For the name of Christ is from chrism; χρισμα in the Greek, is called in Latin unctio, an anointing.

**[33:27]** And He has anointed us for this reason, because He has made us wrestlers against the devil.

**[33:28]** "And early in the morning He came again into the temple, and all the people came unto Him; and He sat down and taught them".

**[33:29]** And He was not taken, for He did not yet deign to suffer.

**[33:30]** 4.

**[33:31]** And now observe wherein the Lord's gentleness was tempted by His enemies.

**[33:32]** "And the scribes and Pharisees brought to Him a woman just taken in adultery: and they set her in the midst, and said to Him, Master, this woman has just been taken in adultery.

**[33:33]** Now Moses in the law commanded us, that such should be stoned: but what sayest thou? But this they said, tempting Him, that they might accuse Him".

**[33:34]** Why accuse Him? Had they detected Himself in any misdeed; or was that woman said to have been concerned with Him in any manner? What, then, is the meaning of "tempting Him, that they might accuse Him"? We understand, brethren, that a wonderful gentleness shone out pre-eminently in the Lord.

**[33:35]** They observed that He was very meek, very gentle: for of Him it had been previously foretold, "Gird Thy sword upon Thy thigh, O most Mighty; in Thy splendor and beauty  urge on, march on prosperously, and reign, because of truth, and meekness, and righteousness".

**[33:36]** Accordingly, as a teacher, He brought truth; as a deliverer, He brought gentleness; as a protector, He brought righteousness.

**[33:37]** That He was to reign on account of these things, the prophet had by the Holy Spirit foretold.

**[33:38]** When He spoke His truth was acknowledged; when He was not provoked to anger against His enemies, His meekness was praised.

**[33:39]** Whilst, therefore, in respect of these two,—namely, His truth and meekness,—His enemies were tormented with malice and envy; in respect of the third,—namely, righteousness,—they laid a stumbling-block for Him.

**[33:40]** In what way? Because the law had commanded the adulterers to be stoned, and surely the law could not command what was unjust: if any man should say other than the law had commanded, he would be detected as unjust.

**[33:41]** Therefore they said among themselves, "He is accounted true, he appears to be gentle; an accusation must be sought against him in respect of righteousness.

**[33:42]** Let us bring before him a woman taken in adultery; let us say to him what is ordered in the law concerning such: if he shall approve her being stoned, he will not show his gentleness; if he consent to let her go, he will not keep righteousness.

**[33:43]** But, say they, that he may not lose the reputation of gentleness, for which he is become an object of love to the people, without doubt he will say that she must be let go.

**[33:44]** Hence we find an opportunity of accusing him, and we charge him as being a transgressor of the law: saying to him, Thou art an enemy to the law; thou answerest against Moses, nay, against Him who gave the law through Moses; thou art worthy of death: thou too must be stoned with this woman".

**[33:45]** By these words and sentiments they might possibly be able to inflame envy against Him, to urge accusation, and cause His condemnation to be eagerly demanded.

**[33:46]** But this against whom? It was perversity against rectitude, falsehood against the truth, the corrupt heart against the upright heart, folly against wisdom.

**[33:47]** When did such men prepare snares, into which they did not first thrust their own heads? Behold, the Lord in answering them will both keep righteousness, and will not depart from gentleness.

**[33:48]** He was not taken for whom the snare was laid, but rather they were taken who laid it, because they believed not on Him who could pull them out of the net.

**[33:49]** 5.

**[33:50]** What answer, then, did the Lord Jesus make? How answered the Truth? How answered Wisdom? How answered that Righteousness against which a false accusation was ready? He did not say, Let her not be stoned; lest He should seem to speak against the law.

**[33:51]** But God forbid that He should say, Let her be stoned: for He came not to lose what He had found, but to seek what was lost.

**[33:52]** What then did He answer? See you how full it is of righteousness, how full of meekness and truth! "He that is without sin of you," saith He, "let him first cast a stone at her".

**[33:53]** O answer of Wisdom! How He sent them unto themselves! For without they stood to accuse and censure, themselves they examined not inwardly: they saw the adulteress, they looked not into themselves.

**[33:54]** Transgressors of the law, they wished the law to be fulfilled, and this by heedlessly accusing; not really fulfilling it, as if condemning adulteries by chastity.

**[33:55]** You have heard, O Jews, you have heard, O Pharisees, you have heard, O teachers of the law, the guardian of the law, but have not yet understood Him as the Lawgiver.

**[33:56]** What else does He signify to you when He writes with His finger on the ground? For the law was written with the finger of God; but written on stone because of the hard-hearted.

**[33:57]** The Lord now wrote on the ground, because He was seeking fruit.

**[33:58]** You have heard then, Let the law be fulfilled, let the adulteress be stoned.

**[33:59]** But is it by punishing her that the law is to be fulfilled by those that ought to be punished? Let each of you consider himself, let him enter into himself, ascend the judgment-seat of his own mind, place himself at the bar of his own conscience, oblige himself to confess.

**[33:60]** For he knows what he is: for "no man knoweth the things of a man, but the spirit of man which is in him".

**[33:61]** Each looking carefully into himself, finds himself a sinner.

**[33:62]** Yes, indeed.

**[33:63]** Hence, either let this woman go, or together with her receive ye the penalty of the law.

**[33:64]** Had He said, Let not the adulteress be stoned, He would be proved unjust: had He said, Let her be stoned, He would not appear gentle: let Him say what it became Him to say, both the gentle and the just, "Whoso is without sin of you, let him first cast a stone at her".

**[33:65]** This is the voice of Justice: Let her, the sinner, be punished, but not by sinners: let the law be fulfilled, but not by the transgressors of the law.

**[33:66]** This certainly is the voice of justice: by which justice, those men pierced through as if by a dart, looking into themselves and finding themselves guilty, "one after another all withdrew".

**[33:67]** The two were left alone, the wretched woman and Mercy.

**[33:68]** But the Lord, having struck them through with that dart of  justice, deigned not to heed their fall, but, turning away His look from them, "again He wrote with His finger on the ground".

**[33:69]** 6.

**[33:70]** But when that woman was left alone, and all they were gone out, He raised His eyes to the woman.

**[33:71]** We have heard the voice of justice, let us also hear the voice of clemency.

**[33:72]** For I suppose that woman was the more terrified when she had heard it said by the Lord, "He that is without sin of you, let him first cast a stone at her".

**[33:73]** But they, turning their thought to themselves, and by that very withdrawal having confessed concerning themselves, had left the woman with her great sin to Him who was without sin.

**[33:74]** And because she had heard this, "He that is without sin.

**[33:75]** let him first cast a stone at her," she expected to be punished by Him in whom sin could not be found.

**[33:76]** But He, who had driven back her adversaries with the tongue of justice, raising the eyes of clemency towards her, asked her, "Hath no man condemned thee?" She answered, "No man, Lord".

**[33:77]** And He said, "Neither do I condemn thee;" by whom, perhaps, thou didst fear to be condemned, because in me thou hast not found sin.

**[33:78]** "Neither will I condemn thee".

**[33:79]** What is this, O Lord? Dost Thou therefore favor sins? Not so, evidently.

**[33:80]** Mark what follows: "Go, henceforth sin no more".

**[33:81]** Therefore the Lord did also condemn, but condemned sins, not man.

**[33:82]** For if He were a patron of sin, He would say, Neither will I condemn thee; go, live as thou wilt: be secure in my deliverance; how much soever thou wilt sin, I will deliver thee from all punishment even of hell, and from the tormentors of the infernal world.

**[33:83]** He said not this.

**[33:84]** 7.

**[33:85]** Let them take heed, then, who love His gentleness in the Lord, and let them fear His truth.

**[33:86]** For "The Lord is sweet and right".

**[33:87]** Thou lovest Him in that He is sweet; fear Him in that He is right.

**[33:88]** As the meek, He said, "I held my peace;" but as the just, He said, "Shall I always be silent?" "The Lord is merciful and pitiful".

**[33:89]** So He is, certainly.

**[33:90]** Add yet further, "Long-suffering;" add yet further, "And very pitiful:" but fear what comes last, "And true".

**[33:91]** For those whom He now bears with as sinners, He will judge as despisers.

**[33:92]** "Or despisest thou the riches of His long-suffering and gentleness; not knowing that the forbearance of God leadeth thee to repentance? But thou, after thy hardness and impenitent heart, treasurest up for thyself wrath against the day of wrath and the revelation of the righteous judgment of God; who will render to every man according to his deeds".

**[33:93]** The Lord is gentle, the Lord is long-suffering, the Lord is pitiful; but the Lord is also just, the Lord is also true.

**[33:94]** He bestows on thee space for correction; but thou lovest the delay of judgment more than the amendment of thy ways.

**[33:95]** Hast thou been a bad man yesterday? To-day be a good man.

**[33:96]** Hast thou gone on in thy wickedness to-day? At any rate change to-morrow.

**[33:97]** Thou art always expecting, and from the mercy of God makest exceeding great promises to thyself.

**[33:98]** As if He, who has promised thee pardon through repentance, promised thee also a longer life.

**[33:99]** How knowest thou what to-morrow may bring forth? Rightly thou sayest in thy heart: When I shall have corrected my ways, God will put all my sins away.

**[33:100]** We cannot deny that God has promised pardon to those that have amended their ways and are converted.

**[33:101]** For in what prophet thou readest to me that God has promised pardon to him that amends, thou dost not read to me that God has promised thee a long life.

**[33:102]** 8.

**[33:103]** From both, then, men are in danger; both from hoping and despairing, from contrary things, from contrary affections.

**[33:104]** Who is deceived by hoping? He who says, God is good, God is merciful, let me do what I please, what I like; let me give loose reins to my lusts, let me gratify the desires of my soul.

**[33:105]** Why this? Because God is merciful, God is good, God is kind.

**[33:106]** These men are in danger by hope.

**[33:107]** And those are in danger from despair, who, having fallen into grievous sins, fancying that they can no more be pardoned upon repentance, and believing that they are without doubt doomed to damnation, do say with themselves, We are already destined to be damned, why not do what we please with the disposition of gladiators destined to the sword.

**[33:108]** This is the reason that desperate men are dangerous: for, having no longer aught to fear, they are to be feared exceedingly.

**[33:109]** Despair kills these; hope, those.

**[33:110]** The mind is tossed to and fro between hope and despair.

**[33:111]** Thou hast to fear lest hope slay thee; and, when thou hopest much from mercy, lest thou fall into judgment: again, thou hast to fear lest despair slay thee, and, when thou thinkest that the grievous sins which thou hast committed cannot be forgiven thee, thou dost not repent, and thou incurrest the sentence of Wisdom, which says, "I also will laugh at your perdition".

**[33:112]** How then does the Lord treat those who are in danger from both these maladies? To those who are in danger from hope, He says, "Be  not slow to be converted to the Lord, neither put it off from day to day; for suddenly His anger will come, and in the time of vengeance, will utterly destroy thee".

**[33:113]** To those who are in danger from despair, what does He say? "In what day soever the wicked man shall be converted, I will forget all his iniquities".

**[33:114]** Accordingly, for the sake of those who are in danger by despair, He has offered us a refuge of pardon; and because of those who are in danger by hope, and are deluded by delays, He has made the day of death uncertain.

**[33:115]** Thou knowest not when thy last day may come.

**[33:116]** Art thou ungrateful because thou hast to-day on which thou mayest be improved? Thus therefore said He to the woman, "Neither will I condemn thee;" but, being made secure concerning the past, beware of the future.

**[33:117]** "Neither will I condemn thee:" I have blotted out what thou hast done; keep what I have commanded thee, that thou mayest find what I have promised.

**[34:1]** Tractate XXXIV.

**[34:2]** Chapter VIII.

**[34:3]** 12  1.

**[34:4]** What we have just heard and attentively received, as the holy Gospel was being read, I doubt not that all of us have also endeavored to understand, and that each of us according to his measure apprehended what he could of so great a matter as that which has been read; and while the bread of the word is laid out, no one can complain that he has tasted nothing.

**[34:5]** But again I doubt not that there is scarcely any who has understood the whole.

**[34:6]** Nevertheless, even should there be any who may sufficiently understand the words of our Lord Jesus Christ now read out of the Gospel, let him bear with our ministry, whilst, if possible, with His assistance, we may, by treating thereof, cause that either all or many may understand that which a few are joyful of having understood for themselves.

**[34:7]** 2.

**[34:8]** I think that what the Lord says, "I am the light of the world, "is clear to those that have eyes, by which they are made partakers of this light: but they who have not eyes except in the flesh alone, wonder at what is said by the Lord Jesus Christ, "I am the light of the world".

**[34:9]** And perhaps there may not be wanting some one too who says with himself: Whether perhaps the Lord Christ is that sun which by its rising and setting causes the day? For there have not been wanting heretics who thought this.

**[34:10]** The Manichaeans have supposed that the Lord Christ is that sun which is visible to carnal eyes, exposed and public to be seen, not only by men, but by the beasts.

**[34:11]** But the right faith of the Catholic Church rejects such a fiction, and perceives it to be a devilish doctrine: not only by believing acknowledges it to be such, but in the case of whom it can, proves it even by reasoning.

**[34:12]** Let us therefore reject this kind of error, which the Holy Church has anathematized from the beginning.

**[34:13]** Let us not suppose that the Lord Jesus Christ is this sun which we see rising from the east, setting in the west; to whose course succeeds night, whose rays are obscured by a cloud, which removes from place to place by a set motion: the Lord Christ is not such a thing as this.

**[34:14]** The Lord Christ is not the sun that was made, but He by whom the sun was made.

**[34:15]** For "all things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made".

**[34:16]** 3.

**[34:17]** There is therefore a Light which made this light of the sun: let us love this Light, let us long to understand it, let us thirst for the same; that, with itself for our guide, we may at length come to it, and that we may so live in it that we may never die.

**[34:18]** This is indeed that Light of which prophecy long ago going before thus sang in the psalm: "O Lord, Thou shalt save men and beasts; even as Thy mercy is multiplied, O God".

**[34:19]** These are the words of the holy psalm: mark ye what the ancient discourse of holy men of God did premise concerning such a light.

**[34:20]** "Men," saith it, "and beasts Thou shalt save, O Lord; even as Thy mercy is multiplied, O God".

**[34:21]** For since Thou art God, and hast manifold mercy, the same multiplicity of Thy mercy reaches not only to men whom Thou hast created in Thine own image, but even to the beasts which Thou hast made subservient to men.

**[34:22]** For He who gives salvation to man, the same gives salvation also to the beast.

**[34:23]** Do not blush to think this of the Lord thy  God: nay, rather believe this and trust it, and see thou think not otherwise.

**[34:24]** He that saves thee, the same saves thy horse and thy sheep; to come to the very least, also thy hen: "Salvation is of the Lord," and God saves these.

**[34:25]** Thou art uneasy, thou questionest.

**[34:26]** I wonder why thou doubtest.

**[34:27]** Shall He disdain to save who deigned to create? Of the Lord is the saving of angels, of men, and of beasts: "Salvation is of the Lord".

**[34:28]** Just as no man is from himself, so no man is saved by himself.

**[34:29]** Therefore most truly and right well doth the psalm say, "O Lord, Thou shall save men and beasts".

**[34:30]** Why? "Even as thy mercy is multiplied, O God".

**[34:31]** For Thou art God, Thou hast created, Thou savest: Thou gavest being, Thou givest to be in health.

**[34:32]** 4.

**[34:33]** Since, therefore, as the mercy of God is multiplied, men and beasts are saved by Him, have not men something else which God as Creator bestows on them, which He bestows not on the beasts? Is there no distinction between the living creature made after the image of God, and the living creature made subject to the image of God? Clearly there is: beyond that salvation common to us with the dumb animals, there is what God bestows on us, but not on them.

**[34:34]** What is this? Follow on in the same psalm: "But the sons of men shall hope under the covert of Thy wings".

**[34:35]** Having now a salvation in common with their cattle, "the sons of men shall hope under the covert of Thy wings".

**[34:36]** They have one salvation in fact, another in hope.

**[34:37]** This salvation which is at present is common to men and cattle; but there is another which men hope for; and which they who hope for receive, they who despair of receive not.

**[34:38]** For it saith, "The sons of men shall hope under covert of Thy wings".

**[34:39]** And they that perseveringly hope are protected by Thee, lest they be cast down from their hope by the devil: "Under covert of Thy wings they shall hope".

**[34:40]** If they shall hope, what shall they hope for, but for what the cattle shall not have? "They shall be fully drunk with the fatness of Thy house; and from the torrent of Thy pleasure Thou shalt give them drink".

**[34:41]** What sort of wine is that with which it is laudable to be drunk? What sort of wine is that which disturbs not the mind, but directs it? What sort of wine is that which makes perpetually sane, and makes not insane by drinking? "They shall be fully drunk".

**[34:42]** How? "With the fatness of Thy house; and from the torrent of Thy pleasure Thou shalt give them drink".

**[34:43]** How so? "Because with Thee is the fountain of life".

**[34:44]** The very fountain of life walked on the earth, the same who said, "Whoso thirsts, let him come unto me".

**[34:45]** Behold the fountain! But we begin to speak about the light, and to handle the question laid down from the Gospel concerning the light.

**[34:46]** For we read how the Lord said, "I am the light of the world".

**[34:47]** Thence arose a question, lest any one, carnally understanding this, should fancy this light to mean the sun: we came thence to the psalm, which having considered, we found meanwhile that the Lord is the fountain of life.

**[34:48]** Drink and live.

**[34:49]** "With Thee," it saith, "is the fountain of life;" therefore, "under the shadow of Thy wings the sons of men hope," seeking to be full drunk with this fountain.

**[34:50]** But we were speaking of the Light.

**[34:51]** Follow on, then; for the prophet, having said, "With Thee is the fountain of life," went on to add, "In Thy light shall we see light,"—God of God, Light of Light.

**[34:52]** By this Light the sun's light was made; and the Light which made the sun, under which He also made us, was made under the sun for our sake.

**[34:53]** That Light which made the sun, was made, I say, under the sun for our sake.

**[34:54]** Do not despise the cloud of the flesh; with that cloud it is covered, not to be obscured, but to be moderated.

**[34:55]** 5.

**[34:56]** That unfailing Light, the Light of wisdom, speaking through the cloud of the flesh, says to men, "I am the light of the world; he that followeth me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life".

**[34:57]** How He has withdrawn thee from the eyes of the flesh, and recalled thee to the eyes of the heart! For it is not enough to say, "Whoso followeth me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have light;" He added too, "of life;" even as it was there said, "For with Thee is the fountain of life".

**[34:58]** See thus, my brethren, how the words of the Lord agree with the truth of that psalm: both there, the light is put with the fountain of life, and by the Lord it is said, "light of life".

**[34:59]** But for bodily use, light and fountain are different things: our mouths seek a fountain, our eyes light; when we thirst we seek a fountain, when we are in darkness we seek light; and if we chance to thirst in the night, we kindle a light to come to a fountain.

**[34:60]** Not so with God: light and fountain are the same thing: He who shines for thee that thou mayest see, the same flows for thee that thou mayest drink.

**[34:61]** 6.

**[34:62]** You see, then, my brethren, you see, if you see inwardly, what kind of light this is, of which the Lord says, "He that followeth me shall not walk in darkness".

**[34:63]** Follow the sun, and let us see if thou wilt not walk in  darkness.

**[34:64]** Behold, by rising it comes forth to thee; it goes by its course towards the west.

**[34:65]** Perhaps thy journey is towards the east: unless thou goest in a contrary direction to that in which it travels, thou wilt certainly err by following it, and instead of east wilt get to the west.

**[34:66]** If thou follow it by land, thou wilt go wrong; if the mariner follow it by sea, he will go wrong.

**[34:67]** Finally, it seems to thee, suppose, that thou must follow the sun, and thou also travellest thyself towards the west, whither it also travels; let us see after it has set if thou wilt not walk in darkness.

**[34:68]** See how, although thou art not willing to desert it, yet it will desert thee, to finish the day by necessity of its service.

**[34:69]** But our Lord Jesus Christ, even when He was not manifest to all through the cloud of His flesh, was yet at the same time holding all things by the power of His wisdom.

**[34:70]** Thy God is whole everywhere: if thou fall not off from Him, He will never fall away from thee.

**[34:71]** 7.

**[34:72]** Accordingly, "He that followeth me," saith He, "shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life".

**[34:73]** What He has promised, He put in a word of the future tense; for He says not has, but "shall have the light of life".

**[34:74]** Yet He does not say, He that shall follow me; but, he that does follow me.

**[34:75]** What it is our duty to do, He put in the present tense; but what He has promised to them that do it, He has indicated by a word of the future tense.

**[34:76]** "He that followeth, shall have".

**[34:77]** That followeth now, shall have hereafter: followeth now by faith, shall have hereafter by sight.

**[34:78]** For, "whilst we are in the body," saith the apostle, "we are absent from the Lord: for we walk by faith, not by sight".

**[34:79]** When shall we walk by sight? When we shall have the light of life, when we shall have come to that vision, when this night shall have passed away.

**[34:80]** Of that day, indeed, which is to arise, it is said, "In the morning I will stand near thee, and contemplate thee".

**[34:81]** What means "in the morning"? When the night of this world is over, when the terrors of temptations are over, when that lion which goeth about roaring in the night, seeking whom it may devour, is vanquished.

**[34:82]** "In the morning I will stand near thee, and contemplate".

**[34:83]** Now what do we think, brethren, to be our duty for the present time, but what is again said in the psalm, "Every night through will I wash my couch; I will moisten my bed with my tears"?  Every night through, saith he, I will weep; I will burn with desire for the light.

**[34:84]** The Lord sees my desire: for another psalm says to Him, "All my desire is before Thee; and my groaning is not hid from Thee".

**[34:85]** Dost thou desire gold? Thou canst be seen; for, while seeking gold, thou wilt be manifest to men.

**[34:86]** Dost thou desire corn? Thou askest one that has it; whom also thou informest, while seeking to get at that which thou desirest.

**[34:87]** Dost thou desire God? Who sees, but God? From whom, then, dost thou seek God, as thou seekest bread, water, gold, silver, corn? From whom dost thou seek God, except from God? He is sought from Himself who has promised Himself.

**[34:88]** Let the soul extend her desire, and with more capacious bosom seek to comprehend that which "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, nor hath entered into the heart of man".

**[34:89]** Desire it we can, long for it we can, pant after it we can; but worthily conceive it, worthily unfold it in words, we cannot.

**[34:90]** 8.
