**[38:26]** But on hearing these words, as is usual with those whose thoughts are carnal, who judge after the flesh, and hear and apprehend everything in a carnal way, they said, "Will he kill himself because he said, Whither I go ye cannot come".

**[38:27]** Foolish words, and overflowing with stupidity! For why could they not go whither He would have proceeded had He killed Himself? Were not they themselves to die? What, then, means, "Will he kill himself because he said, Whither I go ye cannot come?" If He spake of man's death, what man is there that does not die? Therefore, by "whither I go" He meant, not the going to death, but whither He was going Himself after death.

**[38:28]** Such, then, was their answer, because they did not understand.

**[38:29]** 4.

**[38:30]** And what said the Lord to those who savored of the earth? "And He said unto them, Ye are from beneath".

**[38:31]** For this cause ye savor of the earth, because ye lick dust like serpents.

**[38:32]** Ye eat earth! What does it mean? Ye feed on earthly things, ye delight in earthly things, ye gape after earthly things, ye have no heart for what is above.

**[38:33]** "Ye are from beneath: I am from above.

**[38:34]** Ye are of this world: I am not of this world".

**[38:35]** For how could He be of the world, by whom the world was made? All that are of the world come after the world, because the world preceded; and so man is of the world.

**[38:36]** But Christ was first, and then the world; and since Christ was before the world, before Christ there was nothing: because "In the beginning was the Word; all things were made by Him".

**[38:37]** He, therefore, was of that which is above.

**[38:38]** But of what that is above? Of the air? Perish the thought! there the birds wing their flight.

**[38:39]** Of the sky that we see? Again I say, Perish the thought! it is there that the stars and sun and moon revolve.

**[38:40]** Of the angels? Neither is this to be understood: by Him who made all things were the angels also made.

**[38:41]** Of what, then, above is Christ? Of the Father Himself.

**[38:42]** Nothing is above that God who begat the Word equal with Himself, co-eternal with Himself, only-begotten, timeless, that by Him time's own foundations should be laid.

**[38:43]** Understand, then, Christ as from above, so as in thy thought to get beyond everything that is made,—the whole creation together, every material body, every created spirit, everything in any way subject to change: rise above all, as John rose, in order to reach this: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

**[38:44]** 5.

**[38:45]** Therefore said He, "I am from above.

**[38:46]** Ye are of this world: I am not of this world.

**[38:47]** I said therefore unto you, that ye shall die in your sins".

**[38:48]** He has explained to us, brethren, what He wished to be understood by "ye are of this world".

**[38:49]** He said therefore in fact, "Ye are of this world," because they were sinners, because they were unrighteous, because they were unbelieving, because they savored of the earthly.

**[38:50]** For what is your opinion as regards the holy apostles? What difference was there between the Jews and the apostles? As great as between darkness and light, as between faith and unbelief, as between piety and impiety, as between hope and despair, as between love and avarice: surely the difference was great.

**[38:51]** What then, because there was such a difference, were the apostles not of the world? If thy thoughts turn to the manner of their birth, and whence they came, inasmuch as all of them had come from Adam, they were of this world.

**[38:52]** But what said the Lord Himself to them? "I have chosen you out of the world".

**[38:53]** Those, then, who were of the world, became not of the world, and began to belong to Him by whom the world was made.

**[38:54]** But these men continued to be of the world, to whom it was said, "Ye shall die in your sins".

**[38:55]** 6.

**[38:56]** Let none then, brethren, say, I am not of this world.

**[38:57]** Whoever thou art as a man, thou art of this world; but He who made the world came to thee, and delivered thee from this world.

**[38:58]** If the world delights thee, thou wishest always to be unclean (immundus); but if this world no longer delight thee, thou art already clean (mundus).

**[38:59]** And yet, if through  some infirmity the world still delight thee, let Him who cleanseth (mundat) dwell in thee, and thou too shalt be clean.

**[38:60]** But if thou art once clean, thou wilt not continue in the world; neither wilt thou hear what was heard by the Jews, "Ye shall die in your sins".

**[38:61]** For we are all born with sin; we have all in living added to that wherein we were born, and have since become more of the world than when we were born of our parents.

**[38:62]** And where should we be, had He not come, who was wholly free from sin, to expiate all sin? And so, because in Him the Jews believed not, they deservedly heard [the sentence], "Ye shall die in your sins;" for in no way could ye, who were born with sin, be without sin; and yet, said He, if ye believe in me, although it is still true that ye were born with sin, yet in your sin ye shall not die.

**[38:63]** The whole misery, then, of the Jews was just this, not to have sin, but to die in their sins.

**[38:64]** From this it is that every Christian ought to seek to escape; because of this we have recourse to baptism; on this account do those whose lives are in danger from sickness or any other cause become anxious for help; for this also is the sucking child carried by his mother with pious hands to the church, that he may not go out into the world without baptism, and die in the sin wherein he was born.

**[38:65]** Most wretched surely the condition and miserable the lot of these men, who heard from those truth-speaking lips, "Ye shall die in your sins!"  7.

**[38:66]** But He explains whence this should befall them: "For if ye believe not that I am [He], ye shall die in your sins".

**[38:67]** I believe, brethren, that among the multitude who listened to the Lord, there were those also who should yet believe.

**[38:68]** But against all, as it were, had that most severe sentence gone forth, "Ye shall die in your sin;" and thereby even from those who should yet believe had hope been withdrawn: the others were roused to fury, they to fear; yea, to more than fear, they were brought now to despair.

**[38:69]** But He revived their hope; for He added, "If ye believe not that I am, ye shall die in your sins".

**[38:70]** Therefore if ye do believe that I am, ye shall not die in your sins.

**[38:71]** Hope was restored to the desponding, the sleeping were aroused, their hearts got a fresh awakening; and thereafter very many believed, as the Gospel itself attests in the sequel.

**[38:72]** For members of Christ were there, who had not yet become attached to the body of Christ; and among that people by whom He was crucified, by whom He was hanged on a tree, by whom when hanging He was mocked, by whom He was wounded with the spear, by whom gall and vinegar were given Him to drink, were the members of Christ, for whose sake He said, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do".

**[38:73]** And what will a convert not be forgiven, if the shedding of Christ's blood is forgiven? What murderer need despair, if he was restored to hope by whom even Christ was slain? After this many believed; they were presented with Christ's blood as a gift, that they might drink it for their salvation, rather than be held guilty of shedding it.

**[38:74]** Who can despair? And if the thief was saved on the cross,—a murderer shortly before, a little afterwards accused, convicted, condemned, hanged, delivered,—wonder not.

**[38:75]** The place of his conviction was that of his condemnation; while that of his conversion was the place also of his deliverance.

**[38:76]** Among this people, then, to whom the Lord was speaking, were those who should yet die in their sin: there were those also who should yet believe on Him who spake, and find deliverance from all their sin.

**[38:77]** 8.

**[38:78]** But look at this which is said by Christ the Lord: "If ye believe not that I am, ye shall die in your sins".

**[38:79]** What is this, "If ye believe not that I am?" "I am" what? There is nothing added; and because He added nothing, He left much to be inferred.

**[38:80]** For He was expected to say what He was, and yet He said it not.

**[38:81]** What was He expected to say? Perhaps, "If ye believe not that I am" Christ; "if ye believe not that I am" the Son of God; "if ye believe not that I am" the Word of the Father; "if ye believe not that I am" the founder of the world; "if ye believe not that I am" the former and re-former, the creator and re-creator, the maker and re-maker of man;—"if ye believe not that I am" this, "ye shall die in your sins".

**[38:82]** There is much implied in His only saying "I am;" for so also had God said to Moses, "I am who am".

**[38:83]** Who can adequately express what that am means? God by His angel sent His servant Moses to deliver His people out of Egypt (you have read and know what you now hear; but I recall it to your minds); He sent him trembling, self-excusing, but obedient.

**[38:84]** And while thus excusing himself, he said to God, whom he understood to be speaking in the person of the angel: If the people say to me, And who is the God that hath sent thee? what shall I say to them? And the Lord answered him, "I am who am;" and added, "Thou shalt  say to the children of Israel, He who is hath sent me to you".

**[38:85]** There also He says not, I am God; or, I am the framer of the world; or, I am the creator of all things; or, I am the multiplier of the very people to be delivered: but only this, "I am who am;" and, "Thou shall say to the children of Israel, He who is".

**[38:86]** He added not, Who is your God, who is the God of your fathers; but said only this: "He who is hath sent me to you".

**[38:87]** Perhaps it was too much even for Moses himself, as it is too much for us also, and much more so for us, to understand the meaning of such words, "I am who am;" and, "He who is hath sent me to you".

**[38:88]** And supposing that Moses comprehended it, when would those to whom he was sent comprehend it? The Lord therefore put aside what man could not comprehend, and added what he could; for He said also besides, "I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob".

**[38:89]** This thou canst comprehend; for "I am who am," what mind can comprehend?  9.

**[38:90]** What then of us? Shall we venture to say anything on such words, "I am who am;" or rather on this, that you have heard the Lord saying, "If ye believe not that I am, ye shall die in your sins"? Shall I venture with these feeble and scarcely existing powers of mine to discuss the meaning of that which Christ the Lord hath said, "If ye believe not that I am"? I shall venture to ask the Lord Himself.

**[38:91]** Listen to me as one asking rather than discussing, inquiring rather than assuming, learning rather than teaching, and fail not yourselves also to be asking with me or through me.

**[38:92]** The Lord Himself, who is everywhere, is also at hand.

**[38:93]** Let Him hear the feeling that prompts to ask, and grant the fruit of understanding.

**[38:94]** For in what words, even were it so that I comprehend something, can I convey to your hearts what I comprehend? What voice is adequate? what eloquence sufficient? what powers of intelligence? what faculty of utterance?  10.

**[38:95]** I shall speak, then, to our Lord Jesus Christ; I shall speak and may He be pleased to hear me.

**[38:96]** I believe He is present, I am fully assured of it; for He Himself has said, "Lo, I am with you even to the end of the world".

**[38:97]** O Lord our God, what is that which Thou saidst, "If ye believe not that I am"? For what is there that belongs not to the things Thou hast made? Does not heaven so belong? Does not the earth? Does not everything in earth and heaven? Does not man himself to whom Thou speakest? Does not the angel whom Thou sendest? If all these are things made by Thee, what is that existence Thou hast retained as something exclusively Thine own, which Thou hast given to none besides, that Thou mightest be such Thyself alone? For how do I hear "I am who am," as if there were none besides? and how do I hear "If ye believe not that I am"? For had they no existence who heard Him? Yea, though they were sinners, they were men.

**[38:98]** What then can I do? What that existence is, let Him tell my heart, let Him tell, let Him declare it within; let the inner man hear, the mind apprehend this true existence; for such existence is always unvarying in character.

**[38:99]** For a thing, anything whatever (I have begun as it were to dispute, and have left off inquiring.

**[38:100]** Perhaps I wish to speak what I have heard.

**[38:101]** May He grant enlargement to my hearing, and to yours, while I speak);—for anything, whatever in short be its excellence, if it is changeable, does not truly exist; for there is no true existence wherever non-existence has also a place.

**[38:102]** For whatever can be changed, so far as changed, it is not that which was: if it is no longer what it was, a kind of death has therein taken place; something that was there has been eliminated, and exists no more.

**[38:103]** Blackness has died out in the silvery locks of the patriarch, comeliness in the body of the careworn and crooked old man, strength in the body of the languishing, the [previous] standing posture in the body of one walking, walking in the body of one standing, walking and standing in the body of one reclining, speech in the tongue of the silent;—whatever changes, and is what it was not, I see there a kind of life in that which is, and death in that which was.

**[38:104]** In fine, when we say of one deceased, Where is that person? we are answered, He was.

**[38:105]** O Truth, it is thou [alone] that truly art! For in all actions and movements of ours, yea, in every activity of the creature, I find two times, the past and the future.

**[38:106]** I seek for the present, nothing stands still: what I have said is no longer present; what I am going to say is not yet come: what I have done is no longer present; what I am going to do is not yet come: the life I have lived is no longer present; the life I have still to live is not yet come.

**[38:107]** Past and future I find in every creature-movement: in truth, which is abiding, past and future I find not, but the present alone, and that unchangeably, which has no place in the creature.

**[38:108]** Sift the mutations of things, thou wilt find was and will be:  think on God, thou wilt find the is, where was and will be cannot exist.

**[38:109]** To be so then thyself, rise beyond the boundaries of time.

**[38:110]** But who can transcend the powers of his being? May He raise us thither who said to the Father, "I will that they also be with me where I am".

**[38:111]** And so, in making this promise, that we should not die in our sins, the Lord Jesus Christ, I think, said nothing else by these words, "If ye believe not that I am;" yea, by these words I think He meant nothing else than this, "If ye believe not that I am" God, "ye shall die in your sins".

**[38:112]** Well, God be thanked that He said, "If ye believe not," and did not say, If ye comprehend not.

**[38:113]** For who can comprehend this? Or is it so, since I have ventured to speak and you have seemed to understand, that you have indeed comprehended somewhat of a subject so unspeakable? If then thou comprehendest not, faith sets thee free.

**[38:114]** Therefore also the Lord said not, If ye comprehend not that I am; but said what they were capable of attaining, "If ye believe not that I am, ye shall die in your sins".

**[38:115]** 11.

**[38:116]** And savoring as these men always did of the earth, and ever hearing and answering according to the flesh, what did they say to Him? "Who art thou?" For when thou saidst, "If ye believe not that I am," thou didst not tell us what thou wert.

**[38:117]** Who art thou, that we may believe? He answered "The Beginning".

**[38:118]** Here is the existence that [always] is.

**[38:119]** The beginning cannot be changed: the beginning is self-abiding and all-originating; that is, the beginning, to which it has been said, "But thou Thyself art the same, and Thy years shall not fail".

**[38:120]** "The beginning," He said, "for so I also speak to you".

**[38:121]** Believe me [to be] the beginning, that ye may not die in your sins.

**[38:122]** For just as if by saying, "Who art thou?" they had said nothing else than this, What shall we believe thee to be? He replied, "The beginning;" that is, Believe me [to be] the "beginning".

**[38:123]** For in the Greek expression we discern what we cannot in the Latin.

**[38:124]** For in Greek the word "beginning" (principium, ἀρχή), is of the feminine gender, just as with us "law" (lex) is of the feminine gender, while it is of the masculine (νόμος) with them; or as "wisdom" (sapientia, σοφία) is of the feminine gender with both.

**[38:125]** It is the custom of speech, therefore, in different languages to vary the gender of words, because in things themselves there is no place for the distinction of sex.

**[38:126]** For wisdom is not really female, since Christ is the Wisdom of God, and Christ is termed of the masculine gender, wisdom of the feminine.

**[38:127]** When then the Jews said, "Who art thou?" He, who knew that there were some there who should yet believe, and therefore had said, Who art thou? that so they might come to know what they ought to believe regarding Him, replied, "The beginning:" not as if He said, I am the beginning; but as if He said, Believe me [to be] the beginning.

**[38:128]** Which, as I said, is quite evident in the Greek language, where beginning (ἀρχή) is of the feminine gender.

**[38:129]** Just as if He had wished to say that He was the Truth, and to their question, "Who art thou?" had answered, Veritatem[the Truth]; when to the words, "Who art thou?" He evidently ought to have replied, Veritas [the Truth]; that is, I am the Truth.

**[38:130]** But His answer had a deeper meaning, when He saw that they had put the question, "Who art thou?" in such a way as to mean, Having heard from thee, "If ye believe not that I am," what shall we believe thee to be? To this He replied, "The beginning:" as if He said, Believe me to be the beginning.

**[38:131]** And He added "for [as such] I also speak to you;" that is, having humbled myself on your account, I have condescended to such words.

**[38:132]** For if the beginning as it is in itself had remained so with the Father, as not to receive the form of a servant and speak as man with men; how could they have believed in Him, since their weak hearts could not have heard the Word intelligently without some voice that would appeal to their senses? Therefore, said He, believe me to be the beginning; for, that you may believe, I not only am, but also speak to you.

**[38:133]** But on this subject I have still much to say to you; may it therefore please your Charity that we reserve what remains, and by His gracious aid deliver it tomorrow.

**[39:1]** Tractate XXXIX.

**[39:2]** Chapter VIII.

**[39:3]** 26, 27  1.

**[39:4]** The words of our Lord Jesus Christ, which He had addressed to the Jews, so regulating His discourse that the blind saw not, and believers' eyes were opened, are these, which have been read to-day from the holy Gospel: "Then said the Jews, Who art thou?" Because the Lord had said before, "If ye believe not that I am, ye shall die in your sins".

**[39:5]** To this accordingly they rejoined, "Who art thou?" as if seeking to know on whom they ought to believe, so as not to die in their sin.

**[39:6]** He replied to those who asked Him: "Who art thou?" by saying, "The beginning, for [so] also I speak to you".

**[39:7]** If the Lord has called Himself the beginning, it may be inquired whether the Father also is the beginning.

**[39:8]** For if the Son who has a Father is the beginning, how much more easily must God the Father be understood as the beginning, who has indeed the Son whose Father He is, but has no one from whom He Himself proceedeth? For the Son is the Son of the Father, and the Father certainly is the Father of the Son; but the Son is called God of God,—the Son is called Light of Light; the Father is called Light, but not, of Light,—the Father is called God, but not, of God.

**[39:9]** If, then, God of God, Light of Light, is the beginning, how much more easily may we understand as such that Light, from whom the Light [cometh], and God, of whom is God? It seems, therefore, absurd, dearly beloved, to call the Son the beginning, and not to call the Father the beginning also.

**[39:10]** 2.

**[39:11]** But what shall we do? Are there, then, two beginnings? Let us beware of saying so.

**[39:12]** What then, if both the Father is the beginning and the Son the beginning, how are there not two beginnings? In the same way that we call the Father God, and the Son God, and yet say not that there are two Gods; and yet He who is the Father is not the Son, He who is the Son is not the Father; and the Holy Spirit, the Spirit of the Father and of the Son, is neither the Father nor the Son.

**[39:13]** Although, then, as Catholic ears have been taught in the bosom of mother Church, neither He who is the Father is the Son, nor He who is the Son is the Father, nor is the Holy Spirit, of the Father and of the Son, either the Son or the Father, yet we say not that there are three Gods; although, if we are asked of each apart, we must, of whichever we are questioned, confess that He is God.

**[39:14]** 3.

**[39:15]** But all this seems absurd to those who drag up familiar things to a level with things little known, visible things with invisible, and compare the creature to the Creator.

**[39:16]** For unbelievers sometimes question us and say: Whom you call the Father, do you call him God? We answer, God.

**[39:17]** Whom you call the Son, do you call him God? We answer, God.

**[39:18]** Whom you call the Holy Spirit, do you call him God? We answer, God.

**[39:19]** Then, say they, are the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit three Gods? We answer, No.

**[39:20]** They are confounded, because they are not enlightened; they have their heart shut up, because they want the key of faith.

**[39:21]** Let us then, brethren, by an antecedent faith that heals the eye of our heart, receive without obscurity what we understand,—and what we understand not, believe without hesitation; let us not quit the foundation of faith in order to reach the summit of perfection.

**[39:22]** The Father is God, the Son is God, the Holy Spirit is God: and yet He is not the Father who is the Son, nor He the Son who is the Father, and the Holy Spirit, the Spirit of the Father and the Son, is neither the Father nor the Son.

**[39:23]** The Trinity is one God.

**[39:24]** The Trinity is one eternity, one power, one majesty;—three, [but not three] Gods.

**[39:25]** Let not the reviler answer me: "Three what, then? For," he adds, "if there are three, you must say, three what?" I reply: The Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit.

**[39:26]** "See," he says, "you have named three; but express what the three are?" Nay, count them yourself; for I make out three when I say, the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit.

**[39:27]** For the Father is God as respects Himself, but [He is] the Father as respects the Son; the Son is God as respects Himself, but He is the Son as regards the Father.

**[39:28]** 4.

**[39:29]** What I say you may gather from daily analogies.

**[39:30]** So it is with one man and another, if the one be a father, the other his son.

**[39:31]** He is man as regards himself, but a father as regards his son; and the son man as respects himself, but a son as respects his father.

**[39:32]** For father is a name given relatively, and so with son; but these are two men.

**[39:33]** And certainly God the Father is Father in a  relative sense, that is, in relation to the Son; and God the Son is Son relatively, that is, in relation to the Father; but not as the former are two men are these two Gods.

**[39:34]** Why is it not so here? Because that belongs to one sphere and this to another; for this is divine.

**[39:35]** There is here something ineffable which cannot be explained in words, that there should both be, and not be, number.

**[39:36]** For see if there appear not a kind of number, Father, and Son, and Holy Ghost—the Trinity.

**[39:37]** If three, three what? Here number fails.

**[39:38]** And so God neither keeps apart from number, nor is comprehended by number.

**[39:39]** Because there are three, there is a kind of number.

**[39:40]** If you ask three what, number ceases.

**[39:41]** Hence it is said, "Great is our Lord, and great His power; and of His understanding there is no number".

**[39:42]** When you have begun to reflect, you begin to number; when you have numbered, you cannot tell what you have numbered.

**[39:43]** The Father is Father, the Son is Son, the Holy Spirit is the Holy Spirit.

**[39:44]** What are these three, the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit? Are They not three Gods? No.

**[39:45]** Are They not three Almighties? No.

**[39:46]** Not three Creators of the world? No.

**[39:47]** Is the Father then almighty? Manifestly almighty.

**[39:48]** And is the Son then not almighty? Clearly the Son is also almighty.

**[39:49]** And is the Holy Spirit then not almighty? He, too, is almighty.

**[39:50]** Are there then three Almighties? No; only one Almighty.

**[39:51]** Only in Their relation to each other do They suggest number, not in Their essential existence.

**[39:52]** For though God the Father is, as respects Himself, God along with the Son and the Holy Spirit, there are not three Gods; and, though as respects Himself He is omnipotent, as well as the Son and the Holy Spirit, there are not three omnipotents; for in truth He is the Father not in respect to Himself, but to the Son; nor is the Son so in respect to Himself, but to the Father; nor is the Spirit so as regards Himself, in as far as He is called the Spirit of the Father and of the Son.

**[39:53]** I have no name to give the three, save the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, one God, one Almighty.

**[39:54]** And so one beginning.

**[39:55]** 5.

**[39:56]** Take an illustration from the Holy Scriptures, whereby you may in some measure comprehend what I am saying.

**[39:57]** After our Lord Jesus Christ rose again, and was pleased to ascend into heaven, at the end of ten days He sent from thence the Holy Spirit, by whom those who were present in that one chamber were filled, and began to speak in the languages of all nations.

**[39:58]** The Lord's murderers, terrified by the miracle, were pricked to the heart and sorrowed; sorrowing, were changed; and being changed, believed.

**[39:59]** There were added to the Lord's body, that is, to the number of believers, three thousand people.

**[39:60]** And so also by the working of another miracle there were added other five thousand.

**[39:61]** A considerable community was created, in which all, receiving the Holy Spirit, by whom spiritual love was kindled, were by their very love and fervor of spirit welded into one, and began in the very unity of fellowship to sell all that they had, and to lay the price at the apostles' feet, that distribution might be made to every one as each had need.

**[39:62]** And the Scripture says this of them, that "they were of one soul and one heart toward God".

**[39:63]** Give heed then, brethren, and from this acknowledge the mystery of the Trinity, how it is we say, There is both the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit, and yet there is one God.

**[39:64]** See! there were so many thousands of these, and yet there was one heart; there were so many thousands, and one soul.

**[39:65]** But where? In God.

**[39:66]** How much more so God Himself? Do I err at all in word when I call two men two souls, or three men three souls, or many men many souls? Surely I speak correctly.

**[39:67]** Let them approach God, and one soul belongs to all.

**[39:68]** If by approaching God many souls by love become one soul, and many hearts one heart, what of the very fountain of love in the Father and Son? Is it not still more so here that the Trinity is one God? For thence, of that Holy Spirit, does love come to us, as the apostle says: "The love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost, which is given unto us".

**[39:69]** If then the love of God, shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us, makes many souls one soul, and many hearts one heart, how much rather are the Father and Son and Holy Spirit, one God, one light, and one beginning?  6.

**[39:70]** Let us hear, then, the Beginning who speaks to us: "I have," said He, "many things to say of you and to judge".

**[39:71]** You remember that He said, "I do not judge any one".

**[39:72]** See, now He says, "I have many things to say of you and to judge".

**[39:73]** But, "I do not judge" is one thing: "I have to judge" is another; for He had come to save the world, not to judge the world.

**[39:74]** In saying, "I have many things to say of you and to judge," He speaks of the future judgment.

**[39:75]** For therefore did He ascend, that He may come to judge the living and the dead.

**[39:76]** No one will judge more justly than He who was  unjustly judged.

**[39:77]** "Many things," said He, "have I to say of you and to judge; but He that sent me is true".

**[39:78]** See how the Son, His equal, gives glory to the Father.

**[39:79]** For He sets us an example, and says as it were in our hearts: O believer, if thou hearest my gospel, the Lord thy God saith to thee, when I, in the beginning God the Word with God, equal with the Father, coeternal with Him that begat, give glory to Him whose Son I am, how canst thou be proud before Him, whose servant thou art?  7.

**[39:80]** "I have many things," He said, "to say of you and to judge: but He that sent me is true;" as if He had said, Therefore I judge the truth, because, as the Son of the True One, I am the truth.

**[39:81]** The Father true, the Son the truth,—which do we account the greater? Let us reflect, if we can, which is the greater, the True One or the Truth.

**[39:82]** Take some other instances.

**[39:83]** Is a pious man, or piety, the more comprehensive? Surely piety itself; for the pious is derived from piety, not piety from the pious.

**[39:84]** For piety may still exist, though he who was pious became impious.

**[39:85]** He has lost his piety, but has taken nothing from piety itself.

**[39:86]** What also of comely and comeliness? Comeliness is more than comely; for comeliness gives existence to the comely, not the comely to comeliness.

**[39:87]** And so of chaste and chastity.

**[39:88]** Chastity is clearly something more than chaste.

**[39:89]** For if chastity had no existence, one would have no ground to be chaste; but though one may refuse to be chaste, chastity remains entire.

**[39:90]** If then the term piety implies more than the term pious, comeliness more than comely, chastity than chaste, shall we say that the Truth is more than the True One? If we say so, we shall begin to say that the Son is greater than the Father.

**[39:91]** For the Lord Himself says most distinctly, "I am the way, and the truth, and the life".

**[39:92]** Therefore, if the Son is the truth, what is the Father but what the Truth Himself says, "He that sent me is true"? The Son is the truth, the Father true.

**[39:93]** I inquire which is the greater, but find equality.

**[39:94]** For the true Father is true not because He contained a part of that truth, but because He begat it entire.

**[39:95]** 8.

**[39:96]** I see I must speak more plainly.

**[39:97]** And, not to detain you long, let me treat only of this point to-day.

**[39:98]** When I have finished what, with God's help, I wish to say, my discourse shall close.

**[39:99]** I have said this, then, to enlist your attention.

**[39:100]** Every soul, as being a thing, is mutable; and although a great creature, yet a creature; though superior to the body, yet made.

**[39:101]** Every soul, then, since it is changeable—that is, sometimes believes, sometimes disbelieves; at one time wishes, at another time refuses; at one time is adulterous, at another chaste; now good, and again wicked,—is changeable.

**[39:102]** But God is that which is, and so has retained as His own peculiar name, "I am who am".

**[39:103]** Such also is the Son, when He says, "If ye believe not that I am;" and thereto pertains also, "Who art thou? The Beginning" (ver.

**[39:104]** 25).

**[39:105]** God therefore is unchangeable, the soul changeable.

**[39:106]** When the soul receives from God the elements of its goodness it becomes good by participation, just as by participation thine eye seeth.

**[39:107]** For it sees not when the light is withdrawn, while so long as it shares in the light it sees.

**[39:108]** Since then by participation the soul is made good, if it changes and becomes bad, the goodness remains that made it good.

**[39:109]** For there is a goodness of which it partook when good; and when it has turned to evil, that goodness continues entire.

**[39:110]** If the soul fall away and become evil, there is no lessening of goodness; if it return and become good, that goodness is not enlarged.

**[39:111]** Thine eye participates in this light, and thou seest.

**[39:112]** Is it shut? Then thou hast not diminished the light.

**[39:113]** Is it open? Thou hast not increased the light.

**[39:114]** By this illustration, brethren, understand that if the soul is pious, there is piety with God, of which the soul is partaker; if the soul is chaste, there is chastity with God, of which it partakes; if it is good, there is goodness with God, of which it partakes; if it is true, there is truth with God, of which the soul is partaker.

**[39:115]** Whereof if the soul is no partaker, every man is false; and if every man may be false, no man is true of himself.

**[39:116]** But the true Father is true of Himself, for He begat the Truth.

**[39:117]** It is one thing to say, That man is true, for he has taken in the truth: it is another, God is true, for He begat the Truth.

**[39:118]** See then how God is true,—not by participating in, but by generating the Truth.

**[39:119]** I see you have understood me, and am glad.

**[39:120]** Let this suffice you to-day.

**[39:121]** The rest, according as He gives it, we shall expound when the Lord pleases.

**[40:1]** Tractate XL.

**[40:2]** Chapter VIII.

**[40:3]** 28–32  1.

**[40:4]** Of the holy Gospel according to John, which you see in our hand, your Charity has already heard much, whereon by God's grace we have discoursed according to our ability, pressing on your notice that this evangelist, specially, has chosen to speak of the Lord's divinity, wherein He is equal with the Father and the only Son of God; and on that account he has been compared to the eagle, because no other bird is understood to take a loftier flight.

**[40:5]** Accordingly, to what follows in order, as the Lord enables us to treat of it, listen with all your attention.

**[40:6]** 2.

**[40:7]** We have spoken to you on the preceding passage, suggesting how the Father may be understood as True, and the Son as the Truth.

**[40:8]** But when the Lord Jesus said, "He that sent me is true," the Jews understood not that He spake to them of the Father.

**[40:9]** And He said to them, as you have just heard in the reading, "When ye have lifted up the Son of man, then shall ye know that I am, and [that] I do nothing of myself; but as the Father hath taught me, I speak these things".

**[40:10]** What means this? For it looks as if all He said was, that they would know who He was after His passion.

**[40:11]** Without doubt, therefore, He saw that some there, whom He Himself knew, whom with the rest of His saints He Himself in His foreknowledge had chosen before the foundation of the world, would believe after His passion.

**[40:12]** These are the very persons whom we are constantly commending, and with much entreaty setting forth for your imitation.

**[40:13]** For on the sending down of the Holy Spirit after the Lord's passion, and resurrection, and ascension, when miracles were being done in the name of Him whom, as if dead, the persecuting Jews had despised, they were pricked in their hearts; and they who in their rage slew Him were changed and believed; and they who in their rage shed His blood, now in the spirit of faith drank it; to wit, those three thousand, and those five thousand Jews whom now He saw there, when He said, "When ye have lifted up the Son of man, then shall ye know that I am [He]".

**[40:14]** It was as if He had said, I let your recognition lie over till I have completed my passion: in your own order ye shall know who I am.

**[40:15]** Not that all who heard Him were only then to believe, that is, after the Lord's passion; for a little after it is said, "As He spake these words, many believed on Him;" and the Son of man was not yet lifted up.

**[40:16]** But the lifting up He is speaking of is that of His passion, not of His glorification; of the cross, not of heaven; for He was exalted there also when He hung on the tree.

**[40:17]** But that exaltation was His humiliation; for then He became obedient even to the death of the cross.

**[40:18]** This required to be accomplished by the hands of those who should afterwards believe, and to whom He says, "When ye have lifted up the Son of man, then shall ye know that I am [He]".

**[40:19]** And why so, but that no one might despair, however guilty his conscience, when he saw those forgiven their homicide who had slain the Christ?  3.

**[40:20]** The Lord then, recognizing such in that crowd, said, "When ye have lifted up the Son of man, then shall ye know that I am [He]".

**[40:21]** You know already what "I am" signifies; and we must not be continually repeating, lest so great a subject beget distaste.

**[40:22]** Recall that, "I am who am," and "He who is hath sent me," and you will recognize the meaning of the words, "Then shall ye know that I am".

**[40:23]** But both the Father is, and the Holy Spirit is.

**[40:24]** To the same is belongs the whole Trinity.

**[40:25]** But because the Lord spake as the Son, in order that, when He says, "Then shall ye know that I am," there might be no chance of entrance for the error of the Sabellians, that is, of the Patripassians,—an error which I have charged you not to hold, but to beware of,—the error, I mean, of those who have said, The Father and Son are one and the same; two names, but one reality;—to guard them against that error, when the Lord said, "Then shall ye know that I am," that He might not be understood as Himself the Father, He immediately added, "And I do nothing of myself; but as my Father taught me, I speak these things".

**[40:26]** Already was the Sabellian beginning to rejoice over the discovery of a ground for his error; but immediately on showing himself as it were in the shade, he was confounded by the light of the following sentence.

**[40:27]** Thou thoughtest that He was the Father, because He said, "I am".

**[40:28]** Hear now that He is the Son: "And  I do nothing of myself".

**[40:29]** What means this, "I do nothing of myself"? Of myself I am not.

**[40:30]** For the Son is God, of the Father; but the Father is God, yet not of the Son.

**[40:31]** The Son is God of God, and the Father is God, but not of God.

**[40:32]** The Son is light of light; and the Father is light, but not of light.

**[40:33]** The Son is, but there is [One] of whom He is; and the Father is, but there is none of whom He is.

**[40:34]** 4.

**[40:35]** Let not then, my brethren, His further words, "As my Father hath taught me, I speak these things," be the occasion of any carnal thought stealing into your minds.

**[40:36]** For human weakness cannot think, but as it is accustomed to act and to hear.

**[40:37]** Do not then set before your eyes as it were two men, one the father, the other the son, and the father speaking to the son; as any one of you may do, when you say something to your son, admonishing and instructing him how to speak, to charge his memory with what you have told him, and, having done so, to express it in words, to enunciate distinctly, and convey to the ears of others what he has apprehended with his own.

**[40:38]** Think not thus, lest you be fabricating idols in your heart.

**[40:39]** The human shape, the outlines of human limbs, the form of human flesh, the outward senses, stature and motions of the body, the functions of the tongue, the distinctions of sounds,—think not of such as existing in that Trinity, save as they pertain to the servant-form, which the only-begotten Son assumed, when the Word was made flesh to dwell among us.

**[40:40]** Thereof I forbid thee not, human weakness, to think according to thy knowledge: nay, rather I require thee.

**[40:41]** If the faith that is in thee be true, think of Christ as such; but as such of the Virgin Mary, not of God the Father.

**[40:42]** He was an infant, He grew as a man, He walked as a man, He hungered, He thirsted as a man, He slept as a man; at last He suffered as a man, hung on the tree, was slain and buried as a man.

**[40:43]** In the same form He rose again; in the same, before the eyes of His disciples, He ascended into heaven; in the same will He yet come to judgment.

**[40:44]** For angel lips have declared in the Gospel, "He shall so come in like manner as ye have seen Him go into heaven".

**[40:45]** When then you think of the servant-form in Christ, think of a human likeness, if you have faith; but when you think, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God," away with all human fashioning from your heart.

**[40:46]** Banish from your thoughts everything bounded by corporeal limits, included in local measurement, or spread out in a mass, how great soever its size.

**[40:47]** Perish utterly such a figment from your heart.

**[40:48]** Think, if you can, on the beauty of wisdom, picture to yourself the beauty of righteousness.

**[40:49]** Has that a shape? a size? a color? It has none of these, and yet it is; for if it were not, it would neither be loved nor worthy of praise, nor be cherished in our heart and life as an object of honor and affection.

**[40:50]** But men here become wise; and whence would they so, had wisdom no existence? And further, O man, if thou canst not see thine own wisdom with the eyes of the flesh, nor think of it by the same mental imagery as thou canst of bodily things, wilt thou dare to thrust the shape of a human body on the wisdom of God?  5.

**[40:51]** What shall we say then, brethren? How spake the Father to the Son, seeing that the Son says, "As the Father taught me, I speak these things"? Did He speak to Him? When the Father taught the Son, did He use words, as you do when you teach your son? How could He use words to the Word! What words, many in number, could be used to the one Word? Did the Word of the Father approach His ears to the Father's mouth? Such things are carnal: banish them from your hearts.

**[40:52]** For this I say, if only you have understood my words, I certainly have spoken and my words have sounded, and by their sound have reached your ears, and through your sense of hearing have carried their meaning to your mind, if so be you have understood.

**[40:53]** Suppose that some person of Latin speech has heard, but has only heard without understanding, what I have said.

**[40:54]** As regards the noise issuing from my mouth, he who has understood not has been a sharer therein just like yourselves.

**[40:55]** He has heard that sound; the same syllables have smote on his ears, but they have produced no effect on his mind.

**[40:56]** Why? Because he understood not.

**[40:57]** But if you have understood, whence comes your understanding? My words have sounded in the ear: have I kindled any light in the heart? Without doubt, if what I have said is true, and this truth you have not only heard, but also understood, two things have there been wrought (distinguish between them), hearing and intelligence.

**[40:58]** Hearing has been wrought by me, but by whom has understanding? I have spoken to the ear, that you might hear; who has spoken to your heart for understanding? Doubtless some one has also said something  to your heart, that not only the noise of words might strike your ear, but something also of the truth might descend into your heart.

**[40:59]** Some one has spoken also to your heart, but you do not see him.

**[40:60]** If, brethren, you have understood, your heart also has been spoken to.

**[40:61]** Intelligence is the gift of God.

**[40:62]** And who, if you have understood, has spoken so in your heart, but He to whom the Psalm says, "Give me understanding, that I may learn Thy commandments?" For example, the bishop has spoken.

**[40:63]** What has he said, some one asks.

**[40:64]** You repeat what he has spoken, and add, He has said the truth.

**[40:65]** Then another, who has not understood, says, What has he said, or what is it you are praising? Both have heard me; I have spoken to both; but to one of them God has spoken.

**[40:66]** If we may compare small things with great (for what are we to Him?), something, I know not what, of an incorporeal and spiritual kind God works in us, which is neither sound to strike the ear, nor color to be discerned by the eyes, nor smell to enter the nostrils, nor taste to be judged of by the mouth, nor anything hard or soft to be sensible to the touch; yet something there is which it is easy to feel,—impossible to explain.

**[40:67]** If then God, as I was saying, speaks in our hearts without sound, how speaks He to His Son? Thus then, brethren, think thus as much as you can, if, as I have said, we may in some measure compare small things with great: think thus.

**[40:68]** In an incorporeal way the Father spoke to the Son, because in an incorporeal way the Father begot the Son.

**[40:69]** Nor did He so teach Him as if He had begotten Him untaught; but to have taught Him is the same as to have begotten Him full of knowledge; and this, "The Father hath taught me," is the same as, The Father hath begotten me already knowing.

**[40:70]** For if, as few understand, the nature of the Truth is simple, to be is to the Son the same as to know.

**[40:71]** From Him therefore He has knowledge, from whom He has being.

**[40:72]** Not that from Him He had first being, and afterwards knowledge; but as in begetting He gave Him to be, so in begetting He gave Him to know; for, as was said, to the simple nature of the Truth, being is not one thing and knowing another, but one and the same.

**[40:73]** 6.

**[40:74]** Thus then He spoke to the Jews, and added, "And He that sent me is with me".

**[40:75]** He had already said this also before, but of this important point He is constantly reminding them,—"He sent me," and "He is with me".

**[40:76]** If then, O Lord, He is with Thee, not so much hath the One been sent by the other, but ye Both have come.

**[40:77]** And yet, while Both are together, One was sent, the Other was the sender; for incarnation is a sending, and the incarnation itself belongs only to the Son and not to the Father.

**[40:78]** The Father therefore sent the Son, but did not withdraw from the Son.

**[40:79]** For it was not that the Father was absent from the place to which He sent the Son.

**[40:80]** For where is not the Maker of all things? Where is He not, who said, "I fill heaven and earth"? But perhaps the Father is everywhere, and the Son not so? Listen to the evangelist: "He was in this world, and the world was made by Him".

**[40:81]** Therefore said He, "He that sent me," by whose power as Father I am incarnate, "is with me,—hath not left me".

**[40:82]** Why hath He not left me? "He hath not left me," He says, "alone; for I do always those things that please Him".

**[40:83]** That equality exists always; not from a certain beginning, and then onwards; but without beginning, without end.

**[40:84]** For Divine generation has no beginning in time, since time itself was created by the Only-begotten.

**[40:85]** 7.

**[40:86]** "As He spake these words, many believed on Him".

**[40:87]** Would that, while I speak also, many, who before this were otherwise disposed, understood and believed on Him! For perhaps there are some Arians in this large assembly.

**[40:88]** I dare not suspect that there are any Sabellians, who say that the Father Himself is one with the Son, seeing that heresy is too old, and has been gradually eviscerated.

**[40:89]** But that of the Arians seems still to have some movement about it, like that of a putrefying carcase, or certainly, at the most, like a man at the last gasp; and from this some still require deliverance, just as from that other many were delivered.

**[40:90]** This province, indeed, did not use to have such; but ever since the arrival of many foreigners, some of these have also found their way to our neighborhood.

**[40:91]** See then, while the Lord spoke these words, many Jews believed on Him.

**[40:92]** May I see also that, while I am speaking, Arians are believing, not on me, but with me!  8.

**[40:93]** "Then said the Lord to those Jews who believed on Him, If ye continue in my word".

**[40:94]** "Continue," I say, for you are now initiated and have begun to be there.

**[40:95]** "If ye continue," that is, in the faith which is now begun in you who believe, to what will you attain? See the nature of the beginning, and whither it leads.

**[40:96]** You have loved the foundation, give heed to the summit, and out of this  low condition seek that other elevation.

**[40:97]** For faith has humility, but knowledge and immortality and eternity possess not lowliness, but loftiness; that is, upraising, all-sufficiency, eternal stability, full freedom from hostile assault, from fear of failure.

**[40:98]** That which has its beginning in faith is great, but is despised.

**[40:99]** In a building also the foundation is usually of little account with the unskilled.

**[40:100]** A large trench is made, and stones are thrown in every way and everywhere.

**[40:101]** No embellishment, no beauty are apparent there; just as also in the root of a tree there is no appearance of beauty.

**[40:102]** And yet all that delights you in the tree has sprung from the root.

**[40:103]** You look at the root and feel no delight: you look at the tree and admire it.

**[40:104]** Foolish man! what you admire has grown out of that which gave you no delight.

**[40:105]** The faith of believers seems a thing of little value,—you have no scales to weigh it.

**[40:106]** Hear then to what it attains, and see its greatness: as the Lord Himself says in another place, "If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed".

**[40:107]** What is there of less account than that, yet what is there pervaded with greater energy? What more minute, yet what more fervidly expansive? And so "ye" also, He says, "if ye continue in my word," wherein ye have believed, to what will ye be brought? "ye shall be my disciples indeed".

**[40:108]** And what does that benefit us? "and ye shall know the truth".

**[40:109]** 9.

**[40:110]** What, brethren, does He promise believers? "And ye shall know the truth".

**[40:111]** Why so? Had they not come to such knowledge when the Lord was speaking? If they had not, how did they believe? They believed, not because they knew, but that they might come to know.

**[40:112]** For we believe in order that we may know, we do not know in order that we may believe.

**[40:113]** For what we shall yet know, neither eye hath seen, nor ear heard, nor hath it entered the heart of man.

**[40:114]** For what is faith, but believing what you see not? Faith then is to believe what you see not; truth, to see what you have believed, as He Himself saith in a certain place.

**[40:115]** The Lord then walked on earth, first of all, for the creation of faith.

**[40:116]** He was man, He was made in a low condition.

**[40:117]** He was seen by all, but not by all was He known.

**[40:118]** By many was He rejected, by the multitude was He slain, by few was He mourned; and yet even by those who mourned Him, His true being was still unrecognized.

**[40:119]** All this is the beginning as it were of faith's lineaments and future up-building.

**[40:120]** As the Lord, referring thereto, saith in a certain place, "He that loveth me keepeth my commandments; and he that loveth me shall be loved of my Father, and I will love him, and will manifest myself to him".

**[40:121]** They certainly already saw the person to whom they were listening; and yet to them, if they loved Him, does He give it as a promise that they should see Him.

**[40:122]** So also here, "Ye shall know the truth".

**[40:123]** How so? Is that not the truth which Thou hast been speaking? The truth it is, but as yet it is only believed, not beheld.

**[40:124]** If you abide in that which is believed, you shall attain to that which is seen.

**[40:125]** Hence John himself, the holy evangelist, says in his epistle, "Dearly beloved, we are the sons of God; but it is not yet apparent what we shall be".

**[40:126]** We are so already, and something we shall be.

**[40:127]** What more shall we be than we are? Listen: "It is not yet apparent what we shall be: [but] we know that, when He shall appear, we shall be like Him".

**[40:128]** How? "For we shall see Him as He is".

**[40:129]** A great promise, but the reward of faith.

**[40:130]** You seek the reward; then let the work precede.

**[40:131]** If you believe, ask for the reward of faith; but if you believe not, with what face can you seek the reward of faith? "If" then "ye continue in my word, ye shall be my disciples indeed," that ye may behold the very truth as it is, not through sounding words, but in dazzling light, wherewith He shall satisfy us: as we read in the psalm, "The light of Thy countenance is impressed upon us".

**[40:132]** We are God's money: we have wandered away as coin from the treasury.

**[40:133]** The impression that was stamped upon us has been rubbed out by our wandering.

**[40:134]** He has come to refashion, for He it was that fashioned us at first; and He is Himself asking for His money, as Caesar for his.

**[40:135]** Therefore He says, "Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's:" to Caesar his money, to God yourselves.

**[40:136]** And then shall the truth be reproduced in us.

**[40:137]** 10.

**[40:138]** What shall I say to your Charity? Oh that our hearts were in some measure aspiring after that ineffable glory! Oh that we were passing our pilgrimage in sighs, and loving not the world, and continually pushing onwards with pious minds to Him who hath called us! Longing is the very bosom of the heart.

**[40:139]** We shall attain, if with all our power we give way to our longing.

**[40:140]** Such in our behalf is the object of the divine Scriptures, of the assembling of the people, of the celebration of the sacra  ments, of holy baptism, of singing God's praise, and of this our own exposition,—that this longing may not only be implanted and germinate, but also expand to such a measure of capacity as to be fit to take in what eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, nor hath entered into the heart of man.

**[40:141]** But love with me.

**[40:142]** He who loves God is not much in love with money.

**[40:143]** And I have but touched on this infirmity, not venturing to say, He loves not money at all, but, He loves not money much; as if money were to be loved, but not in a great degree.

**[40:144]** Oh, were we loving God worthily, we should have no love at all for money! Money then will be thy means of pilgrimage, not the stimulant of lust; something to use for necessity, not to joy over as a means of delight.

**[40:145]** Love God, if He has wrought in thee somewhat of that which thou hearest and praisest.

**[40:146]** Use the world: let not the world hold thee captive.

**[40:147]** Thou art passing on the journey thou hast begun; thou hast come, again to depart, not to abide.

**[40:148]** Thou art passing on thy journey, and this life is but a wayside inn.

**[40:149]** Use money as the traveller at an inn uses table, cup, pitcher, and couch, with the purpose not of remaining, but of leaving them behind.

**[40:150]** If such you would be, you, who can stir up your hearts and hear me; if such you would be, you will attain to His promises.

**[40:151]** It is not too much for your strength, for mighty is the hand of Him who hath called you.

**[40:152]** He hath called you.

**[40:153]** Call upon Him, say to Him, Thou hast called us, we call upon Thee; see, we have heard Thee calling us, hear us calling upon Thee: lead us whither Thou hast promised; perfect what Thou hast begun; forsake not Thine own gifts; leave not Thine own field; let Thy tender shoots yet be gathered into Thy barn.

**[40:154]** Temptations abound in the world, but greater is He who made the world.

**[40:155]** Temptations abound, but he fails not whose hope reposes in Him in whom there is no deficiency.

**[40:156]** 11.

**[40:157]** I have been exhorting you, brethren, to this in such words, because the freedom of which our Lord Jesus Christ speaks belongs not to this present time.

**[40:158]** Look at what He added: "Ye shall be my disciples indeed; and ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall set you free".

**[40:159]** What means that—"shall set you free"? It shall make you freemen.

**[40:160]** In a word, the carnal, and fleshly-minded Jews—not those who had believed, but those in the crowd who believed not—thought that an injury was done them, because He said to them, "The truth shall make you free".

**[40:161]** They were indignant at being designated as slaves.

**[40:162]** And slaves truly they were; and He explains to them what slavery it is, and what is that future freedom which is promised by Himself.

**[40:163]** But of this liberty and of that slavery it were too long to speak to-day.

**[41:1]** Tractate XLI.

**[41:2]** Chapter VIII.

**[41:3]** 31–36  1.

**[41:4]** Of what follows of the previous lesson, and has been read publicly to us to-day from the holy Gospel, I then deferred speaking, because I had already said much, and of that liberty into which the grace of the Saviour calleth us it was needful to treat in no cursory or negligent way.

**[41:5]** Of this, by the Lord's help, we purpose speaking to you to-day.

**[41:6]** For those to whom the Lord Jesus Christ was speaking were Jews, in a large measure indeed His enemies, but also in some measure already become, and yet to be, His friends; for some He saw there, as we have already said, who should yet believe after His passion.

**[41:7]** Looking to these, He had said, "When ye have lifted up the Son of man, then shall ye know that I am [He]".

**[41:8]** There also were those who, when He so spake, straightway believed.

**[41:9]** To them He spake what we have heard to-day: "Then said Jesus to those Jews who believed on Him, If ye continue in my word, ye shall be my disciples indeed".

**[41:10]** By continuing ye shall be so; for as now ye are believers, by so continuing ye shall be beholders.

**[41:11]** Hence there follows, "And ye shall know the truth".

**[41:12]** The truth is unchangeable.

**[41:13]** The truth is bread, which refreshes our minds and fails not; changes the eater, and is not itself changed into the eater.

**[41:14]** The truth itself is the Word of God,  God with God, the only-begotten Son.

**[41:15]** This Truth was for our sake clothed with flesh, that He might be born of the Virgin Mary, and the prophecy fulfilled, "Truth has sprung from the earth".

**[41:16]** This Truth then, when speaking to the Jews, lay hid in the flesh.

**[41:17]** But He lay hid not in order to be denied, but to be deferred [in His manifestation]; to be deferred, in order to suffer in the flesh; and to suffer in the flesh, in order that flesh might be redeemed from sin.

**[41:18]** And so our Lord Jesus Christ, standing full in sight as regards the infirmity of flesh, but hid as regards the majesty of Godhead, said to those who had believed on Him, when He so spake, "If ye continue in my word, ye shall be my disciples indeed".

**[41:19]** For he that endureth to the end shall be saved.

**[41:20]** "And ye shall know the truth," which now is hid from you, and speaks to you.

**[41:21]** "And the truth shall free you".

**[41:22]** This word, liberabit [shall free], the Lord hath taken from libertas [freedom].

**[41:23]** For liberat [frees, delivers] is properly nothing else but liberum facit [makes free].

**[41:24]** As salvat [he saves] is nothing else but salvum facit [he makes safe]; as he heals is nothing else but he makes whole; he enriches is nothing else but he makes rich; so liberat [he frees] is nothing else but liberum facit [he makes free].

**[41:25]** This is clearer in the Greek word.

**[41:26]** For in Latin usage we commonly say that a man is delivered (liberari), in regard not to liberty, but only to safety, just as one is said to be delivered from some infirmity.

**[41:27]** So is it said customarily, but not properly.

**[41:28]** But the Lord made such use of this word in saying, "And the truth shall make you free (liberabit)," that in the Greek tongue no one could doubt that He spake of freedom.

**[41:29]** 2.

**[41:30]** In short, the Jews also so understood and "answered Him;" not those who had already believed, but those in that crowd who were not yet believers.

**[41:31]** "They answered Him, We are Abraham's seed, and were never in bondage to any man: how sayest thou, Ye shall be free?" But the Lord had not said, "Ye shall be free," but, "The truth shall make you free".

**[41:32]** That word, however, they, because, as I have said, it is clearly so in the Greek, understood as pointing only to freedom, and puffed themselves up as Abraham's seed, and said, "We are Abraham's seed, and were never in bondage to any man: how sayest thou, Ye shall be free?" O inflated skin! such is not magnanimity, but windy swelling.

**[41:33]** For even as regards freedom in this life, how was that the truth when you said, "We were never in bondage to any man"? Was not Joseph sold? Were not the holy prophets led into captivity? And again, did not that very nation, when making bricks in Egypt, also serve hard rulers, not only in gold and silver, but also in clay? If you were never in bondage to any man, ungrateful people, why is it that God is continually reminding you that He delivered you from the house of bondage? Or mean you, perchance, that your fathers were in bondage, but you who speak were never in bondage to any man? How then were you now paying tribute to the Romans, out of which also you formed a trap for the Truth Himself, as if to ensnare Him, when you said, "Is it lawful to give tribute to Caesar?" in order that, had He said, It is lawful, you might fasten on Him as one ill-disposed to the liberty of Abraham's seed; and if He said, It is not lawful, you might slander Him before the kings of the earth, as forbidding the payment of tribute to such? Deservedly were you defeated on producing the money, and compelled yourselves to concur in your own capture.

**[41:34]** For there it was told you, "Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's," after your own reply, that the money-piece bore the image of Caesar.

**[41:35]** For as Caesar looks for his own image on the coin, so God looks for His in man.

**[41:36]** Thus, then, did He answer the Jews.

**[41:37]** I am moved, brethren, by the hollow pride of men, because even of that very freedom of theirs, which they understood carnally, they lied when they said, "We were never in bondage to any man".

**[41:38]** 3.

**[41:39]** But to the Lord's own answer, let us give better and more earnest heed, lest we ourselves be also found bondmen.

**[41:40]** For "Jesus answered them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, that every one who committeth sin is the servant of sin".

**[41:41]** He is the servant—would that it were of man, and not of sin! Who will not tremble at such words? The Lord our God grant us, that is, both you and me, that I may speak in fitting terms of this freedom to be sought, and of that bondage to be avoided.

**[41:42]** "Amen, amen [verily, verily], I say unto you".

**[41:43]** The Truth speaks: and in what sense does the Lord our God claim it as His to say, "Amen, amen, I say unto you"? His charge is weighty in so announcing it.

**[41:44]** In some sort, if lawful to be said, His form of swearing is, "Amen, amen, I say unto you".

**[41:45]** Amen in a way may be interpreted, [It is] true [truly, verily]; and yet it is not interpreted, though it might have  been said, What is true [verily] I say unto you.

**[41:46]** Neither the Greek translator nor the Latin has dared to do so; for this word Amen is neither Greek nor Latin, but Hebrew.

**[41:47]** So it has remained without interpretation, to possess honor as the covering of something hidden; not in order to be disowned, but that it might not, as a thing laid bare to the eye, fall into disrepute.

**[41:48]** And yet it is not once, but twice uttered by the Lord, "Amen, amen, I say unto you".

**[41:49]** And now learn from the very doubling, how much was implied in the charge before us.

**[41:50]** 4.

**[41:51]** What, then, is the charge given? Verily, verily, I say unto you, saith the Truth who surely, though He had not said, Verily, I say, could not possibly lie.

**[41:52]** Yet [thereby] He impresses, inculcates His charge, arouses in a way the sleeping, makes them attentive, and would not be contemned.

**[41:53]** What does He say? "Verily, verily, I say unto you, that every one who committeth sin is the servant of sin".

**[41:54]** Miserable slavery! Men frequently, when they suffer under wicked masters, demand to get themselves sold, not seeking to be without a master, but at all events to change him.

**[41:55]** What can the servant of sin do? To whom can he make his demand? To whom apply for redress? Of whom require himself to be sold? And then at times a man's slave, worn out by the commands of an unfeeling master, finds rest in flight.

**[41:56]** Whither can the servant of sin flee? Himself he carries with him wherever he flees.

**[41:57]** An evil conscience flees not from itself; it has no place to go to; it follows itself.

**[41:58]** Yea, he cannot withdraw from himself, for the sin he commits is within.

**[41:59]** He has committed sin to obtain some bodily pleasure.

**[41:60]** The pleasure passes away; the sin remains.

**[41:61]** What delighted is gone; the sting has remained behind.

**[41:62]** Evil bondage! Sometimes men flee to the Church, and we generally permit them, uninstructed as they are—men, wishing to be rid of their master, who are unwilling to be rid of their sins.

**[41:63]** But sometimes also those subjected to an unlawful and wicked yoke flee for refuge to the Church; for, though free-born men, they are retained in bondage: and an appeal is made to the bishop.

**[41:64]** And unless he care to put forth every effort to save free-birth from oppression, he is accounted unmerciful.

**[41:65]** Let us all flee to Christ, and appeal against sin to God as our deliverer.

**[41:66]** Let us seek to get ourselves sold, that we may be redeemed by His blood.

**[41:67]** For the Lord says, "Ye were sold for nought, and ye shall be redeemed without money".

**[41:68]** Without price, that is, of your own; because of mine.

**[41:69]** So saith the Lord; for He Himself has paid the price, not in money, but His own blood.

**[41:70]** Otherwise we had remained both bondmen and indigent.

**[41:71]** 5.

**[41:72]** From this bondage, then, we are set free by the Lord alone.

**[41:73]** He who had it not, Himself delivers us from it; for He alone came without sin in the flesh.

**[41:74]** For the little ones whom you see carried in their mothers' hands cannot yet walk, and are already in fetters; for they have received from Adam what they are loosened from by Christ.

**[41:75]** To them also, when baptized, pertains that grace which is promised by the Lord; for He only can deliver from sin who came without sin, and was made a sacrifice for sin.

**[41:76]** For you heard when the apostle was read: "We are ambassadors," he says, "for Christ, as though God were exhorting you by us; we beseech you in Christ's stead,"—that is, as if Christ were beseeching you, and for what?—"to be reconciled unto God".

**[41:77]** If the apostle exhorts and beseeches us to be reconciled unto God, then were we enemies to God.

**[41:78]** For no one is reconciled unless from a state of enmity.

**[41:79]** And we have become enemies not by nature, but by sin.

**[41:80]** From the same source are we the servants of sin, that we are the enemies of God.

**[41:81]** God has no enemies in a state of freedom.

**[41:82]** They must be slaves; and slaves will they remain unless delivered by Him to whom they wished by their sins to be enemies.

**[41:83]** Therefore, says be, "We beseech you in Christ's stead to be reconciled unto God".

**[41:84]** But how are we reconciled, save by the removal of that which separates between us and Himself? For He says by the prophet, "He hath not made the ear heavy that it should not hear; but your iniquities have separated between you and your God".

**[41:85]** And so, then, we are not reconciled, unless that which is in the midst is taken away, and something else is put in its place.

**[41:86]** For there is a separating medium, and, on the other hand, there is a reconciling Mediator.

**[41:87]** The separating medium is sin, the reconciling Mediator is the Lord Jesus Christ: "For there is one God and Mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus".

**[41:88]** To take then away the separating wall, which is sin, that Mediator has come, and the priest has Himself become the sacrifice.

**[41:89]** And because He was made a sacrifice for sin, offering Himself as a whole burnt-offering on the cross of His passion, the apostle, after saying, "We beseech you in Christ's stead to be reconciled unto God,"—as if we had said, How shall  we be able to be reconciled?—goes on to say, "He hath made Him," that is, Christ Himself, "who knew no sin, [to be] sin for us, that we may be the righteousness of God in Him," "Him," he says, Christ Himself our God, "who knew no sin".

**[41:90]** For He came in the flesh, that is, in the likeness of sinful flesh, but not in sinful flesh, because He had no sin at all; and therefore became a true sacrifice for sin, because He Himself had no sin.

**[41:91]** 6.

**[41:92]** But perhaps, through some special perception of my own, I have said that sin is a sacrifice for sin.

**[41:93]** Let those who have read it be free to acknowledge it; let not those who have not read it be backward; let them not, I say, be backward to read, that they may be truthful in judging.

**[41:94]** For when God gave commandment about the offering of sacrifices for sin, in which sacrifices there was no expiation of sins, but the shadow of things to come, the self-same sacrifices, the self-same offerings, the self-same victims, the self-same animals, which were brought forward to be slain for sins, and in whose blood that [true] blood was prefigured, are themselves called sinsby the law; and that to such an extent that in certain passages it is written in these terms, that the priests, when about to sacrifice, were to lay their hands on the head of the sin, that is, on the head of the victim about to be sacrificed for sin.

**[41:95]** Such sin, then, that is, such a sacrifice for sin, was our Lord Jesus Christ made, "who knew no sin".

**[41:96]** 7.

**[41:97]** With efficacious merit does He deliver from this bondage of sin, who saith in the psalms: "I am become as a man without help, free among the dead".

**[41:98]** For He only was free, because He had no sin.

**[41:99]** For He Himself says in the Gospel, "Behold, the prince of this world cometh," meaning the devil about to come in the persons of the persecuting Jews;—"behold," He says, "he cometh, and shall find nothing in me".

**[41:100]** Not as he found some measure of sin in those whom he also slew as righteous; in me he shall find nothing.

**[41:101]** And just as if He were asked, If he shall find nothing in Thee, wherefore will he slay Thee? He further said, "But that all may know that I do the will of my Father, rise and let us go hence".

**[41:102]** I do not, He says, pay the penalty of death as a necessity of my sinfulness; but in the death I die, I do the will of my Father.

**[41:103]** And in this, I am doing rather than enduring it; for, were I unwilling, I should not have had the suffering to endure.

**[41:104]** You have Him saying in another place, "I have power to lay down my life, and I have power to take it up again".

**[41:105]** Here surely is one "free among the dead".

**[41:106]** 8.

**[41:107]** Since, then, every one that committeth sin is the servant of sin, listen to what is our hope of liberty.

**[41:108]** "And the servant," He says, "abideth not in the house for ever".

**[41:109]** The church is the house, the servant is the sinner.

**[41:110]** Many sinners enter the church.

**[41:111]** Accordingly He has not said, "The servant" is not in the house, but "abideth not in the house for ever".

**[41:112]** If, then, there shall be no servant there, who will be there? For "when" as the Scripture speaketh, "the righteous king sitteth on the throne, who will boast of having a clean heart? or who will boast that he is pure from his sin?" He has greatly alarmed us, my brethren, by saying, "The servant abideth not in the house for ever".

**[41:113]** But He further adds, "But the Son abideth ever".

**[41:114]** Will Christ, then, be alone in His house? Will no people remain at His side? Whose head will He be, if there shall be no body? Or is the Son all this, both the head and the body? For it is not without cause that He has inspired both terror and hope: terror, in order that we should not love sin; and hope, that we should not be distrustful of the remission of sin.

**[41:115]** "Every one," He says, "that committeth sin is the servant of sin.

**[41:116]** And the servant abideth not in the house for ever".

**[41:117]** What hope, then, have we, who are not without sin? Listen to thy hope: "The Son abideth for ever.

**[41:118]** If the Son, therefore, shall make you free, then shall ye be free indeed".

**[41:119]** Our hope is this, brethren, to be made free by the free One; and that, in setting us free, He may make us His servants.

**[41:120]** For we were the servants of lust; but being set free, we are made the servants of love.

**[41:121]** This also the apostle says: "For, brethren, ye have been called unto liberty; only use not liberty for an occasion to the flesh, but by love serve one another".

**[41:122]** Let not then the Christian say, I am free; I have been called unto liberty: I was a slave, but have been redeemed, and by my very redemption have been made free, I shall do what I please: no one may balk me of my will, if I am free.

**[41:123]** But if thou committest sin with such a will, thou art the servant of sin.

**[41:124]** Do not then abuse your liberty for freedom in sinning, but use it for the purpose of sinning not.

**[41:125]** For only if thy will is pious, will it be free.

**[41:126]** Thou wilt be free, if thou art a servant still,—free from sin, the servant of righteous  ness: as the apostle says, "When ye were the servants of sin, ye were free from righteousness.

**[41:127]** But now, being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness, and the end everlasting life".

**[41:128]** Let us be striving after the latter, and be doing the other.

**[41:129]** 9.

**[41:130]** The first stage of liberty is to be free from crimes.

**[41:131]** Give heed, my brethren, give heed, that I may not by any means mislead your understanding as to the nature of that liberty at present, and what it will be.

**[41:132]** Sift any one soever of the highest integrity in this life, and however worthy he may already be of the name of upright, yet is he not without sin.

**[41:133]** Listen to Saint John himself, the author of the Gospel before us, when he says in his epistle, "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us".

**[41:134]** He alone could say this who was "free among the dead:" of Him only could it be said, who knew no sin.

**[41:135]** It could be said only of Him, for He also "was in all points tempted like as we are, yet without sin".

**[41:136]** He alone could say, "Behold, the prince of this world cometh, and shall find nothing in me".

**[41:137]** Sift any one else, who is accounted righteous, yet is he not in all respects without sin; not even such as was Job, to whom the Lord bore such testimony, that the devil was filled with envy, and demanded that he should be tempted, and was himself defeated in the temptation, to the end that Job might be proved.

**[41:138]** And he was proved for this reason, not that the certainty of his carrying off the conqueror's wreath was unknown to God, but that he might become known as an object of imitation to others.

**[41:139]** And what says Job himself? "For who is clean? not even the infant whose life is but a day's span upon the earth".

**[41:140]** But it is plain that many are called righteous without opposition, because the term is understood as meaning, free from crime; for in human affairs there is no just ground of complaint attaching to those who are free from criminal conduct.

**[41:141]** But crime is grievous sin, deserving in the highest measure to be denounced and condemned.

**[41:142]** Not, however, that God condemns certain sins, and justifies and praises certain others.

**[41:143]** He approves of none.

**[41:144]** He hates them all.

**[41:145]** As the physician dislikes the ailment of the ailing, and works by his healing measures to get the ailment removed and the ailing relieved; so God by his grace worketh in us, that sin may be consumed, and man made free.

**[41:146]** But when, you will be saying, is it consumed? If it is lessened, why is it not consumed? That is growing less in the life of those who are advancing onwards, which is consumed in the life of those who have attained to perfection.

**[41:147]** 10.

**[41:148]** The first stage of liberty, then, is to be free from crimes [sinful conduct].
