**[44:148]** For ye have the Lord saying, "Had ye believed Moses, ye would have also believed me; for he wrote of me".

**[44:149]** Is it thus ye follow the servant, and turn your back against the Lord? But not even the servant do ye follow; for by him ye would be guided to the Lord.

**[44:150]** 13.

**[44:151]** "The man answered and said unto them, Herein is a marvellous thing, that ye know not from whence he is, and yet he hath opened mine eyes.

**[44:152]** Now we know that God heareth not sinners; but if any man is a worshipper of God, and doeth His will, him He heareth".

**[44:153]** He speaks still as one only anointed.

**[44:154]** For God heareth even sinners.

**[44:155]** For if God heard not sinners, in vain would the publican, casting his eyes on the ground, and smiting on his breast, have said, "Lord, be merciful to me a sinner".

**[44:156]** And that confession merited justification, as this blind man enlightenment.

**[44:157]** "Since the world began was it not heard that any man opened the eyes of one that was born blind.

**[44:158]** If this man were not of God, he could do nothing".

**[44:159]** With frankness, constancy, and truthfulness [he spoke].

**[44:160]** For these things that were done by the Lord, by whom were they done but by God? Or when would such things be done by disciples, were not the Lord dwelling in them?  14.

**[44:161]** "They answered and said unto him, Thou wast wholly born in sins".

**[44:162]** What means this "wholly"? Even to blindness of the eyes.

**[44:163]** But He who has opened his eyes, also saves him wholly: He will grant a resurrection at His right hand, who gave enlight  enment to his countenance.

**[44:164]** "Thou wast altogether born in sins, and dost thou teach us? And they cast him out".

**[44:165]** They had made him their master; many questions had they asked for their own instruction, and they ungratefully cast forth their teacher.

**[44:166]** 15.

**[44:167]** But, as I have already said before, brethren, when they expel, the Lord receiveth; for the rather that he was expelled, was he made a Christian.

**[44:168]** "Jesus heard that they had cast him out; and when He had found him, He said unto him, Dost thou believe on the Son of God?" Now He washes the face of his heart.

**[44:169]** "He answered and said," as one still only anointed, "Who is he, Lord, that I might believe on him? And Jesus said unto him, Thou hast both seen Him, and it is He that talketh with thee".

**[44:170]** The One is He that is sent; the other is one washing his face in Siloam, which is interpreted, Sent.

**[44:171]** And now at last, with the face of his heart washed, and a conscience purified, acknowledging Him not only as the son of man, which he had believed before, but now as the Son of God, who had assumed our flesh, "he said, Lord, I believe".

**[44:172]** It is but little to say, "I believe:" wouldst thou also see what he believes Him? "He fell down and worshipped Him".

**[44:173]** 16.

**[44:174]** "And Jesus said to him".

**[44:175]** Now is He, the day, discerning between the light and the darkness.

**[44:176]** "For judgment am I come into this world; that they who see not might see, and they who see might be made blind".

**[44:177]** What is this, Lord? A weighty subject of inquiry hast Thou laid on the weary; but revive our strength that we may be able to understand what Thou hast said.

**[44:178]** Thou art come "that they who see not may see:" rightly so, for Thou art the light: rightly so, for Thou art the day: rightly so, for Thou deliverest from darkness: this every soul accepts, every one understands.

**[44:179]** What is this that follows, "And those who see may be made blind?" Shall then, because Thou art come, those be made blind who saw? Hear what follows, and perhaps thou wilt understand.

**[44:180]** 17.

**[44:181]** By these words, then, were "some of the Pharisees" disturbed, "and said unto Him, Are we blind also?" Hear now what it is that moved them, "And they who see may be made blind".

**[44:182]** "Jesus said unto them, If ye were blind, ye should have no sin;" while blindness itself is sin.

**[44:183]** "If ye were blind," that is, if ye considered yourselves blind, if ye called yourselves blind, ye also would have recourse to the physician: "if" then in this way "ye were blind, ye should have no sin;" for I am come to take away sin.

**[44:184]** "But now ye say, We see; [therefore] your sin remaineth".

**[44:185]** Wherefore? Because by saying, "We see:" ye seek not the physician, ye remain in your blindness.

**[44:186]** This, then, is that which a little above we did not understand, when He said, "I am come, that they who see not may see;" for what means this, "that they who see not may see"? They who acknowledge that they do not see, and seek the physician, that they may receive sight.

**[44:187]** And "they who see may be made blind:" what means this, "they who see may be made blind"? That they who think they see, and seek not the physician, may abide in their blindness.

**[44:188]** Such discerning therefore of one from another He called judgment, when He said, "For judgment I am come into this world," whereby He distinguishes the cause of those who believe and make confession from the proud, who think they see, and are therefore the more grievously blinded: just as the sinner, making confession, and seeking the physician, said to Him, "Judge me, O God, and discern my cause against the unholy nation,"—namely, those who say, "We see," and their sin remaineth.

**[44:189]** But it was not that judgment He now brought into the world, whereby in the end of the world He shall judge the living and the dead.

**[44:190]** For in respect to this He had said, "I judge no man;" seeing that He came the first time, "not to judge the world, but that the world through Him might be saved".

**[45:1]** Tractate XLV.

**[45:2]** Chapter X.

**[45:3]** 1–10  1.

**[45:4]** Our Lord's discourse to the Jews began in connection with the man who was born blind and was restored to sight.

**[45:5]** Your Charity therefore ought to know and be advised that today's lesson is interwoven with that one.

**[45:6]** For when the Lord had said, "For judgment I am come into this world; that they who see not might see, and they who see might be made blind,"—which, on the occasion of its reading, we expounded according to our  ability,—some of the Pharisees said, "Are we blind also?" To whom He replied, "If ye were blind, ye should have no sin: but now ye say, We see; [therefore] your sin remaineth".

**[45:7]** To these words He added what we have been hearing today when the lesson was read.

**[45:8]** 2.

**[45:9]** "Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that entereth not by the door into the sheepfold, but climbeth up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber".

**[45:10]** For they declared that they were not blind; yet could they see only by being the sheep of Christ.

**[45:11]** Whence claimed they possession of the light, who were acting as thieves against the day? Because, then, of their vain and proud and incurable arrogance, did the Lord Jesus subjoin these words, wherein He has given us also salutary lessons, if we lay them to heart.

**[45:12]** For there are many who, according to a custom of this life, are called good people,—good men, good women, innocent, and observers as it were of what is commanded in the law; paying respect to their parents, abstaining from adultery, doing no murder, committing no theft, giving no false witness against any one, and observing all else that the law requires—yet are not Christians; and for the most part ask boastfully, like these men, "Are we blind also?" But just because all these things that they do, and know not to what end they should have reference, they do to no purpose, the Lord has set forth in today's lesson the similitude of His own flock, and of the door that leads into the sheepfold.

**[45:13]** Pagans may say, then, We live well.

**[45:14]** If they enter not by the door, what good will that do them, whereof they boast? For to this end ought good living to benefit every one, that it may be given him to live for ever: for to whomsoever eternal life is not given, of what benefit is the living well? For they ought not to be spoken of as even living well, who either from blindness know not the end of a right life, or in their pride despise it.

**[45:15]** But no one has the true and certain hope of living always, unless he know the life, that it is Christ; and enter by the gate into the sheepfold.

**[45:16]** 3.

**[45:17]** Such, accordingly, for the most part seek to persuade men to live well, and yet not to be Christians.

**[45:18]** By another way they wish to climb up, to steal and to kill, not as the shepherd, to preserve and to save.

**[45:19]** And thus there have been certain philosophers, holding many subtle discussions about the virtues and the vices, dividing, defining, drawing out to their close the most acute processes of reasoning, filling books, brandishing their wisdom with rattling jaws; who would even dare to say to people, Follow us, keep to our sect, if you would live happily.

**[45:20]** But they had not entered by the door: they wished to destroy, to slay, and to murder.

**[45:21]** 4.

**[45:22]** What shall I say of such? Look, the Pharisees themselves were in the habit of reading, and in what they read, their voices re-echoed the Christ, they hoped He would come, and recognized Him not when present; they boasted, even they, of being amongst those who saw, that is, among the wise, and they disowned the Christ, and entered not in by the door.

**[45:23]** Therefore would such also, if they chanced to seduce any, seduce them to be slaughtered and murdered, not to be brought into liberty.

**[45:24]** Let us leave these also to themselves, and look at those who glory in the name of Christ Himself, and see whether even they perchance are entering in by the door.

**[45:25]** 5.

**[45:26]** For there are countless numbers who not only boast that they see, but would have it appear that they are enlightened by Christ; yet are they heretics.

**[45:27]** Have even they somehow entered by the gate? Surely not.

**[45:28]** Sabellius says, He who is the Son is Himself the Father; but if the Son, then is there no Father.

**[45:29]** He enters not by the door, who asserts that the Son is the Father.

**[45:30]** Arius says, The Father is one thing, the Son is another thing.

**[45:31]** He would say rightly if he said, Another person; but not another thing.

**[45:32]** For when he says, Another thing, he contradicts Him who says in his hearing, "I and my Father are One".

**[45:33]** Neither does he therefore enter by the door; for he preaches a Christ such as he fabricates for himself, not such as the truth declares Him.

**[45:34]** Thou hast the name, thou hast not the reality.

**[45:35]** Christ is the name of something; keep hold of the thing itself, if thou wouldst benefit by the name.

**[45:36]** Another, I know not from whence, says with Photinus, Christ is mere man; He is not God.

**[45:37]** He enters not in by the door, for Christ is both man and God.

**[45:38]** But why need I make many references, and enumerate the many vanities of heretics? Keep hold of this, that Christ's sheepfold is the Catholic Church.

**[45:39]** Whoever would enter the sheepfold, let him enter by the door, let him preach the true Christ.

**[45:40]** Not only let him preach the true Christ, but seek Christ's glory, not his own; for many, by seeking their own glory, have scattered Christ's sheep, instead of gathering them.

**[45:41]** For Christ the Lord is a low gateway: he who  enters by this gateway must humble himself, that he may be able to enter with head unharmed.

**[45:42]** But he that humbleth not, but exalteth himself, wishes to climb over the wall; and he that climbeth over the wall, is exalted only to fall.

**[45:43]** 6.

**[45:44]** Thus far, however, the Lord Jesus speaks in covert language; not as yet is He understood.

**[45:45]** He names the door, He names the sheepfold, He names the sheep: all this He sets forth, but does not yet explain.

**[45:46]** Let us read on then, for He is coming to those words, wherein He may think proper to give us some explanation of what He has said; from the explanation of which He will perhaps enable us to understand also what He has not explained.

**[45:47]** For He gives us what is plain, for food; what is obscure, for exercise.

**[45:48]** "He that entereth not by the door into the sheepfold, but climbeth up some other way".

**[45:49]** Woe to the wretch, for he is sure to fall! Let him then be humble, let him enter by the door: let him walk on the level ground, and he shall not stumble.

**[45:50]** "The same," He says, "is a thief and a robber".

**[45:51]** The sheep of another he desires to call his own sheep,—his own, that is, as carried off by stealth, for the purpose, not of saving, but of slaying them.

**[45:52]** Therefore is he a thief, because what is another's he calls his own; a robber, because what he has stolen he also kills.

**[45:53]** "But he that entereth in by the door is the shepherd of the sheep: to him the porter openeth".

**[45:54]** Concerning this porter we shall make inquiry, when we have heard of the Lord Himself what is the door and who is the shepherd.

**[45:55]** "And the sheep hear his voice: and he calleth his own sheep by name".

**[45:56]** For He has their names written in the book of life.

**[45:57]** "He calleth his own sheep by name".

**[45:58]** Hence, says the apostle, "The Lord knoweth them that are His".

**[45:59]** "And he leadeth them out.

**[45:60]** And when he putteth forth his own sheep, he goeth before them, and the sheep follow him: for they know his voice.

**[45:61]** And a stranger do they not follow, but do flee from him: for they know not the voice of strangers".

**[45:62]** These are veiled words, full of topics of inquiry, pregnant with sacramental signs.

**[45:63]** Let us follow then, and listen to the Master as He makes some opening into these obscurities; and perhaps by the opening He makes, He will cause us to enter.

**[45:64]** 7.

**[45:65]** "This parable spake Jesus unto them; but they understood not what He spake unto them".

**[45:66]** Nor we also, perhaps.

**[45:67]** What, then, is the difference between them and us, before even we can understand these words? This, that we on our part knock, that it may be opened unto us; while they, by disowning Christ, refused to enter for salvation, and preferred remaining outside to be destroyed.

**[45:68]** In as far, then, as we listen to these words with a pious mind, in as far as, before we understand them, we believe them to be true and divine, we stand at a great distance from these men.

**[45:69]** For when two persons are listening to the words of the gospel, the one impious, the other pious, and some of these are such as neither perhaps understands, the one says, It has said nothing; the other says, It has said the truth, and what it has said is good, but we do not understand it.

**[45:70]** This latter, because he believes, now knocks, that he may be worthy to have it opened up to him, if he continue knocking; but the other still hears the words, "If ye believe not, ye shall not understand".

**[45:71]** Why do I draw your attention to this? Even for this reason, that when I have explained as I can these obscure words, or, because of their great abstruseness, I have either myself failed to arrive at an understanding of them, or wanted the faculty of explaining what I do understand, or every one has been so dull as not to follow me, even when I give the explanation, yet should he not despair of himself; but continue in faith, walk on in the way, and hear the apostle saying, "And if in anything ye be otherwise minded, God shall reveal even this unto you.

**[45:72]** Nevertheless whereto we have already attained, let us walk therein".

**[45:73]** 8.

**[45:74]** Let us begin, then, with hearing His exposition of what we have heard Him propounding.

**[45:75]** "Then said Jesus unto them again, Verily, verily, I say unto you, I am the door of the sheep".

**[45:76]** See, He has opened the very door which was shut in His former description.

**[45:77]** He Himself is the door.

**[45:78]** We have come to know it; let us enter, or rejoice that we are already within.

**[45:79]** "All that ever came are thieves and robbers".

**[45:80]** What is this, Lord, "All that ever came"? How so hast Thou not come? But understand; I said, "All that ever came," meaning, of course, exclusive of myself.

**[45:81]** Let us recollect then.

**[45:82]** Before His coming came the prophets: were they thieves and robbers? God forbid.

**[45:83]** They did not come apart from Him, for they came  with Him.

**[45:84]** When about to come, He sent heralds, but retained possession of the hearts of His messengers.

**[45:85]** Do you wish to know that they came with Him, who is Himself ever existent? Certainly He assumed human flesh at the time appointed.

**[45:86]** But what means that "ever"? "In the beginning was the Word".

**[45:87]** With Him, therefore, came those who came with the word of God.

**[45:88]** "I am," said He, "the way, and the truth, and the life".

**[45:89]** If He is the truth, with Him came those who were truthful.

**[45:90]** As many, therefore, as were apart from Him, were "thieves and robbers," that is, had come to steal and to destroy.

**[45:91]** 9.

**[45:92]** "But the sheep did not hear them".

**[45:93]** This is a more important point, "the sheep did not hear them".

**[45:94]** Before the advent of our Lord Jesus Christ, when He came in humility in the flesh, righteous men preceded, believing in the same way in Him who was to come, as we believe in Him who has come.

**[45:95]** Times vary, but not faith.

**[45:96]** For verbs themselves also vary with the tense, when they are variously declined.

**[45:97]** He is to come, has one sound; He has come, has another: there is a change in the sound between He is to come, and He has come: yet the same faith unites both,—both those who believed that He would come, and those who have believed that He is come.

**[45:98]** At different times, indeed, but by the one doorway of faith, that is, by Christ, do we see that both have entered.

**[45:99]** We believe that the Lord Jesus Christ was born of the Virgin, that He came in the flesh, suffered, rose again, ascended into heaven: all this, just as you hear verbs of the past tense, we believe to be already fulfilled.

**[45:100]** In that faith a partnership is also held with us by those fathers who believed that He would be born of the Virgin, would suffer, would rise again, would ascend into heaven; for to such the apostle pointed when he said, "But we having the same spirit of faith, according as it is written, I believed, and therefore have I spoken; we also believe, and therefore speak".

**[45:101]** The prophet said, "I believed, therefore have I spoken:" the apostle says, "We also believe, and therefore speak".

**[45:102]** But to let you know that their faith is one, listen to him saying, "Having the same spirit of faith, we also believe".

**[45:103]** So also in another place, "For I would not have you ignorant, brethren, how that all our fathers were under the cloud, and all passed through the sea: and were all baptized unto Moses in the cloud and in the sea; and did all eat the same spiritual meat, and did all drink the same spiritual drink".

**[45:104]** The Red Sea signifies baptism; Moses, their leader through the Red Sea, signifies Christ; the people, who passed through, signify believers; the death of the Egyptians signifies the abolition of sins.

**[45:105]** Under different signs there is the same faith.

**[45:106]** It is with different signs as with different words [verbs]; for verbs change their sounds through the tenses, and verbs are indeed nothing else than signs.

**[45:107]** For they are words because of what they signify: take away the meaning from a word, and it becomes a senseless sound.

**[45:108]** All, therefore, have become signs.

**[45:109]** Was not the same faith theirs by whom these signs were employed, and by whom were foretold in prophecy the very things which we believe? Certainly it was: but they believed that they were yet to come, and we, that they have come.

**[45:110]** In like manner does he also say, "They all drank the same spiritual drink;" "the same spiritual," for it was not the same material [drink].

**[45:111]** For what was it they drank? "For they drank of the spiritual Rock that followed them; and that Rock was Christ".

**[45:112]** See, then, how that while the faith remained, the signs were varied.

**[45:113]** There the rock was Christ; to us that is Christ which is placed on the altar of God.

**[45:114]** And they, as a great sacramental sign of the same Christ, drank the water flowing from the rock: what we drink is known to believers.

**[45:115]** If one's thoughts turn to the visible form, the thing is different; if to the meaning that addresses the understanding, they drank the same spiritual drink.

**[45:116]** As many, then, at that time as believed, whether Abraham, or Isaac, or Jacob, or Moses, or the other patriarchs or prophets who foretold of Christ, were sheep, and heard Christ.

**[45:117]** His voice, and not another's, did they hear.

**[45:118]** The Judge was present in the person of the Crier.

**[45:119]** For even when the judge speaks through the crier, the clerk does not make it, The crier said; but the judge said.

**[45:120]** But others there are whom the sheep did not hear, in whom Christ's voice had no place,—wanderers, uttering falsehoods, prating inanities, fabricating vanities, misleading the miserable.

**[45:121]** 10.

**[45:122]** Why is it, then, that I have said, This is a more important point? What is there about it obscure and difficult to understand? Listen, I beseech you.

**[45:123]** See, the Lord Jesus Christ Himself came and preached.

**[45:124]** Much more surely was that the Shepherd's voice which was uttered by the very mouth of the  Shepherd.

**[45:125]** For if the Shepherd's voice came through the prophets, how much more did the Shepherd's own tongue give utterance to the Shepherd's voice? Yet all did not hear Him.

**[45:126]** But what are we to think? Those who did hear, were they sheep? Lo? Judas heard, and was a wolf: he followed, but, clad in sheep-skin, he was laying snares for the Shepherd.

**[45:127]** Some, again, of those who crucified Christ did not hear, and yet were sheep; for such He saw in the crowd when He said, "When ye have lifted up the Son of man, then shall ye know that I am He".

**[45:128]** Now, how is this question to be solved? They that are not sheep do hear, and they that are sheep do not hear.

**[45:129]** Some, who are wolves, follow the Shepherd's voice; and some, that are sheep, contradict it.

**[45:130]** Last of all, the sheep slay the Shepherd.

**[45:131]** The point is solved; for some one in reply says, But when they did not hear, as yet they were not sheep, they were then wolves: the voice, when it was heard, changed them, and out of wolves transformed them into sheep; and so, when they became sheep, they heard, and found the Shepherd, and followed Him.

**[45:132]** They built their hopes on the Shepherd's promises, because they obeyed His precepts.

**[45:133]** 11.

**[45:134]** That question has been solved in a way, and perhaps satisfies every one.

**[45:135]** But I bare still a subject of concern, and what concerns me I shall impart to you, that, in some sort inquiring together, I may through His revelation be found worthy with you to attain the solution.

**[45:136]** Hear, then, what it is that moves me.

**[45:137]** By the Prophet Ezekiel the Lord rebukes the shepherds, and among other things says of the sheep, "The wandering sheep have ye not recalled".

**[45:138]** He both declares it a wanderer, and calls it a sheep.

**[45:139]** If, while wandering, it was a sheep, whose voice was it hearing to lead it astray? For doubtless it would not be straying were it hearing the shepherd's voice: but it strayed just because it heard another's voice; it heard the voice of the thief and the robber.

**[45:140]** Surely the sheep do not hear the voice of robbers.

**[45:141]** "Those that came," He said,—and we are to understand, apart from me,—that is, "those that came apart from me are thieves and robbers, and the sheep did not hear them".

**[45:142]** Lord, if the sheep did not hear them, how can the sheep wander? If the sheep hear only Thee, and Thou art the truth, whoever heareth the truth cannot certainly fall into error.

**[45:143]** But they err, and are called sheep.

**[45:144]** For if, in the very midst of their wandering, they were not called sheep, it would not be said by Ezekiel, "The wandering sheep have ye not recalled".

**[45:145]** How is it at the same time a wanderer and a sheep? Has it heard the voice of another? Surely "the sheep did not hear them".

**[45:146]** Accordingly many are just now being gathered into Christ's fold, and from being heretics are becoming catholics.

**[45:147]** They are rescued from the thieves, and restored to the shepherds: and sometimes they murmur, and become wearied of Him that calls them back, and have no true knowledge of him that would murder them; nevertheless also, when, after a struggle, those have come who are sheep, they recognize the Shepherd's voice, and are glad they have come, and are ashamed of their wandering.

**[45:148]** When, then, they were glorying in that state of error as in the truth, and were certainly not hearing the Shepherd's voice, but were following another, were they sheep, or were they not? If they were sheep, how can it be the case that the sheep do not listen to aliens? If they were not sheep, wherefore the rebuke addressed to those to whom it is said, "The wandering sheep have ye not recalled"? In the case also of those already become catholic Christians, and believers of good promise, evils sometimes occur: they are seduced into error, and after their error are restored.

**[45:149]** When they were thus seduced, and were rebaptized, or after the companionship of the Lord's fold were turned back again into their former error, were they sheep, or were they not? Certainly they were catholics.

**[45:150]** If they were faithful catholics, they were sheep.

**[45:151]** If they were sheep, how was it that they could listen to the voice of a stranger when the Lord saith, "The sheep did not hear them"?  12.

**[45:152]** You hear, brethren, the great importance of the question.

**[45:153]** I say then, "The Lord knoweth them that are His".

**[45:154]** He knoweth those who were foreknown, He knoweth those who were predestinated; because it is said of Him, "For whom He did foreknow, He also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of His Son, that He might be the firstborn among many brethren.

**[45:155]** Moreover, whom He did predestinate, them He also called; and whom He called, them He also justified; and whom He justified, them He also glorified.

**[45:156]** If God be for us, who can be against us?" Add to this: "He that spared not His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all, how hath He not with Him also freely given us all things?" But what "us"? Those who are foreknown, predestinated, justified, glorified; regarding  whom there follows, "Who shall lay anything to the charge of God's elect?" Therefore "the Lord knoweth them that are His;" they are the sheep.

**[45:157]** Such sometimes do not know themselves, but the Shepherd knoweth them, according to this predestination, this foreknowledge of God, according to the election of the sheep before the foundation of the world: for so saith also the apostle, "According as He hath chosen us in Him before the foundation of the world".

**[45:158]** According, then, to this divine foreknowledge and predestination, how many sheep are outside, how many wolves within! and how many sheep are inside, how many wolves without! How many are now living in wantonness who will yet be chaste! how many are blaspheming Christ who will yet believe in Him! how many are giving themselves to drunkenness who will yet be sober! how many are preying on other people property who will yet freely give of their own! Nevertheless at present they are hearing the voice of another, they are following strangers.

**[45:159]** In like manner, how many are praising within who will yet blaspheme; are chaste who will yet be fornicators; are sober who will wallow hereafter in drink; are standing who will by and by fall! These are not the sheep.

**[45:160]** (For we speak of those who were predestinated,—of those whom the Lord knoweth that they are His.

**[45:161]** ) And yet these, so long as they keep right, listen to the voice of Christ.

**[45:162]** Yea, these hear, the others do not; and yet, according to predestination, these are not sheep, while the others are.

**[45:163]** 13.

**[45:164]** There remains still the question, which I now think may meanwhile thus be solved.

**[45:165]** There is a voice of some kind,—there is, I say, a certain kind of voice of the Shepherd, in respect of which the sheep hear not strangers, and in respect of which those who are not sheep do not hear Christ.

**[45:166]** What a word is this! "He that endureth to the end, the same shall be saved".

**[45:167]** No one of His own is indifferent to such a voice, a stranger does not hear it: for this reason also does He announce it to the former, that he may abide perseveringly with Himself to the end; but by one who is wanting in such persevering continuance with Him, such a word remains unheard.

**[45:168]** One has come to Christ, and has heard word after word of one kind and another, all of them true, all of them salutary; and among all the rest is also this utterance, "He that endureth to the end, the same shall be saved".

**[45:169]** He who has heard this is one of the sheep.

**[45:170]** But there was, perhaps, some one listening to it, who treated it with dislike, with coldness, and heard it as that of a stranger.

**[45:171]** If he was predestinated, he strayed for the time, but he was not lost for ever: he returns to hear what he has neglected, to do what he has heard.

**[45:172]** For if he is one of those who are predestinated, then both his very wandering and his future conversion have been foreknown by God: if he has strayed away, he will return to hear that voice of the Shepherd, and to follow Him who saith, "He that endureth to the end, the same shall be saved".

**[45:173]** A good voice, brethren, it is; true and shepherd-like, the very voice of salvation in the tabernacles of the righteous.

**[45:174]** For it is easy to hear Christ, easy to praise the gospel, easy to applaud the preacher: but to endure unto the end, is peculiar to the sheep who hear the Shepherd's voice.

**[45:175]** A temptation befalls thee, endure thou to the end, for the temptation will not endure to the end.

**[45:176]** And what is that end to which thou shalt endure? Even till thou reachest the end of thy pathway.

**[45:177]** For as long as thou hearest not Christ, He is thine adversary in the pathway, that is, in this mortal life.

**[45:178]** And what doth He say? "Agree with thine adversary quickly, while thou art in the way with him".

**[45:179]** Thou hast heard, hast believed, hast agreed.

**[45:180]** If thou hast been at enmity, agree.

**[45:181]** If thou hast got the opportunity of coming to an agreement, keep not up the quarrel longer.

**[45:182]** For thou knowest not when thy way will be ended, and it is known to Him.

**[45:183]** If thou art a sheep, and if thou endurest to the end, thou shalt be saved: and therefore it is that His own despise not that voice, and strangers hear it not.

**[45:184]** According to my ability, as He gave me the power, I have either explained to you or gone over with you a subject of great profundity.

**[45:185]** If any have failed fully to understand, let him retain his piety, and the truth will be revealed: and let not those who have understood vaunt themselves as swifter at the expense of the slower, lest in their vaunting they turn out of the track, and the slower more easily attain the goal.

**[45:186]** But let all of us be guided by Him to whom we say, "Lead me, O Lord, in Thy way, and I will walk in Thy truth".

**[45:187]** 14.

**[45:188]** By this, then, which the Lord hath explained, that He Himself is the door, let us find entrance to what He has set forth, but not explained.

**[45:189]** And indeed who it is that is the Shepherd, although He hath not told us in the lesson we have read to-day, yet in that which follows He very plainly tells us: "I am the good Shepherd".

**[45:190]** And although He had not said so, whom else but Himself ought  we to have understood in those words where He saith, "He that entereth in by the door is the Shepherd of the sheep.

**[45:191]** To Him the porter openeth: and the sheep hear His voice: and He calleth His own sheep by name, and leadeth them out.

**[45:192]** And when He putteth forth His own sheep, He goeth before them, and the sheep follow Him: for they know His voice"? For who else calleth His own sheep by name, and leadeth them hence unto eternal life, but He who knoweth the names of those that are fore-ordained? Hence He said to His disciples, "Rejoice that your names are written in heaven;" for from this it is that He calleth them by name.

**[45:193]** And who else putteth them forth, save He who putteth away their sins, that, freed from their grievous fetters, they may be able to follow Him? And who hath gone before them to the place whither they are to follow Him, but He who, rising from the dead, dieth no more; and death shall have no more dominion over Him; and who, when He was manifest here in the flesh, said, "Father, I will that they also whom Thou hast given me be with me where I am"? Hence it is that He saith, "I am the door: by me if any man enter in, he shall be saved, and shall go in and out, and find pasture".

**[45:194]** In this He clearly shows that not only the Shepherd, but the sheep also enter in by the door.

**[45:195]** 15.

**[45:196]** But what is this, "He shall go in and out, and find pasture"? To enter indeed into the Church by Christ the door, is eminently good; but to go out of the Church, as this same John the evangelist saith in his epistle, "They went out from us, but they were not of us," is certainly otherwise than good.

**[45:197]** Such a going out could not then be commended by the good Shepherd, when He said, "And he shall go in and out, and find pasture".

**[45:198]** There is therefore not only some sort of entrance, but some outgoing also that is good, by the good door, which is Christ.

**[45:199]** But what is that praiseworthy and blessed outgoing? I might say, indeed, that we enter when we engage in some inward exercise of thought; and go out, when we take to some active work without: and since, as the apostle saith, Christ dwelleth in our hearts by faith, to enter by Christ is to give ourselves to thought in accordance with that faith; but to go out by Christ is, in accordance also with that same faith, to take to outside works, that is to say, in the presence of others.

**[45:200]** Hence, also, we read in a psalm, "Man goeth forth to his work;" and the Lord Himself saith, "Let your works shine before men".

**[45:201]** But I am better pleased that the Truth Himself, like a good Shepherd, and therefore a good Teacher, hath in a certain measure reminded us how we ought to understand His words, "He shall go in and out, and find pasture," when He added in the sequel, "The thief cometh not, but for to steal, and to kill, and to destroy: I am come that they might have life, and that they might have it more abundantly".

**[45:202]** For He seems to me to have meant, That they may have life in coming in, and have it more abundantly at their departure.

**[45:203]** For no one can pass out by the door—that is, by Christ—to that eternal life which shall be open to the sight, unless by the same door—that is, by the same Christ—he has entered His church, which is His fold, to the temporal life, which is lived in faith.

**[45:204]** Therefore, He saith, "I am come that they may have life," that is, faith, which worketh by love; by which faith they enter the fold that they may live, for the just liveth by faith: "and that they may have it more abundantly," who, enduring unto the end, pass out by this same door, that is, by the faith of Christ; for as true believers they die, and will have life more abundantly when they come whither the Shepherd hath preceded them, where they shall die no more.

**[45:205]** Although, therefore, there is no want of pasture even here in the fold,—for we may understand the words "and shall find pasture" as referring to both, that is, both to their going in and their going out,—yet there only will they find the true pasture.

**[45:206]** where they shall be filled who hunger and thirst after righteousness,—such pasture as was found by him to whom it was said, "To-day shalt thou be with me in paradise".

**[45:207]** But how He Himself is the door, and Himself the Shepherd, so that He also may in a certain respect be understood as going in and out by Himself, and who is the porter, it would be too long to inquire to-day, and, according to the grace given us by Himself, to unfold in the way of dissertation.

**[46:1]** Tractate XLVI.

**[46:2]** Chapter X.

**[46:3]** 11–13  1.

**[46:4]** The Lord Jesus is speaking to His sheep—to those already so, and to those yet to become such—who were then present; for in the place where they were, there were those who were already His sheep, as well as those who were afterwards to become so: and He likewise shows to those then present and those to come, both to them and to us, and to as many also after us as shall yet be His sheep, who it is that had been sent to them.

**[46:5]** All, therefore, hear the voice of their Shepherd saying, "I am the good Shepherd".

**[46:6]** He would not add "good," were there not bad shepherds.

**[46:7]** But the bad shepherds are those who are thieves and robbers, or certainly hirelings at the best.

**[46:8]** For we ought to examine into, to distinguish, and to know, all the characters whom He has here depicted.

**[46:9]** The Lord has already unfolded two points, which He had previously set forth in a kind of covert form: we already know that He is Himself the door, and we know that He is Himself the Shepherd.

**[46:10]** Who the thieves and robbers are, was made clear in yesterday's lesson; and to-day we have heard of the hireling, as we have heard also of the wolf.

**[46:11]** Yesterday the porter was also introduced by name.

**[46:12]** Among the good, therefore, are the door, the doorkeeper, the shepherd, and the sheep: among the bad, the thieves and robbers, the hirelings, and the wolf.

**[46:13]** 2.

**[46:14]** We understand the Lord Christ as the door, and also as the Shepherd; but who is to be understood as the doorkeeper? For the former two, He has Himself explained: the doorkeeper He has left us to search out for ourselves.

**[46:15]** And what doth He say of the doorkeeper? "To him," He saith, "the porter [doorkeeper] openeth".

**[46:16]** To whom doth he open? To the Shepherd.

**[46:17]** What doth he open to the Shepherd? The door.

**[46:18]** And who is also the door? The Shepherd Himself.

**[46:19]** Now, if Christ the Lord had not Himself explained, had not Himself said, "I am the Shepherd," and "I am the door," would any of us have ventured to say that Christ is Himself both the Shepherd and the door? For had He said, "I am the Shepherd," and had not said, "I am the door," we should be setting ourselves to inquire what was the door, and perhaps, mistaken in our views, be still standing before the door.

**[46:20]** His grace and mercy have revealed to us the Shepherd, by His calling Himself so; have revealed to us also the door, when declared Himself such; but He hath left us to search out the doorkeeper for ourselves.

**[46:21]** Whom, then, are we to call the doorkeeper? Whomsoever we fix upon, we must take care not to think of him as greater than the door itself; for in men's houses the doorkeeper is greater than the door.

**[46:22]** The doorkeeper is placed before the door, not the door before the doorkeeper; because the porter keepeth the door, not the door the porter.

**[46:23]** I dare not say that any one is greater than the door, for I have heard already what is the door: that is no longer unknown to me, I am not left to my own conjecture, and I have not got much room for mere human guess work: God hath said it, the Truth hath said it, and we cannot change what the Unchangeable hath uttered.

**[46:24]** 3.

**[46:25]** In respect, then, of the profound nature of this question, I shall tell you what I think: let each one make the choice that pleases him, but let him think of it reverently; as it is written, "Think of the Lord with goodness, and in simplicity of heart seek Him".

**[46:26]** Perhaps we ought to understand the Lord Himself as the doorkeeper: for the shepherd and the door are in human respects as much different from each other as the doorkeeper and the door; and yet the Lord has called Himself both the Shepherd and the door.

**[46:27]** Why, then, may we not understand Him also as the doorkeeper? For if we look at His personal qualities, the Lord Christ is neither a shepherd, in the way we are accustomed to know and to see shepherds; nor is He a door, for no artisan made Him: but if, because of some point of similarity, He is both the door and the Shepherd, I venture to say, He is also a sheep.

**[46:28]** True, the sheep is under the shepherd; yet He is both the Shepherd and a sheep.

**[46:29]** Where is He the Shepherd? Look, here thou hast it; read the Gospel: "I am the good Shepherd".

**[46:30]** Where is He a sheep? Ask the prophet: "He was led as a sheep to the slaughter".

**[46:31]** Ask the friend of the bridegroom: "Behold the Lamb of God, that taketh away the sin of the world".

**[46:32]** Moreover,  I am going to say something of a still more wonderful kind, in accordance with these points of similarity.

**[46:33]** For both the lamb, and the sheep, and the shepherd are friendly with one another, but from the lions as their foes the sheep are protected by their shepherds: and yet of Christ, who is both sheep and Shepherd, we have it said, "The Lion of the tribe of Judah hath prevailed".

**[46:34]** All this, brethren, understand in connection with points of similarity, not with personal qualities.

**[46:35]** It is a common thing to see the shepherds sitting on a rock, and there guarding the cattle committed to their care.

**[46:36]** Surely the shepherd is better than the rock that he sits upon; and yet Christ is both the Shepherd and the rock.

**[46:37]** All this by way of comparison.

**[46:38]** But if thou askest me for His peculiar personal quality: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

**[46:39]** If thou askest me for the personal quality peculiarly His own: The only Son, from everlasting to everlasting begotten of the Father, the equal of Him that begat, the Maker of all things, unchangeable with the Father, unchanged by the assuming of human form, man by incarnation, the Son of man, and the Son of God.

**[46:40]** All this that I have said is not figure, but reality.

**[46:41]** 4.

**[46:42]** Therefore, let us not, brethren, be disturbed in understanding Him, in harmony with certain resemblances, as Himself the door, and also the doorkeeper.

**[46:43]** For what is the door? The way of entrance.

**[46:44]** Who is the doorkeeper? He who opens it.

**[46:45]** Who, then, is He that opens Himself, but He who unveils Himself to sight? See, when the Lord spoke at first of the door, we did not understand: so long as we did not understand, it was shut: He who opened it is Himself the doorkeeper.

**[46:46]** There is no need, then, of seeking any other meaning, no need; but perhaps there is the desire.

**[46:47]** If there is so, quit not the path, go not outside of the Trinity.

**[46:48]** If thou art in quest of some other impersonation of the doorkeeper, bethink thee of the Holy Spirit; for the Holy Spirit will not think it unmeet to be the doorkeeper, when the Son has thought it meet to be Himself the door.

**[46:49]** Look at the doorkeeper as perhaps the Holy Spirit: about Him the Lord saith to His disciples, "He shall guide you into all truth".

**[46:50]** What is the door? Christ.

**[46:51]** What is Christ? The Truth.

**[46:52]** Who, then, openeth the door, but He who guideth into all truth?  5.

**[46:53]** But what are we to say of the hireling? He is not mentioned here among the good.

**[46:54]** "The good Shepherd," He says, "giveth His life for the sheep.

**[46:55]** But he that is an hireling, and not the Shepherd, whose own the sheep are not, seeth the wolf coming, and leaveth the sheep, and fleeth; and the wolf catcheth them, and scattereth the sheep".

**[46:56]** The hireling does not here bear a good character, and yet in some respects is useful; nor would he be called an hireling, did he not receive hire from his employer.

**[46:57]** Who then is this hireling, that is both blameworthy and needful? And here, brethren, let the Lord Himself give us light, that we may know who the hirelings are, and be not hirelings ourselves.

**[46:58]** Who then is the hireling? There are some in office in the church, of whom the Apostle Paul saith, "Who seek their own, not the things that are Jesus Christ's".

**[46:59]** What means that, "Who seek their own"? Who do not love Christ freely, who do not seek after God for His own sake; who are pursuing after temporal advantages, gaping for gain, coveting honors from men.

**[46:60]** When such things are loved by an overseer, and for such things God is served, whoever such an one may be, he is an hireling who cannot count himself among the children.

**[46:61]** For of such also the Lord saith: "Verily, I say unto you, they have their reward".

**[46:62]** Listen to what the Apostle Paul says of St.

**[46:63]** Timothy: "But I trust in the Lord Jesus to send Timothy shortly unto you, that I also may be of good comfort, when I know your circumstances; for I have no man like-minded, who will naturally care for you.

**[46:64]** For all seek their own, not the things which are Jesus Christ's".

**[46:65]** The shepherd mourned in the midst of hirelings.

**[46:66]** He sought some one who sincerely loved the flock of Christ, and round about him, amongst those who were with him at that time, he found not one.

**[46:67]** Not that there was no one then in the Church of Christ but the Apostle Paul and Timothy, who had a brother's concern for the flock; but it so happened at the time of his sending Timothy, that he had none else of his sons about him; only hirelings were with him, "who sought their own, not the things which are Jesus Christ's".

**[46:68]** And yet he himself, with a brother's anxiety for the flock, preferred sending his son, and remaining himself amongst hirelings.

**[46:69]** Hirelings are also found among ourselves, but the Lord alone distinguisheth them.

**[46:70]** He that searcheth the heart, distinguisheth them; and yet sometimes we know them ourselves.

**[46:71]** For it was not without a purpose that the Lord Himself said also of the wolves: "By their fruits ye shall know  them".

**[46:72]** Temptations put many to the question, and then their thoughts are made manifest; but many remain undiscovered.

**[46:73]** The Lord's fold must have as overseers, both those who are children and those who are hirelings.

**[46:74]** But the overseers, who are sons, are the shepherds.

**[46:75]** If they are shepherds, how is there but one Shepherd, save that all of them are members of the one Shepherd, to whom the sheep belong? For they are also members of Himself as the one sheep; because "as a sheep he was led to the slaughter".

**[46:76]** 6.

**[46:77]** But give heed to the fact that even the hirelings are needful.

**[46:78]** For many indeed in the Church are following after earthly profit, and yet preach Christ, and through them is heard the voice of Christ; and the sheep follow, not the hireling, but the Shepherd's voice speaking through the hireling.

**[46:79]** Hearken to the hirelings as pointed out by the Lord Himself: "The scribes," He saith, "and the Pharisees sit in Moses' seat: do what they say; but do not what they do".

**[46:80]** What else said He but, Listen to the Shepherd's voice speaking through the hirelings? For sitting in Moses' seat, they teach the law of God; therefore God teacheth by them.

**[46:81]** But if they wish to teach their own things, hear them not, do them not.

**[46:82]** For certainly such seek their own, not the things which are Jesus Christ's; but no hireling has dared to say to Christ's people, Seek your own, not the things which are Jesus Christ's.

**[46:83]** For his own evil conduct he does not preach from the seat of Christ: he does injury by the evil that he does, not by the good that he says.

**[46:84]** Pluck the grapes, beware of the thorn.

**[46:85]** It is well I see that you have understood; but for the sake of those that are slower, I shall repeat these words with greater plainness.

**[46:86]** How said I, Pluck the bunch of grapes, beware of the thorn; when the Lord saith, "Do men gather grapes of thorns, or figs of thistles"? That is quite true: and yet what I said is also true, Pluck the bunch of grapes, beware of the thorn.

**[46:87]** For sometimes the grape-cluster, springing from the root of the vine, finds its support in a common hedge; its branch, grows, becomes embedded among thorns, and the thorn bears other fruit than its own.

**[46:88]** For the thorn has not been produced from the vine, but has become the resting-place of its runner.

**[46:89]** Make thine inquiries only at the roots.

**[46:90]** Seek for the thorn-root, thou wilt find it apart from the vine: seek the origin of the grape, and from the root of the vine it will be found to have sprung.

**[46:91]** And so, Moses' seat was the vine; the morals of the Pharisees were the thorns.

**[46:92]** Sound doctrine cometh through the wicked, as the vine-branch in a hedge, a bunch of grapes among thorns.

**[46:93]** Gather carefully, so as in seeking the fruit not to tear thine hand; and while thou art to hear one speaking what is good, imitate him not when doing what is evil.

**[46:94]** "What they tell you, do,"—gather the grapes; "but what they do, do not,"—beware of the thorns.

**[46:95]** Even through hirelings listen to the voice of the Shepherd, but be not hirelings yourselves, seeing ye are members of the Shepherd.

**[46:96]** Yea, Paul himself, the holy apostle who said, "I have no one who hath a brother's concern about you; for all seek their own, not the things which are Jesus Christ's," draws a distinction in another place between hirelings and sons; and see what he saith: "Some preach Christ even of envy and strife, and some also of good will: some of love, knowing that I am set for the defence of the gospel; but some also preach Christ of contention, not sincerely, supposing to add affliction to my bonds".

**[46:97]** These were hirelings who disliked the Apostle Paul.

**[46:98]** And why such dislike, but just because they were seeking after temporal things? But mark what he adds: "What then, notwithstanding, every way, whether in pretence or in truth, Christ is preached: and I therein do rejoice, yea, and will rejoice".

**[46:99]** Christ is the truth: let the truth be preached in pretense by hirelings, let it be preached in truth by the children: the children are waiting patiently for the eternal inheritance of the Father, the hirelings are longing for, and in a hurry to get, the temporal pay of their employer.

**[46:100]** For my part let me be shorn of the human glory, which I see such an object of envy to hirelings: and yet by the tongues both of hirelings and of children let the divine glory of Christ be published abroad, seeing that, "whether in pretense or in truth, Christ is preached".

**[46:101]** 7.

**[46:102]** We have seen who the hireling is also.

**[46:103]** Who, but the devil, is the wolf? And what was said of the hireling? "When he seeth the wolf coming, he fleeth: but the sheep are not his own, and he careth not for the sheep".

**[46:104]** Was the Apostle Paul such an one? Certainly not.

**[46:105]** Was Peter such an one? Far from it.

**[46:106]** Was such the character of the other apostles, save Judas, the son of perdition? Surely not.

**[46:107]** Were they shepherds then? Certainly they were.

**[46:108]** And how is there one Shepherd? I have already said they were shepherds, because members of the Shepherd.

**[46:109]** In that head they rejoiced, under that head  they were in harmony together, with one spirit they lived in the bond of one body; and therefore belonged all of them to the one Shepherd.

**[46:110]** If, then, they were shepherds, and not hirelings, wherefore fled they when suffering persecution? Explain it to us, O Lord.

**[46:111]** In an epistle, I have seen Paul fleeing: he was let down by the wall in a basket, to escape the hands of his persecutor.

**[46:112]** Had he, then, no care of the sheep, whom he thus abandoned at the approach of the wolf? Clearly he had, but he commended them by his prayers to the Shepherd who was sitting in heaven; and for their advantage he preserved himself by flight, as he says in a certain place, "To abide in the flesh is needful for you".

**[46:113]** For all had heard from the Shepherd Himself, "If they persecute you in one city, flee ye into another".

**[46:114]** May the Lord be pleased to explain to us this point! Lord, Thou saidst to those whom Thou didst certainly wish to be faithful shepherds, and whom Thou didst form into Thine own members, "If they persecute you, flee".

**[46:115]** Doest Thou, then, injustice to them, when Thou blamest the hirelings who flee when they see the wolf coming! We ask Thee to tell us what meaning lies hid in the depths of the question.

**[46:116]** Let us knock, and the keeper of the door, which is Christ, will be here to reveal Himself.

**[46:117]** 8.

**[46:118]** Who is the hireling that seeth the wolf coming, and fleeth? He that seeketh his own, not the things which are Jesus Christ's.

**[46:119]** He is one that does not venture plainly to rebuke an offender.

**[46:120]** Look, some one or other has sinned—grievously sinned; he ought to be rebuked, to be excommunicated: but once excommunicated, he will turn into an enemy, hatch plots, and do all the injury he can.

**[46:121]** At present, he who seeketh his own, not the things that are Jesus Christ's, in order not to lose what he follows after, the advantages of human friendship, and incur the annoyances of human enmity, keeps quiet and does not administer rebuke.

**[46:122]** See, the wolf has caught a sheep by the throat; the devil has enticed a believer into adultery: thou holdest thy peace—thou utterest no reproof.

**[46:123]** O hireling, thou hast seen the wolf coming and hast fled! Perhaps he answers and says: See, I am here; I have not fled.

**[46:124]** Thou hast fled, because thou hast been silent; thou hast been silent, because thou hast been afraid.

**[46:125]** The flight of the mind is fear.

**[46:126]** Thou stoodest with thy body, thou fleddest in thy spirit, which was not the conduct of him who said, "Though I be absent in the flesh, yet am I with you in the spirit".

**[46:127]** For how did he flee in spirit, who, though absent in the flesh, yet in his letters reproved the fornicators? Our affections are the motions of our minds.

**[46:128]** Joy is expansion of the mind; sorrow, contraction of the mind; desire, a forward movement of the mind; and fear, the flight of the mind.

**[46:129]** For thou art expanded in mind when thou art glad; contracted in mind when thou art in trouble; thou movest forward in mind when thou hast an earnest desire; and thou fleest in mind when thou art afraid.

**[46:130]** This, then, is how the hireling is said to flee at the sight of the wolf.

**[46:131]** Why? "Because he careth not for the sheep".

**[46:132]** Why "careth he not for the sheep"? "Because he is an hireling".

**[46:133]** What is that, "he is an hireling"? He seeketh a temporal reward, and shall not dwell in the house for ever.

**[46:134]** There are still some things here to be inquired about and discussed with you, but it is not prudent to burden you.

**[46:135]** For we are ministering the Lord's food to our fellow-servants; we feed as sheep in the Lord's pastures, and are fed together.

**[46:136]** And just as we must not withhold what is needful, so our weak hearts are not to be overcharged with the abundance of provisions.

**[46:137]** Let it not then annoy your Charity that I do not take up to-day all that I think is still here to be discussed; but the same lesson will, in the Lord's name, be read over to us again on the preaching days, and be, with His help, more carefully considered.

**[47:1]** Tractate XLVII.

**[47:2]** Chapter X.

**[47:3]** 14–21  1.

**[47:4]** Those of you who hear the word of our God, not only with willingness, but also with attention, doubtless remember our promise.

**[47:5]** Indeed the same gospel lesson has also been read to-day which was read last Lord's day; because, having lingered over certain closely related topics, we could not discuss all that we owed to your powers of understanding.

**[47:6]** Accordingly, what has been already said and discoursed about we do not inquire into to  day, lest by continual repetitions we should be prevented from reaching what has still to be spoken.

**[47:7]** You know now in the Lord's name who is the good Shepherd, and in what way good shepherds are His members, and therefore the Shepherd is one.

**[47:8]** You know who is the hireling we have to bear with; who the wolf, and the thieves, and the robbers we have to beware of; who are the sheep, and what is the door whereby both sheep and shepherd enter: how we are to understand the doorkeeper.

**[47:9]** You know also that every one who entereth not by the door is a thief and a robber, and cometh not but to steal, and to kill, and to destroy.

**[47:10]** All these sayings have, as I think, been sufficiently handled.

**[47:11]** To-day we ought to tell you, as far as the Lord enables us (for Jesus Christ our Saviour hath Himself told us that He is both the Shepherd and the door, and that the good Shepherd entereth in by the door), how it is that He entereth in by Himself.

**[47:12]** For if no one is a good shepherd but he that entereth by the door, and He Himself is preeminently the good Shepherd, and also Himself the door, I can understand it only in this way, that He entereth in by Himself to His sheep, and calleth them to follow Him, and they, going in and out, find pasture, which is to say, eternal life.

**[47:13]** 2.

**[47:14]** I proceed, then, without more delay.

**[47:15]** When I seek to get into you, that is, into your heart, I preach Christ: were I preaching something else, I should be trying to climb up some other way.

**[47:16]** Christ, therefore, is my gate to you: by Christ I get entrance, not to your houses, but to your hearts.

**[47:17]** It is by Christ I enter: it is Christ in me that you have been willingly hearing.

**[47:18]** And why is it you have thus willingly hearkened to Christ in me? Because you are the sheep of Christ, purchased with the blood of Christ.

**[47:19]** You acknowledge your own price, which is not paid by me, but is preached by my instrumentality.

**[47:20]** He, and only He, was the buyer, who shed precious blood—the precious blood of Him who was without sin.

**[47:21]** Yet made He precious also the blood of His own, for whom He paid the price of blood: for had He not made the blood of His own precious, it would not have been said, "Precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of His saints".

**[47:22]** So also when He saith, "The good Shepherd giveth His life for the sheep," He is not the only one who has done such a deed; and yet if those who have done so are His members, He only Himself was the doer of it.

**[47:23]** For He was able to do so without them, but whence had they the power apart from Him, who Himself had said, "Without me ye can do nothing"? But from the same source we can show what others also have done, for the apostle John himself, who preached the very gospel you have been hearing, has said in his epistle, "Just as Christ laid down His life for us, so ought we also to lay down our lives for the brethren".

**[47:24]** "We ought," he says: He made us debtors who first set the example.

**[47:25]** To the same effect it is written in a certain place, "If thou sittest down to sup at a ruler's table, make wise observation of what is set before thee; and put to thy hand, knowing that it will be thy duty to make similar provision in turn".

**[47:26]** You know what is meant by the ruler's table: you there find the body and blood of Christ; let him who comes to such a table be ready with similar provision.

**[47:27]** And what is such similar provision? As He laid down His life for us, so ought we also, for the edification of others, and the maintenance of the faith, to lay down our lives for the brethren.

**[47:28]** To the same effect He said to Peter, whom He wished to make a good shepherd, not in Peter's own person, but as a member of His body: "Peter, lovest thou me? Feed my sheep".

**[47:29]** This He did once, again, and a third time, to the disciple's sorrow.

**[47:30]** And when the Lord had questioned him as often as He judged it needful, that he who had thrice denied might thrice confess Him, and had a third time given him the charge to feed His sheep, He said to him, "When thou wast young, thou girdedst thyself, and walkedst whither thou wouldest: but when thou shall be old, thou shalt stretch forth thy hands, and another shall gird thee, and carry thee whither thou wouldest not".

**[47:31]** And the evangelist has explained the Lord's meaning: "But this spake He, signifying by what death he should glorify God".

**[47:32]** "Feed my sheep" applies, then, to this, that thou shouldst lay down thy life for my sheep.

**[47:33]** 3.

**[47:34]** And now when He saith, "As the Father knoweth me, even so know I the Father," who can be ignorant of His meaning? For He knoweth the Father by Himself, and we by Him.

**[47:35]** That He hath knowledge by Himself, we know already: that we also have knowledge by Him, we have like  wise learned, for this also we have learned of Him.

**[47:36]** For He Himself hath said: "No one hath seen God at any time; but the only-begotten Son, who is in the bosom of the Father, He hath declared Him".

**[47:37]** And so by Him do we also get this knowledge, to whom He hath declared Him.

**[47:38]** In another place also He saith: "No one knoweth the Son, but the Father; neither knoweth any one the Father, save the Son, and he to whomsoever the Son will reveal Him".

**[47:39]** As He then knoweth the Father by Himself, and we know the Father by Him; so into the sheepfold He entereth by Himself, and we by Him.

**[47:40]** We were saying that by Christ we have a door of entrance to you; and why? Because we preach Christ.

**[47:41]** We preach Christ; and therefore we enter in by the door.

**[47:42]** But Christ preacheth Christ, for He preacheth Himself; and so the Shepherd entereth in by Himself.

**[47:43]** When the light shows the other things that are seen in the light, does it need some other means of being made visible itself? The light, then, exhibits both other things and itself.

**[47:44]** Whatever we understand, we understand with the intellect: and how, save by the intellect, do we understand the intellect itself? But does one in the same way with the bodily eye see both other things and [the eye] itself? For though men see with their eyes, yet their own eyes they see not.

**[47:45]** The eye of the flesh sees other things, itself it cannot [see]: but the intellect understands itself as well other things.

**[47:46]** In the same way as the intellect seeth itself, so also doth Christ preach Himself.

**[47:47]** If He preacheth Himself, and by preaching entereth into thee, He entereth into thee by Himself.

**[47:48]** And He is the door to the Father, for there is no way of approach to the Father but by Him.

**[47:49]** "For there is one God and one Mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus".

**[47:50]** Many things are expressed by a word: all that I have just said, I have said, of course, by means of words.

**[47:51]** If I were wishing to speak also of a word itself, how could I do so but by the use of the word? And thus both many things are expressed by a word, which are not the same as the word, and the word itself can only be expressed by means of the word.

**[47:52]** By the Lord's help we have been copious in illustration.

**[47:53]** Remember, then, how the Lord Jesus Christ is both the door and the Shepherd: the door, in presenting Himself to view; the Shepherd, in entering in by Himself.

**[47:54]** And indeed, brethren, because He is the Shepherd, He hath given to His members to be so likewise.

**[47:55]** For both Peter, and Paul, and the other apostles were, as all good bishops are, shepherds.

**[47:56]** But none of us calleth himself the door.

**[47:57]** This—the way of entrance for the sheep—He has retained as exclusively belonging to Himself.

**[47:58]** In short, Paul discharged the office of a good shepherd when he preached Christ, because he entered by the door.

**[47:59]** But when the undisciplined sheep began to create schisms, and to set up other doors before them, not of entrance to their joint assembly, but for falling away into divisions, saying, some of them, "I am of Paul;" others, "I am of Cephas;" others, "I of Apollos;" others, "I of Christ:" terrified for those who said, "I am of Paul,"—as if calling out to the sheep, Wretched ones, whither are you going? I am not the door,—he said, "Was Paul crucified for you? or were ye baptized in the name of Paul?" But those who said, "I am of Christ," had found the door.

**[47:60]** 4.

**[47:61]** But of the one sheepfold and of the one Shepherd, you are now indeed being constantly reminded; for we have commended much the one sheepfold, preaching unity, that all the sheep should enter by Christ, and none of them should follow Donatus.

**[47:62]** Nevertheless, for what particular reason this was said by the Lord, is sufficiently apparent.

**[47:63]** For He was speaking among the Jews, and had been specially sent to the Jews, not for the sake of that class who were bound up in their inhuman hatred and persistently abiding in darkness, but for the sake of some in the nation whom He calls His sheep: of whom He saith, "I am not sent but to the lost sheep of the house of Israel".

**[47:64]** He knew them even amid the crowd of His raging foes, and foresaw them in the peace of believing.

**[47:65]** What, then, does He mean by saying, "I am not sent but to the lost sheep of the house of Israel," but that He exhibited His bodily presence only to the people of Israel? He did not proceed Himself to the Gentiles, but sent: to the people of Israel He both sent and came in person, that those who proved despisers should receive the greater judgment, because favored also with the sight of His actual presence.

**[47:66]** The Lord Himself was there: there He chose a mother: there He wished to be conceived, to be born, to shed His blood: there are His footprints, now objects of adoration where last He stood, and  whence He ascended to heaven: but to the Gentiles He only sent.

**[47:67]** 5.

**[47:68]** But perhaps some one thinks that, as He Himself came not to us, but sent, we have not heard His own voice, but only the voice of those whom He sent.

**[47:69]** Far from it: let such a thought be banished from your hearts; for He Himself was in those whom He sent.

**[47:70]** Listen to Paul himself whom He sent; for Paul was specially sent as an apostle to the Gentiles; and it is Paul who, terrifying them not with himself but with Him saith, "Do ye wish to receive a proof of Him who speaketh in me, that is, of Christ?" Listen also to the Lord Himself.

**[47:71]** "And other sheep I have," that is, among the Gentiles, "which are not of this fold," that is, of the people of Israel: "them also must I bring".

**[47:72]** Therefore, even when it is by the instrumentality of His servants, it is He and not another that bringeth them.

**[47:73]** Listen further: "They shall hear my voice".

**[47:74]** See here also, it is He Himself who speaks by His servants, and it is His voice that is heard in those whom He sends.

**[47:75]** "That there may be one fold, and one shepherd".

**[47:76]** Of these two flocks, as of two walls, is the corner-stone formed.

**[47:77]** And thus is He both door and the corner-stone: all by way of comparison, none of them literally.

**[47:78]** 6.

**[47:79]** For I have said so before, and earnestly pressed it on your notice, and those who comprehend it are wise, yea, those who are wise do comprehend it; and yet let those who are not yet intellectually enlightened, keep hold by faith of what they cannot as yet understand.

**[47:80]** Christ is many things metaphorically, which strictly speaking He is not.

**[47:81]** Metaphorically Christ is both a rock, and a door, and a corner-stone, and a shepherd, and a lamb, and a lion.

**[47:82]** How numerous are such similitudes, and as many more as would take too long to enumerate! But if you select the strict significations of things as you are accustomed to see them, then He is neither a rock, for He is not hard and senseless; nor a door, for no artisan made Him; nor a corner-stone, for He was not constructed by a builder; nor a shepherd, for He is no keeper of four-footed animals; nor a lion, as it ranks among the beasts of the forest; nor a lamb, as it belongs to the flock.

**[47:83]** All such, then, are by way of comparison.

**[47:84]** But what is He properly? "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God [God was the Word]".

**[47:85]** And what, as He appeared in human nature? "And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us [in us]".

**[47:86]** 7.

**[47:87]** Hear also what follows.

**[47:88]** "Therefore doth my Father love me," He saith, "because I lay down my life, that I might take it again".

**[47:89]** What is this that He says? "Therefore doth my Father love me:" because I die, that I may rise again.

**[47:90]** For the "I" is uttered with special emphasis: "Because I lay down," He saith, "I lay down my life," "I lay down".

**[47:91]** What is that "I lay down"? I lay it down.

**[47:92]** Let the Jews no longer boast: they might rage, but they could have no power: let them rage as they can; if I were unwilling to lay down my life, what would all their raging effect? By one answer of His they were prostrated in the dust: when they were asked, "Whom seek ye?" they said, "Jesus;" and on His saying to them, "I am He, they went backward, and fell to the ground".

**[47:93]** Those who thus fell to the ground at one word of Christ when about to die, what will they do at the sound of His voice when coming to judgment? "I, I," I say, "lay down my life, that I may take it again".

**[47:94]** Let not the Jews boast, as if they had prevailed; He Himself laid down His life.

**[47:95]** "I laid me down [to sleep]," He says [elsewhere].

**[47:96]** You know the psalm: "I laid me down and slept; and I awaked [rose up], for the Lord sustaineth me".

**[47:97]** What of that—"I lay down"? Because it was my pleasure, I did so.

**[47:98]** What does "I lay down" mean? I died.

**[47:99]** Was it not a lying down to sleep on His part, who, when He pleased, rose from the tomb as He would from a bed? But He loves to give glory to the Father, that He may stir us up to glorify our Creator.

**[47:100]** For in adding, "I arose, for the Lord sustaineth me;" think you there was here a kind of failing in His power, so that, while He had it in His own power to die, He had it not in His power to rise again? So, indeed, the words seem to imply when not more closely considered.

**[47:101]** "I lay down to sleep;" that is, I did so, because I pleased.

**[47:102]** "And I arose:" why? "Because the Lord sustaineth [will sustain] me".

**[47:103]** What then? wouldst Thou not have power to rise of Thyself? If Thou hadst not the power, Thou wouldst not have said, "I have power to lay down my life, and I have power to take it again".

**[47:104]** But, as showing that not only did the Father raise the Son, but the Son also raised Himself,  hear how, in another passage in the Gospel, He saith, "Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up".

**[47:105]** And the evangelist adds: "But this He spake of the temple of His body".

**[47:106]** For only that which died was restored to life.

**[47:107]** The Word is not mortal, His soul is not mortal.

**[47:108]** If even thine dieth not, could the Lord's be subject to death?  8.

**[47:109]** How can I know, thou wilt say, that mine dieth not? Slay it not thyself, and it cannot die.

**[47:110]** How, thou asketh, can I slay my soul? To say nothing meanwhile of other sins, "The mouth that lieth, slayeth the soul".

**[47:111]** How, thou sayest, can I be sure that it dieth not? Listen to the Lord Himself giving security to His servant: "Be not afraid of them that kill the body, and after that have no more that they can do".

**[47:112]** But what in the plainest terms does He say? "Fear Him who hath power to slay both soul and body in hell".

**[47:113]** Here you have the fact that it dieth, and that it doth not die.

**[47:114]** What is its dying? What is dying to thy flesh? Dying, to thy flesh, is the losing of its life: dying to thy soul, is the losing of its life.

**[47:115]** The life of thy flesh is thy soul: the life of thy soul is thy God.

**[47:116]** As the flesh dies in losing the soul, which is its life, so the soul dieth in losing God, who is its life.

**[47:117]** Of a certainty, then, the soul is immortal.

**[47:118]** Manifestly immortal, for it liveth even when dead.

**[47:119]** For what the apostle said of the luxurious widow, may also be said of the soul if it has lost its God, "she is dead while she liveth".

**[47:120]** 9.

**[47:121]** How, then, does the Lord lay down His life [soul]? Let us, brethren, inquire into this a little more carefully.

**[47:122]** The time is not so pressing as is usual on the Lord's day: we have leisure, and theirs will be the profit who have assembled to-day also to wait on the Word of God.

**[47:123]** "I lay down my life," He says.

**[47:124]** Who lays down? What lays He down? What is Christ? The Word and man.

**[47:125]** Not man as being flesh alone: but as man consists of flesh and soul, so, in Christ there is a complete humanity.

**[47:126]** For He would not have assumed the baser part, and left the better behind, seeing that the soul of man is certainly superior to the body.

**[47:127]** Since, then, there is entire manhood in Christ, what is Christ? The Word, I repeat, and man.

**[47:128]** What is the Word and man? The Word, soul, and flesh.

**[47:129]** Keep hold of that, for there has been no lack of heretics on this point also, expelled as they were some time ago from the catholic truth, but still persisting, like thieves and robbers who enter not by the door, to lay their snares around the fold.

**[47:130]** These heretics are termed Apollinarians, and have ventured to assert dogmatically that Christ is only the word and flesh, and contend that He did not assume a human soul.

**[47:131]** And yet some of them could not deny that there was a soul in Christ.

**[47:132]** See their intolerable absurdity and madness.

**[47:133]** They would have Him to possess an irrational soul, but deny Him a rational one.

**[47:134]** They allowed Him a mere animal, they deprived Him of a human, soul.

**[47:135]** But they took away Christ's reason by losing their own.

**[47:136]** Let it be otherwise with us, who have been nourished and established in the catholic faith.

**[47:137]** Accordingly, on this occasion I would remind your Charity, that, as in former lectures, we have given you sufficient instruction against the Sabellians and Arians,—the Sabellians, who say, The Father is the same as the Son—the Arians, who say, The Father is one being, the Son is another, as if the Father and Son were not of the same substance—and also, provided you remember as you ought, against the Photinian heretics, who have asserted that Christ was mere man, and destitute of Godhead: and against the Manicheans, who maintain that He was God only without any true humanity: we may, on this occasion, in speaking about the soul, give you some instruction also in opposition to the Apollinarians, who say that our Lord Jesus Christ had no human soul, that is, a rational intelligent soul,—that soul, I mean, by which, as men, we differ from the brutes.

**[47:138]** 10.

**[47:139]** In what sense, then, did our Lord say here, "I have power to lay down my soul [life]"? Who lays down his soul, and takes it again? Is it as being the Word that Christ does so? Or is it the human soul He possesses that lays down and resumes its own existence? Or is it His fleshly nature that lays down its life and takes it again? Let us sift each of the three questions I have suggested, and choose that which conforms to the standard of truth.

**[47:140]** For if we say that the Word of God laid down His soul, and took it again, we should have to fear the entrance of a wicked thought, and have it said to us: Then there was a time when that soul was separated from the Word, and a time, after His assumption of that soul, when He was without a soul.

**[47:141]** I see, indeed, that the Word  was once without a human soul, but only so, when "in the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

**[47:142]** But from the time that the Word was made flesh, to dwell amongst us, and manhood was assumed by the Word, that is, our whole nature, soul and flesh, what more could His passion and death do than separate the body from the soul? It separated not the soul from the Word.

**[47:143]** For if the Lord died, yea, because He died (for He did so for us on the cross), doubtless His flesh breathed out that which was its life: for a short time the soul forsook the flesh, although destined by its own return to raise the flesh again to life.

**[47:144]** But I cannot say that the soul was separated from the Word.

**[47:145]** He said to the soul of the thief, "To-day shalt thou be with me in paradise".

**[47:146]** He forsook not the believing soul of the robber, and did He abandon His own? Surely not; but when the Lord took that of the other into His keeping, He certainly retained His own in indissoluble union.
